[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I just wanna make sure that I understand what's recurring and what is one-time funding in hopes that we can always keep it at or about this number and it can be routine maintenance throughout each fiscal year moving forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But in order to do that, we just have to make sure we budget accordingly and other line items

[Lungo-Koehn]: as far as like adding additional personnel because you only want to add so much that you can maintain and not have to eventually pull from something like this, which is what they've done in the past.

[Lungo-Koehn]: what is going on with the HVAC and now the MSBA submittals we did on Friday for roofs at our other elementary schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It catches up to you when you don't do routine maintenance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: go back years, but I think we can definitely get you a snapshot of what we're looking at now within the next several weeks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know the finance department's been working on trying to get that together in a readable format for us to just keep an eye on as these are such uncertain times.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I can just add, we did look into that last year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think we looked back about 20 years and there's only been three years where it's been over 2 million and that's been in the last four or five.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, great.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's helpful.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I appreciate that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I can answer that a member member Reinfeld is best I can now Nina, and I, after Courtney has kind of gathered the budgets together Courtney's our budget director, are starting to meet with each department head and understand

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those types of scenarios, because it wasn't just last year that we pulled from the city to help better fund the schools I think it's a priority of the Council myself in the schools to fund our in the school committee to make sure our schools are funded properly to make sure our libraries funded properly.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But having said that, I thank you for asking the question because, yes, we have had tough budget side on the city side with people that were upset because they couldn't do or the things they wanted to do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we're going to take a hard look and see what can be added while at the same time still trying to prioritize our schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're very lucky to have that override pass.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I still, even though schools have a number,

[Lungo-Koehn]: If there's additional funding which I always try, we always try to do, we want to make sure we meet the needs of the schools that's just important piece of puzzle.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So yes, it's a balance, and we have 25 departments, and we are going to try to first add back some of the things we had to cut.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and then see what room there is to maybe grow in a few spots.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we always know we can usually add a position or two, and there's a long list of 20 plus positions that are needed within the departments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I think Nina and I have, and our CFO, have a good pulse on how the departments are operating and which ones need to see a little more growth in that 1%, 2%, 3%, and which ones

[Lungo-Koehn]: can sustain.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it's a work in progress.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We hope to finish those meetings by the end of April so that we can prepare and get the council their budget beginning in May, which is I think in the budget ordinance first week in May.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it's still a work in progress.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Correct.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if the state is going to budget conservatively from what I understood from my meetings yesterday, in case they need to plug gaps like Medicaid, which will be in the billions, then

[Lungo-Koehn]: it's a guessing game of what the state's gonna cover and what the cities and towns are gonna have to cover.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it could be substantial and we're just praying and hoping that it is not.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Great, thanks so much.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we all may rise to salute the flag, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Agenda item number three is the MSBA Accelerated Repair Statements of Interest, SOI.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Peter Cushing, assistant superintendent, and this is concerning the district's intention to submit a statement of interest to the Massachusetts School Building Authority MSBA accelerated program on behalf of the Roberts, the Misituck, and the Brooks Elementary Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford School Committee is hereby asked to approve three separate motions hereby authorizing the administration to formally submit the statement of interest

[Lungo-Koehn]: For the schools listed below under priority five, replacement, renovation and modernization of school facility systems, such as roofs, windows, boilers, heating and ventilation systems to increase energy conservation and decrease energy related costs in school facilities.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number one is the Roberts Elementary School roof and heat pump.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Two is Mississippi Tech Elementary School roof and heat pump.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And number three is Brooks Elementary School roof and heat pump.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Cushing, I don't know if you have anything to add before we take votes and discuss.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then, so the general public's aware, this is the same process we took, just a different category under MSBA as it relates to the work we're doing for the new high school, which we're now excited to share last week that we're in the feasibility study.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So this is just the first phase of trying to get that

[Lungo-Koehn]: portion of these projects paid for through the MSBA.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I want to thank all that are working on these applications from the chair.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Needed projects, of course, is one that has to worry about city and school budgets.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's a lot of work that we are doing on our HVAC and our high school and now these roofs.

[Lungo-Koehn]: nevermind city-side projects, but definitely getting at least 50% reimbursement is something that you just can't pass up trying to do when you have buildings that are 25 years old at this point and their roofs are at the life expectancy or gonna be there shortly.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau, then Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's a motion on the floor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: by Member Graham, seconded by Member Reinfeld.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, I think it's fine.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I also have a student at the Roberts, but I'm going to vote in favor of all three.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 7 the affirmative, 0 the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: ADFW water wellness policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford Public Schools is committed to the health and safety and well-being of our students, faculty, staff, and community partners.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In doing so, the Medford Public Schools commits to providing safe drinkable water for consumption district-wide.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sure.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to waive the full reading by member Reinfeld, seconded by?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll second.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham, I think Scott got you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: She did?

[Lungo-Koehn]: She did.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The reading was waived.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We all want drinkable water.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've recently learned, if I may, from the chair that changing out the faucets, and Dr. Cushing can further elaborate, but the good news is that changing out the faucets did alleviate a lot of our problems.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that is very good news and we will continue working through that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know we got that update from Paul Riggie, our city side facilities director that's helping the schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So is there a motion for approval, if Dr. Cushing doesn't want anything, for the second reading of this policy?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Olapade, seconded by?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, Member Intoppa.

[Lungo-Koehn]: motion for approval by Member Olapade but amended by Member Intoppa.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is there a second?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I can second.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Second reading is passed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Under new business, we have 2025-07 offered by Member Olapade and Member Reinfeld.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Resolution in support of MPS's LGBTQIA plus community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford School Committee affirms the Medford Public Schools commitment

[Lungo-Koehn]: to protecting the safety, dignity, and educational rights of our queer and gender non-conforming community members.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We recognize and celebrate the unique qualities and potential that each of these individuals brings to our community and reject any efforts to erase, denigrate, or weaponize their identities as a direct affront to the values and practices of member public schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We remain committed to upholding the non-discrimination principles and protocols outlined in Mass General Laws, Chapter 76, Section 5, and Chapter 662, Medford Public Schools policies AC, ACA1, ACE, ACA-E, and JB, and all federal laws that prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex, sexual orientation, or gender identity.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also affirm students' and employees' right to privacy in accordance with the above

[Lungo-Koehn]: in other relevant state and federal laws.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it further resolved, the Metropolitan Public Schools shall continue all activities and initiatives to ensure a healthy and welcoming school environment for our queer, questioning, and gender nonconforming community members in and beyond the classroom, included but not limited to the gay, lesbian, bisexual, pansexual, and asexual students, teachers, and staff, including but not limited to transgender, nonbinary, genderfluid, and intersex students, teachers, and staff.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, thank you Member Reinfeld.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Olapade?

[Lungo-Koehn]: So the motion for approval by Member Reinfeld as amended in the two locations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There were two.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was to add the policy, additional policies under school policy, and then on the first paragraph, you wanted to add... I have the first paragraph.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then roll call, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes as amended.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Offered by Member Olapade and Member Reinfeld

[Lungo-Koehn]: 2025-08, whereas federal and state level actions outside of Massachusetts have recently sought to limit educational practices, restrict local control, and suppress diverse perspectives in public schools across the nation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee believes that education should empower students with the knowledge, critical thinking skills, and cultural awareness necessary to thrive in a diverse society and to contribute meaningfully to their communities.

[Lungo-Koehn]: whereas the Medford School Committee recognizes that a high quality education must respect and celebrate the abilities, needs, and potential of all students, regardless of race, ethnicity, nationality, gender identity, sexual orientation, ability, socioeconomic status, religion, or language background.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Therefore, be it resolved, the Medford School Committee reaffirms its unwavering commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion as foundational principles that inform all aspects of district policy, curriculum development,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and educational practice.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have further resolved the Medford School Committee fully supports the district's use of robust and inclusive educational resources that accurately reflect and affirm the diverse lived experiences of our students and families, provide historically and culturally responsive curricula that honor the contributions and histories of all people, including historically marginalized communities.

[Lungo-Koehn]: equip students with the knowledge, skills, and global awareness necessary to engage in respectful dialogue, civic engagement, and lifelong learning.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it further resolved, the Medford School Committee strongly opposes any efforts to restrict or eliminate essential academic content, including history, art, science, literature, and health education on the basis of political ideology,

[Lungo-Koehn]: that seek to erase diverse voices and lived experiences.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it further resolved, the Medford School Committee unequivocally opposes the removal of resources, support systems, or accommodations for neurodiverse learners and students with disabilities, recognizing that access to an equitable and inclusive education is a fundamental right for all students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it further resolved, the Medford School Committee extends this commitment beyond the classroom, ensuring that extracurricular activities, afterschool programming,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and school-sponsored initiatives remain inclusive and accessible to all students fostering leadership, creativity, and personal growth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it further resolved, the Medford School Committee will not tolerate bullying, harassment, or intimidation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: whether from within or outside the district, particularly when such actions seek to undermine students' rights to a fair, comprehensive, and affirming education in a safe and welcoming environment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it finally resolved that the Medford School Committee remains steadfast in its mission to cultivate a school system that is inclusive, equitable, and empowering for all students, staff, and families, and will continue to advocate for policies and practices that advance these values.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is there a motion for approval?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I remember in Tapa seconded by second member Bramley.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Member Olapade.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Reinfeld?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, both.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's been a motion and a second, so I'm going to ask Member Ruseau to call the roll, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm in the affirmative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do not have any everyone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

Skerry, former Medford School Committee member and cousin to Medford High School teacher and unified basketball coach John Skerry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just don't want, I want to point out something Mr. Petrellis mentioned, that this is an affordable camp that people of all different economic backgrounds use, including many that can't afford six acres and

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I would just make a suggestion if, I know we can't make amendments on the floor, but just to people to think about maybe spreading that $75 increase out over two years, just to make it a little bit more digestible for families, like Mr. Petrella said, that are struggling to get by.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford School Committee appoints member Rousseau as the representative to the Shore Educational Collaborative Board of Directors.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion on the floor by

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to approve.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And member Graham seconded by second, but can I just speak real quick?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, thank you for serving.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham moved approval, seconded by Member Intoppa.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Paper passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: offered by member Rousseau, member Olapade, and member Reinfeld, 2025-02.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And please bear with me, it's a couple pages, but I think it's important to read out loud.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford Public Schools does not request immigration status as part of its registration process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: MPS is committed to serving all children whose principal domicile is in Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The district is committed to maintaining a safe and productive learning environment for its students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To provide a public education regardless of a child or family immigration status absent any applicable federal, state, or local law, regulation, ordinance, or court decision, and in the absence of proof of criminal proceedings as described by law enforcement agency, the district shall abide by the following practices and procedures.

[Lungo-Koehn]: discrimination, harassment, and bullying.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In accordance with the district's non-discrimination and bullying prevention policies, number one, any allegations of bullying or harassment of students based on their race, ethnicity, color, national origin, or immigration status shall be promptly investigated and handled in accordance with the district policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Two, student residency determinations will not be based in whole or in part on the student's immigration status.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three,

[Lungo-Koehn]: District personnel will not inquire about a student's immigration status or require documentation of a student's legal status, such as asking for a green card or citizenship papers at initial registration or at any other time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Four, district personnel will not make unreasonable inquiries on a student or his or her parents, guardians, or to expose a child or his or her family's immigration status.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Five, district personnel shall be attentive to school curricula to ensure that it is inclusive and non-discriminatory.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All district curricula shall encourage respect for the civil rights of individuals regardless of race, color, sex, gender identity, religion, national origin, or sexual orientation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Six, district personnel will not require students to apply for social security numbers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seven, district personnel shall promptly report any potential alleged hate crime to the local law enforcement agency.

[Lungo-Koehn]: access to records in accordance with Metro Public Schools student record policy and state laws and regulations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 603 CMR 23.00.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One, unless distracted by the superintendent and under a signed judicial court order, district personnel shall not share student record information, including immigration status, with any immigration law enforcement official or agent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Two, all requests for student records or student record information, documents by ICE or INS, should be forwarded to the superintendent, who may consult with the district's legal counsel to determine if the documents can be released.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three principles may remind families of their right to opt out of disclosure of student directory information, which includes the student's name, address, and date of birth, place of birth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: access to school premises.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Because an ICE or INS visit may severely disrupt the educational setting, requests by ICE slash INS to visit a school site will be denied unless the superintendent is prepared with a signed judicial court order.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The superintendent's office will review the order with legal counsel before a decision is made to allow access to the site.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If immigration law enforcement agents arrive at your school building, principals shall take the following steps.

[Lungo-Koehn]: students may be called in case of an emergency.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One do not allow the agents into the school building and still until instructed to do so to request identification from the agents and a copy of any judicial warrant.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three immediately contact the superintendent's office for further instruction.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dismissal of students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Students may only be dismissed persons specified by parents, guardians in writing principles may remind families to update student emergency contact

[Lungo-Koehn]: to parents, guardians may be provided with a caregiver affidavit to designate someone to make educational and or medical decisions for a child temporarily living with someone other than the parents, guardians.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Handling of students whose parents, guardians have been detained or taken into custody.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If the district receives notification that parents, guardians of a student

[Lungo-Koehn]: have been detained or taken into custody by immigration law enforcement officials or agents, the district shall take the following steps.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One, contact the persons listed on the student's emergency card to inform the persons of the situation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Ask if they can retrieve the student.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Two, make arrangements for school Councilors to be available to support the student.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three, contact the Department of Children and Families.

[Lungo-Koehn]: if parents, guardians have not authorized a responsible adult to receive the student.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Four, consult with the district's McKinney-Vento liaison if the student becomes unhoused due to their parent, guardian's detention.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I will turn it over to member Rousseau, member LaPadia, member Reinfeld, if you'd like to speak on this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Just repeat which one you're eliminating.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Intoppa.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, so is there a motion on the floor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Olapade.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You can raise your hand up, I'll be listening.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But thanks for your honesty in telling me who's first.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I really appreciate that at all.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Honest board.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, member Olapade, member Branley.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, so motion for approval, I take it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Runfeld.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As amended, seconded by Member Olapade.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: OK, I think nobody's online with their hand up.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have no reports requested, and we do have a few condolences.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The members of the Medford School Committee expressed their sincerest condolences to the family of John R. Granara Jr., who served as a member of the Medford School Committee and a member of the Superintendent Search Committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, he chaired, established the Conner Scholarship for students in Medford, pursuing higher education and vocational training,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, the members of the Medford School Committee expressed their sincerest condolences to the family of James E. Morell, father of Andrea Bell, a reading specialist at the McGlynn Elementary School, as well as the husband of Mary Morell, who worked for former Mayor McGlynn.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Members of the Medford School Committee expressed their sincerest condolences to the family of Marie L. Cabanero Ward, grandmother of Dr. Suzanne B. Galussi, interim superintendent of schools,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Did I pronounce it right?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sorry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, you did.

[Lungo-Koehn]: She passed away peacefully just days before her 100th birthday.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we all may rise for a moment of silence.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our next regular meeting is February 10th, 2025, here in the Alden Memorial Chambers, Medford City Hall, in addition to Zoom.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have our Lunar New Year celebration, 10 a.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: to 1 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: at the Senior Center on Saturday.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Otherwise, have a wonderful rest of the week.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to adjourn?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Intoppa, seconded by Member Reinfeld.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Brianna is fine, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Terry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Good morning, everyone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm honored to be here today to celebrate Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'

[Lungo-Koehn]: 's life and legacy with you all.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you to everyone who makes this wonderful event possible, the West Medford Community Center for organizing and running this event, led by Executive Director Lisa Crossman and Terry Carter, Medford Community Media for being with us today, St.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Rayfield's Parish for hosting, and Wegmans, the Mystic Valley branch of the NAACP, and Needham Bank for your support and sponsorship.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also have an amazing keynote speaker with us today, Celia Johnston, Blue of the Massachusetts Women of Color Coalition.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you for being here and offering your words and insights.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This year's theme, your piece of the dream, is an important idea and deserves our thought and reflection.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We all have dreams of a brighter, more peaceful, and united future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We all strive to be more caring, more forgiving, and more empathetic of one another's situations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But making these dreams a reality is harder than it looks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why we must look to the past before making our plans for the future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. King's words and actions provide us with a roadmap to equality and equity.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it's up to us to emulate those ideals and put them into action in our lives.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So let's strive to do better each day together as a community continuing to reach our goal of equality for all.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I look forward to the wonderful program.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you for having me and can't wait.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Can you hear me?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Bears and the City Council for allowing us to be here tonight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With me is Chief of Staff Nina Nazarian, Human Resource Director Lisa Crowley, DPW Commissioner Tim McGivern, and you just heard from Scott Brink, who is our

[Lungo-Koehn]: deputy commissioner.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also have, um, Chief Evans is on the call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know OT is on the agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Unfortunately, Scott van der Waal, our building commissioner, is away on vacation today.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I believe he comes back tomorrow, but I can talk to the issue.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First, I just want to thank Councilor Scarpelli for reading

[Lungo-Koehn]: the email that we sent today with regards to overtime and what we've been doing, especially over the last year in all departments that have overtime budgets.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I wanna thank you for allowing us to read the email that Scott Brink sent about the drug testing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We just want to be able to tell our story and tell the facts as we see it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll start with what Councilor Scarpelli said

[Lungo-Koehn]: with regards to dinner breaks, because I just need to get the facts out there, and I think it's important, because there is another side to that story.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There is a lawsuit that the building inspectors have filed against the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They are demanding over a million dollars.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And one of those pieces of that lawsuit is that they're stating they didn't take a lunch for three years, and they're looking for triple damages.

[Lungo-Koehn]: almost $400,000 demand.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So since that lawsuit was filed, we in the city have been actively, over the last six to nine months, actively working to implement timesheets.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Timesheets are now implemented.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's a way to track when an employee comes to work, when they leave for lunch, when they come back from lunch, and then when they check out for the day.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It happens in private sector and a lot of cities and towns do do it, and it's a way to ensure that our employees are taking lunch and when they're taking that lunch.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now, Councilor Scarpelli is incorrect.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There was no threats made to any building inspector.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I would not do that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What I did do is I did have a meeting with the commissioner that night.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I went down.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and witnessed everybody having dinner, so we did just say, I did say to the commissioner, please make sure that all breaks, lunch, dinner, are recorded on those timesheets.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That didn't happen, so our staff, HR director, chief of staff, we just notified Commissioner van der Waal that either the hour needs to be split if they're gonna take a dinner break,

[Lungo-Koehn]: or they need to stop.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We didn't say stop dinner.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We said, if you want to take a dinner break, that's absolutely fine.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You're just going to have to put in your time for dinner as 5 to 6 or 5.30, 6.30, whichever it may be, and obviously work through lunch like the rest of the staff does.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it wasn't a don't take a dinner.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's you have one hour a day, like everybody else, and that hour just needs to be recorded on the timesheets that we now fill out

[Lungo-Koehn]: pretty much because of the lawsuit.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I did let them know.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I mean, I feel like we have a really good staff down there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I respect our inspectors.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They are suing the city, and I believe they were pushed to sue the city, not even realizing what the outcomes would be.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think the gentleman's in the audience that tries to get people within City Hall to file different suits against the city because

[Lungo-Koehn]: people love to come to the, or this gentleman loves to come up to the podium and either say, there's too many lawsuits, there's too much spent on attorney's fees, or there's too many settlements.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Making the situation pretty difficult for the administration because if you have somebody actively asking employees or telling employees or pushing employees to file suits against the city, of course the city needs to defend those suits and pay attorneys.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What Mr. Scarpelli is inaccurate about is that we're losing lawsuits.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're not losing lawsuits.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're defending grievances and charges.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And this is probably one of the biggest lawsuits we unfortunately have.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it's stressful for the administration who has to also balance a budget on the resources that we have.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think George Scarpelli said it best.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When you were talking about the welcoming ordinance, it's a question of if we can survive.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's where we're at in Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why we did overrides.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And so to know that you have a unit being pushed to file suit against the city and we're spending money to defend

[Lungo-Koehn]: one way or another, that's taking money away from other city services, or it's taking money away from our school department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's a tough pill to swallow.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I did let them know that they're good people, and I was gonna have to sometime, such as tonight, gonna have to tell the city's story, our story, and what we're going through.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I just wanted to lay that out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Anybody can take a dinner break, anybody can go home for dinner or lunch, it's just that

[Lungo-Koehn]: Every single employee that is filling out timesheets that's not a department head has an hour.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They have an hour.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You can use it whatever way you want, but make sure it's recorded on your timesheets.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now, as it relates to overtime, there are calls that are placed by the dispatch to our building commissioner, and he and he alone decides whether or not to send an inspector out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There are times when inspectors go out building,

[Lungo-Koehn]: electrical, and there are times where he may say, it's not needed, it can wait till tomorrow morning at 8.30.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's not up to me, I don't get the calls.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I don't wanna get the calls.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why we have a backup.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And our prior commissioner, Bill 40, has graciously been willing to stay on in a very, very limited capacity.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He's taken four phone calls in the last year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: at $60 a call when building commissioner van der Waals not available.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So he's not on staff.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He's not part time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He is the backup for when dispatch calls to give the explanation of why a building inspector may be needed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm completely left out of that process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's our building commissioner, and then it's our prior building commissioner, and one of them will take that call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think this is stemming from a call from last week or the week before where our building commissioner did say to dispatch, I don't think we need an inspector at this call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That was one time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I can't speak for him because he is on vacation, but that was one time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And this is stemming from one phone call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's no protocol in place that says they will no longer respond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was just that one phone call, and I don't fully remember the circumstances.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But the building commissioner is the expert in this field, and he knows when we need to send an inspector and when it can wait till the next morning at 8.30.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I just wanted to set that record straight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My email to you all has been read into the record.

[Lungo-Koehn]: OT is something I do take seriously.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and I've been really working with all of our department heads to figure out ways to make sure that we are providing OT to our staff, but making sure it's not misused, making sure it's not overused.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think it's something that the public would want us to do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They want us to be able to budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They wanna make sure there's no waste.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So to spin up a story that we are denying our employees overtime is completely false.

[Lungo-Koehn]: millions and millions on overtime.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm just trying to get a handle with Chief Evans and Chief Buckley and Building Commissioner Van De Wall and Commissioner McGivern and Deputy Commissioner Brink.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're asking the questions that need to be asked.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's something that was on my agenda from the beginning, and I really dug into it the last year, especially after February, to make sure we got a handle on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's something my

[Lungo-Koehn]: the whole administration is really working towards.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that's our story.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That is the city's side.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those are the facts.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I really thank you for your time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know we can't all always be on the call on Tuesday nights, but I needed to set the record straight on a few of these things.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our staff needed to set the record straight because there is always another side to the story.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'm sorry,

[Lungo-Koehn]: can't get in the weeds and tell it every Tuesday night.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're doing extremely, a lot of work and it's just very appreciated for the time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think we're all here to answer questions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll leave it up to city staff to raise hands if they have anything to add.

[Lungo-Koehn]: but we are here to answer some questions before we head off, and obviously a little bit.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Anytime somebody

[Lungo-Koehn]: from within DPW has come to me with concerns about drug use.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's always been about the past.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Like two weeks ago, there was an this happened or that happened.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As of recent, I was told that there was needle caps found in the vehicles and that people were driving under the influence, alleged people driving under the influence, and they were very concerned.

[Lungo-Koehn]: but it was about things that have happened within the past month.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it wasn't something that I was told the day of.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We were told the day of, I let the building commissioner, DPW commissioner and the DPW deputy commissioner know, hey, I got this allegation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Can you please bring so-and-so in?

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is being alleged.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That was not the case.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It wasn't until we found, and I'll let Scott take over, it wasn't until we found

[Lungo-Koehn]: a hypodermic needle in a trash barrel.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It wasn't there the day before that we knew that something took place or could have taken place that day.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we took action that day.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll turn it over to the building commissioner, but that I just want to explain why past allegations didn't lead to immediate drug testing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's because things were being reported of having been happened within the last week or two or three.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, I can answer that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think I answered it when I spoke the first time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Deputy, Commissioner Forty was the prior building commissioner.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And when he took another opportunity in another city or town and we did not have a commissioner, he did take the phone calls from dispatch.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When we hired Commissioner Van Der Waal, he then became the primary to take phone calls

[Lungo-Koehn]: to be able to send out inspectors to calls, and we wanted a backup in case Commissioner van der Waal is away on vacation or doesn't answer the phone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For example, he does not answer the phone when he's driving, and sometimes he goes away and cannot get to the phone calls.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So like I said before, there have been

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think four times when Commissioner van de Walt has not been available to pick up a call from dispatch.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we need a backup listed in dispatch and prior Commissioner Forty is our backup to pick up those calls so that we have somebody other than a building inspector dispatching themselves like we had over a year ago.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that was a change we made over a year ago.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We now have a commissioner and then the prior commissioner as a backup to dispatch calls if they think that an inspector is needed at a scene.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if I can, just while I have you before I hop off, I wanna just point out, I know, I believe it was in the email from Deputy Commissioner Brink, but one other issue we've had

[Lungo-Koehn]: being reported was accidents within our Department of Public Works, damage to vehicles and motor vehicle accidents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the one several weeks ago that took place was actually reported by a resident.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So not only are there needle calves being found in vehicles, reported driving under the influence of employees, and there's been multiple

[Lungo-Koehn]: There was also the hypodermic needle found and several accidents and being reported, including the representative who was in with HR stating there's accidents that we're not aware of.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So all that circumstances led us to what do we do?

[Lungo-Koehn]: We don't wanna have to do this, but God forbid, and this is what I think of, God forbid we had an accident with a DPW vehicle, our employee,

[Lungo-Koehn]: hit somebody walking on the sidewalk.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That type of lawsuit is what we need to prevent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We needed to find a way to make sure we protected our employees, got them help if they need it, and to make sure we got to the bottom of what was in that trash barrel to make sure anybody operating heavy machinery, that day especially,

[Lungo-Koehn]: that we took the proper steps, and that's what we had to do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is it's $60 when he's called so $60 times times four over the year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He is not paid Any we do not pay the prior building commissioner a weekly paycheck We pay him her backup call, which I believe it could be five, but I'm almost positive It's for or since he took the backup role.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I clear up just one more thing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Immediately when I was told of needle caps being found in trucks and employees worried about other employees, I immediately, I immediately

[Lungo-Koehn]: and I have the emails to prove it, reached out to our human resource director and our building commissioner to let them know this is what's being reported.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It wasn't today, it wasn't yesterday, but within the last month, staff are finding hypodermic needle caps in vehicles, and they're worried about their fellow employees, and they obviously want us to do something, but we can't do anything today.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that is in writing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those are emails sent to city staff.

[Lungo-Koehn]: that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I know that Councilor Newton took that very seriously.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Um, so I just want to make that that clear.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That was not said.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I never would ask somebody to drop a lawsuit.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I said, they said, sit down and have some dinner.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I said, I don't take breaks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I said, while I have you, because I was supposed to meet with Scott, while I have you, I just want to let you know that I'm dealing with your lawsuit and I'm struggling with it, especially since the council, meaning you and the gentleman in the audience, are going to be before the podium claiming there's too much legal fees, there's too many lawsuits.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I know in my, I do know, I said to the inspectors, I said, I do know who pushed you to file suit.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I said, but while I'm struggling to fund a school budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is difficult, and I'm gonna have to go public with the facts, and I'm just, out of courtesy, letting you know, our building commission was present.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I never once asked them to drop a lawsuit, quite the contrary.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They said, well, we don't, we're not, you know, and I said, listen, I know who asked you to file that lawsuit.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know they probably told you it was gonna be a quick payout, but I have to defend it here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's over a million dollars.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was an $850,000 demand that I got in writing and then additional claims were added on after for things like you didn't take a lunch or you'll want to be paid double time for Wednesdays while they're having dinner.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm having people tell me it's not a working dinner, whether it is or isn't, we'll figure that out in court.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I just feel bad, I feel bad that we even have to bring their names up when, in my opinion, they're used by the gentleman in the audience so that the gentleman in the audience can say that the city has too many lawsuits against them, the mayor's paying too much for legal fees, or there's too many settlements.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And you say settlements, and I can only think of one settlement we negotiated.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I really, you're inflating the number of lawsuits that we're settling out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if you wanna talk about contracts, we've settled them all.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The two union representatives from the Teamsters have been amazing to work with, with contracts.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've settled almost every single one except the building.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's a difficult one to swallow.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Even though it was ratified during my time, it was negotiated in 2019, right before an election.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is the most generous contract.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our building inspectors are paid more than most of our department heads.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's lucky for them, paid more than our department heads.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But it comes to a point where there needs to be equity within the organization.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And so building inspectors making upwards of $26,000 a year in stipends, there's a point where I have to say, I can't give you as much as I gave public safety.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just can't.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They're making more than our public safety officers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They're making far more than our teachers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm doing my best to negotiate contracts and to bring some equity to the organization on so many levels.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And for people to be making more than our department heads, I'm trying to level it off a bit.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So yes, we are still in negotiations, and we will try to work through that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I'm managing as best I can, and we're doing the best we can.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Testing, testing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The first regular meeting of the Medford School Committee will come to order.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is January 13th, 2025.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have executive session at 5 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and our regular meeting at or about 6 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting is being recorded.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed live on the Medford Public Schools YouTube channel, or through Medford Community Media on your local cable channel, Comcast channel nine, eight, or 22, and Verizon channel 43, 45, 47.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Participants can log or call in by using the following Zoom link.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you very much for the presentation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We don't have any presentations of the public or continued business, but we do have new business offered by member and topper.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Policy ADF-W-Water Wellness Policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford Public Schools is committed to the health, safety, and wellbeing of our students, faculty, staff, and community partners.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In doing so, the Medford Public Schools commits to providing safe drinking water for consumption district-wide.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To ensure safe water, the following testing frequency will occur.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Water testing for all non-drinking

[Lungo-Koehn]: Intended fixtures, bathroom sinks, slop sinks, outdoor fixtures will occur every four calendar years to ensure that action level demands are met for lead proper levels, water testing for all drinking intended fixtures, kitchen sinks, classroom sinks, water fountains, water filtration, filter systems, stations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: will take place every two calendar years to ensure the action level demands are met for lead copper levels.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Action levels.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The action levels per 310CMR22, the Massachusetts drinking water regulations are defined as follows for each metal.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the presence of lead results in the range of 1 to 15 ppb and or equal to or greater than 15 ppb.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford Public Schools will conduct water testing of all fixtures in said building at least twice a singular calendar year until all results yield 1 ppb.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Testing will continue at this frequency for an additional year to ensure safety needs are met.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the presence of copper results equal to greater than 1300 ppb, the Medford Public Schools will conduct water testing of all fixtures in said building at least twice a singular calendar year until all results yielded.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Testing will continue at this frequency for an additional year to ensure safety needs are met.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Action plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If the action levels are met.

[Lungo-Koehn]: per 310 CMR 22.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The following procedures must be met by the administration and building staff in the presence of lead results in the range of one to 15 ppb.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Hand washing only signs must be posted at each impacted fixture in the presence of lead results equal to or greater than 15 ppb.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The fixture must be disabled and signage must be posted at each impacted fixture.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The presence

[Lungo-Koehn]: of copper results equal to or greater than 1300 PVV, the fixture must be disabled and signage must be posted at each impacted fixture.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All action plan items must be communicated and executed in the impacted communities of the impacted building no later than 36 hours after this discovery of said results.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Intoppa.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If I may, through the chair,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Where did you get these standards?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Because I do know a lot of this is relevant to the hand washing only signs, but removal of fixtures, did you get this somewhere specific?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Just because if it's safe to wash your hands after you run the water for 30 seconds, why would we remove the fixtures and test twice a year?

[Lungo-Koehn]: The fixture must be disabled, so.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And you got this language from the MWRA?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, motion for approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And Dr. Cushing, do you feel that this policy is doable?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And do we know if this is how it's handled in most school districts?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mabruso?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Remember in Tapa.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, and I just don't want to set somebody up for failure, whoever has to take this project on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Because we don't know what the problem is yet.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're looking into it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Right.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've ordered new fixtures to see if it is fixtures.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Reinfeld.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Oh, it was?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 2024-42 offered by member Reinfeld whereas a resolution was offered and approved at the June 24 2024 special meeting of the member school committee that the committee receive a report by December 15, describing the implementation impact of position reductions between the previous and current budget year to inform the budget request for the upcoming fiscal year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas the voters of Medford authorized on November 5, 2024 the assessment of additional tax funds to support the district staffing needs and expand access to programming, be it therefore resolved the report shall focus on concerns identified during the spring budget hearings and prioritizes expressed during the fall campaign season

[Lungo-Koehn]: including but not limited to the district's ability to provide students with ongoing and acute mental health support are some vocational programming and administrative support as well as the effect of staffing changes on class and caseload sizes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He further resolved that the presentation of the report be limited to roles and responsibilities independent of individual employees' performances and other confidential matters.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We just don't have the funding

[Lungo-Koehn]: He's actually.

[Lungo-Koehn]: involved in the school department, banks, and so has our director of planning and development and sustainability.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They're helping the schools make sure that we are getting work done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We made sure that all of the door locks have been changed, so now we know who has

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had lights that were running out, there was no lighting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These are the projects that we are working on to maintain.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we've never had, it's like we do now on the city side, but on the school side, we still don't have those routine maintenance yearly checks, write-in checks of our systems.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've let our HR get so bad in the last 20 years on our political school loan that it's costing us over a million dollars for an OPM and architect.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it's almost $20 million to get AC and HVAC just to those two schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They were built at the same time as our other non-federal schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's just the HVAC, VRM, et cetera.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So to be able to put in several hundred thousand dollars to do routine maintenance and annual maintenance of our schools is essential.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need to do it to prevent the bad.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We can't let that, we can't go on like this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We just can't, especially when we have residents who are saying, please help fund our school, fund our city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and putting it to a vote.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You know, there are people that I know can't afford it, and I've said in my videos, and I'll say tonight, there are exceptions out there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our assessors have an online paper copies in our assessor's office.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a calculator on our city website that will tell you how this will affect you and what options there are for you if there are exemptions and exclusions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So there are ways, and the biggest part of that question seven is current personnel in our State Department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now we did, we'll say do the hard work, you're not managing right.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Remember Graham and I, and the school committee, and the superintendent, and our finance staff, we did the hard, we did some very hard work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We got two to three million dollars from our school department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We want the taxpayers to let us know, do you want us to do it again?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Because we're going to have to cut at least $2 million in staff on the school side, but it's also going to take things up on the city side, because I prioritize our schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And there are going to be some tough budget meetings moving forward if question seven doesn't pass, because I'll be

[Lungo-Koehn]: I mean, we're talking meetings going over budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's like, please level the bottom as much as you can.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're already talking about that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's not mismanagement, it's the fact that school costs, which is the largest piece of this puzzle, is up at least 8% across the state.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We can't cut homeless transportation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's about $500,000.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Jenny probably knows the numbers better than I do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We cannot cut certain things that are essential in our school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Homeless transportation, transportation, special ed costs, they can't be cut.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So our cuts are coming from people.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our cuts are going straight to the classroom, straight to the mental health supports, the guidance Councilors, people that are needed for our students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since COVID it's been extremely tough.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our children are struggling and knowing that we did the hard work and we made the adjustments and we changed what I felt needed to be changed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I worked with the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I worked with the city council.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We passed a budget and we came up with this plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We worked together.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's been very, very transparent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Everything we've done, we've laid out in press releases.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think there's about four up there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is all transparent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We want you to have the right to vote.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes or no?

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's a debt exclusion.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Once that debt's paid off, that will fall off your due taxes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So yes, it passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Question seven, you spoke about.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So now's the time for

[Lungo-Koehn]: Some cities and towns do overrides quite often.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've never done it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In support of these override questions, I'll be voting yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just ask that you do your homework.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I ask that you keep an open mind and really just think about it, especially how it will affect you and your family.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I understand that this is both of the people of my burden.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I hope they're successful.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now, to therefore, what does that mean?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Like I said, I've done a pre-cash video, and then on the city side, we just put out a diagram of city needs, what would that be?

[Lungo-Koehn]: 100% open spend of free cash on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It just outlines the needs in Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have over 100 million in backlog on our streets and sidewalks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're putting out a press release this week with regards to 10,000 homes that will get a letter in November letting them know they either have landlines into their home or that they're an unknown.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's going to be upwards of a hundred plus million dollars for the city to fix those lead mines.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So there you have over $200,000 million, $200 million.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Then you also have a large issue with water and sewer infrastructure,

[Lungo-Koehn]: put in over 420 years ago, that is probably several hundred million dollars to do our water and sewer infrastructure.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So between the lead that needs to be, the new federal guidelines say we need to take care of this lead line issue over the next eight to ten years, we have to fix our streets and sidewalks, and we have to fix our water and sewer infrastructure.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That alone is

[Lungo-Koehn]: $400 million.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Then we have in the pocket, right here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: several million in different buckets.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One, like Councilor Callahan said, is five million into a stabilization account.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That is our emergency fund, and that is important to have in case some large project, like a new roof, needs to get done anyway.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Then we put, that included, we put six million into that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Five million went into a capital improvement stabilization account.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that was five million, it was our first,

[Lungo-Koehn]: First stabilization comes ever, and as of July 1st, we either had projects go over in cost, or we've had emergencies of about $1.2 million, just from July 1st.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That includes the Brooks School hot water heater, the blue, that was a couple hundred thousand.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had,

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that was a water feeder.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had road safety, traffic safety improvements at Central and Spring Street.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That project was over $250,000 that we needed to spend money on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Today, there was another request for a grant match, for an MVP grant match of $35,000, and the list goes on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So in just a matter of a few months, we needed to spend $1.1 million.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That account is down to $3.9.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that just goes to show the emergencies and the overages and the cost of things that we need to get done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a capital improvement plan that you can also access on our website.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That has us spending millions of dollars a year just on equipment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: DBW, police cruisers, fire trucks, and the list goes on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So please take a look at our capital improvement plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's a six-year plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've, Collin Center helped us with that plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: the most professional planning efforts ever had.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we had one that was done in 2021, and we just re-updated it two years later.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that's on our website.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We averaged over the last couple decades, we've averaged anywhere from

[Lungo-Koehn]: one to one and a half million in new growth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This past fiscal year, we brought that up, that number up to 2.5 million.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we are growing in new growth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've doubled the size of our planning department, thankfully, which is planning, development, and sustainability, and we have our first ever economic development director who's trying to bring in new business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we've been working extremely hard on

[Lungo-Koehn]: a number of projects that are in the works, and a number of projects that are coming in the future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, we are doing well with regrowth, but we're always looking to expand.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think we've, you should correct me if I'm wrong, but we had

[Lungo-Koehn]: five or six life science facilities that were ready to move forward, and that market kind of fell apart.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I started asking developers to bring life science to Medford right when I became mayor in 2020, and at that time it was too late.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we are,

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're trying to get the tech industry, we're trying to get multi, we just put an RFP out for our three lots in Medford Square, that's gonna be mixed use, affordable housing, commercial, so we are doing everything we can, we're gonna have the space above the well into the air rights, and we're moving, but it just takes time, so you see a lot of development now, but you see more and more as the years go by.

[Lungo-Koehn]: it was likely to be a 30-year loan for $30 million to build a new high school, and that wouldn't hit, fire station, I'm sorry, fire station, and that wouldn't hit our tax rolls this year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That would be next year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In debt exclusion, yes, we're asking for 30 million for a new headquarters, and the question was the process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Back when I was on the city council, there was a proposal that was put before us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was actually no community involvement, no involvement from anybody that I'm aware of except the chief of police at the time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it was just put before us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was a design of a new police headquarters.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And at the time, as a city councilor, I just asked that we take

[Lungo-Koehn]: a couple months to explore a combined station, a fire and a police station.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Combined station would save us money in the long run.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That didn't happen, so once I became mayor, obviously as I was campaigning, I made it a central issue to make sure that we also take a look at our fire headquarters and all of our fire buildings, there's six of them, and we put the work in that needs to be put in to make the living environment and the work environment a better place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So since that time, I commissioned a task force.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have put millions of dollars into the five substations, windows, roofs, new kitchens, and the list goes on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I also tasked my chief of staff, who is my trade and engineer, to lead that project.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So she's been working on the EnviroHeadquarters for about

[Lungo-Koehn]: over two years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I've kind of taken a step back.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have other things to do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's a long list, so we divide and conquer, but she led that chapter with the prior fire chief and the current fire chief, and we've created a plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Right now, it's still in concept design.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's hopefully going into final design, especially if this vote passes, and we're working towards it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: for a building that's 70 years old that needs a lot of work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's the same problems that we have in the police station from ventilation to rodents to windows that need to be replaced and living quarters that need to be better maintained and updated.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the list goes on, and it's an old building, and our department and our city deserves better.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it's debt exclusion.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We chose to go debt exclusion because you can bond multiple ways.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One is through debt exclusion, and that is the extra tax.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Or you can put it on the budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You can put the debt on the budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But in my mind, if you're paying hundreds of thousands of dollars on your bond each year for our headquarters that we could have a debt exclusion on, in my mind, you're taking money away from our schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we just can't afford that right now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We haven't been able to.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think this is the much better route.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So what will happen if this doesn't pass?

[Lungo-Koehn]: They don't know how long we would build.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll just get into the last piece a bit because although

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm one member of the school committee, and Member Graham's one member, it's seven members have to vote on something, and the superintendent and the finance director create the budget, obviously with our help and advice and discussion.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're pretty clear, this is two million, question seven is two million in personnel, it's Chromebooks for our students, it's maintenance for our buildings, and it's a DPW crew.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now, will the superintendent want to take $50,000 from the maintenance to help with busing or special ed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's going to be, obviously, the prerogative of the superintendent and finance director, but we are not going to go cut positions to fund something else.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're being as clear as possible, knowing that, obviously, things will live.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And with question eight, it's going to cost at least that or more.

[Lungo-Koehn]: to extend the school day.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're not spending it another way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the debt exclusion is the debt exclusion.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I don't buy the argument that we're just going to go into the general fund and we're going to spend it on X, Y, and Z. We work very hard, member Graham and I, and Councilor Callahan as well, to balance the budget, to know the needs,

[Lungo-Koehn]: You know, that's what the taxpayers want us to do, and we do it every day.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now, we don't have full control of the schools, but we spend a lot of time, we spend a lot of time on that area, and I'm doing it on the city side, and it's the first time the city's had human resources in Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There was no human resources in the city of Medford until four years ago when I became mayor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, holding people accountable, making sure your tax dollars are spent the right way, we're doing it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's not perfect.

[Lungo-Koehn]: believe me, I'm starting to look at the parking revenue, I'm looking at overtime, I'm looking at sick time, I'm doing it every day, and so is in Denver right now, both of us on the school side.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So this money is going to our children, one way or another, it's our priority.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have an application in for the EAP for lead pipe repair, but we don't have, we don't know if we'll get that for another month.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's not guaranteed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, the EAP grant is, we don't know yet.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It will be another month, and if we do get the grant, it will be, well, one-sixth of the need, or just above lead issue.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, so just so fan-day.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's a substantial amount of money, but when you're talking 100 plus million dollars in replacement that we need to do, the 20 million grant that we applied for through the EPA, we'll just touch a fraction of that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What is set is a piece of land that we have to build the fire station on, which is a very difficult piece of property.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's configured in a way, especially the curb cuts and the structure of it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think what is set is a 22,000 or so square foot building.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're trying to do 20 to 25,000 construction costs, and then obviously we need

[Lungo-Koehn]: contingencies and additional funding for it to get finalized.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What is also set is that we heard from the department and we heard from the current fire chief the position of the building, and that is not how other department heads of the city felt.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was a position where I was left, and I told you I stayed out of the process, but it was a position where I said, okay, traffic and transportation wants this,

[Lungo-Koehn]: planning, things that should go with this, engineering, DPW, they were all involved.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And our fire chief said, actually for our department and our members, and the safety of exiting that parcel, this is the way the building needs to be positioned.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's when I took a stand and said, we're gonna do what the fire department wants.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm sorry to those department heads that weren't happy with that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But those are the things that are definite.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now it's a concept design, so things can definitely be

[Lungo-Koehn]: be tweaked and changed just like we've done over the last several months.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've added more storage space.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've changed bunk space.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I did put a training tower in the design because I've heard loud and clear that the

[Lungo-Koehn]: training tower was a request of our department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That was put in writing that the union would like to take that out in return for more bunk space, so we took the tower out, there's more bunk space.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is not perfect, I'm not 100% happy, our planning director is not 100% happy, fire chief's not 100% happy, the list goes on, but it's gonna be a brand new building for our department, and final design will come after this building.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do have a lot of supports for those who are struggling to pay rent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Most of that is funded through our community development block grant funding, our CPA funding.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We did a round of funding to non-profits with our federal funds, APA money.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think that is the avenue, more so than free cash.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't know if I was able to discuss it, but a number of different funding sources.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We actually, the law says what we can and cannot spend public funds on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we do have a webpage that outlines this quite a bit, but anything public safety related especially, we can use public funds on private and public ways.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we do fill potholes, for instance, or tree branches that are in the middle of any public or private way, we'll get taken care of.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since Tim came on board and Owen came on board, we do follow the laws as it relates to private and public ways, and it is very frustrating.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There is no presentations of the public or continued business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do have new business offered by member Rousseau, first reading of policy, GBED, tobacco use on school property by staff members prohibited.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Use of any tobacco products, including but not limited to cigarettes, cigars, little cigars, chewing tobacco, pipe tobacco, and snuff, and electric cigarettes, electronics cigars, electronic pipes,

[Lungo-Koehn]: or other similar projects that rely on vaporization or aerosolization within school buildings, school facilities, on school grounds, or school buses, or at school-sponsored events by any individual, including school personnel, is prohibited at all times.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Staff members who violate this policy will be referred to their immediate supervisor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by?

[Lungo-Koehn]: To add nicotine pouches and to exclude patches.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by Member Reinfeld as amended, seconded by?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Second.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham, all those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Paper passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to waive the second reading by Member Graham, seconded by Member Reinfeld.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Second reading is waived.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number 2024-37 offered by Member Graham be it resolved that the administration will provide an in-depth before and after school update that includes answers to the question posed in our 3-7-2024 meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The request should include

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number one, current wait lists for this school year by building in comparison of the prior three years at a comparable point in time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Two, enrollment information at outside programs and a summary of the offerings MPS is supporting via transportation or other activities.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three, for each wait list, the percent of students on our wait list that are enrolled elsewhere versus entirely unenrolled.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Four, description of efforts pursued

[Lungo-Koehn]: create programming at Andrews Middle School and or with Medford Recreation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Five, summary of other initiatives to expand programming citywide and or within MPS.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by my member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Russo, seconded by Member Reinfeld.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With no reports requested, and we have a few condolences.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The members of the Medford School Committee express their sincere condolences to the family of Jean Bando, mother-in-law of former Medford High School boys hockey coach Mark Bates.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The members of the Medford School Committee express their sincerest condolences to the family of Linda Small, beloved wife of former Medford Vocational Technical High School

[Lungo-Koehn]: HVAC teacher, Robert Small.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The members of the Medford School Committee expressed their sincerest condolences to the family of Pasquale Patrick Melchioda, former Director of Fine Arts for Medford Public Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the members of the Medford School Committee expressed their sincerest condolences to the family of Rory Douglas-Klein, who was a Medford Public Schools employee for 28 years, cafeteria manager at the Mississippi Elementary School, and sister of Charlene Douglas,

[Lungo-Koehn]: former teacher at the Andrews Middle School and MTA president.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we all may rise for a moment of silence.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Second reading is passed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: New Business 2024-33 offered by Member Reinfeld.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Resolution in support of November 2024 ballot questions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be resolved that the Medford School Committee support the following ballot initiatives.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Question two concerning the use of MCAS as a high school graduation requirement.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee supports the use of robust assessment and rigorous education standards in public education, but rejects the use of high stakes testing as a gate keeping tool

[Lungo-Koehn]: to define student competencies.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This ballot question does not eliminate the MCAS as a standardized assessment tool, but rather constrains its influence over classroom teaching practices and empowers our educators to consistently employ equitable practices for facilitating student learning.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Question seven, concerning the stabilization of the Medford Public Schools budget and investment in the Medford Department of Public Works.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee recognizes the need to permanently fund essential activities and jobs previously and currently supported by temporary pandemic relief funds.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The assessment of tax dollars for this purpose avoids in perpetuity this suite of devastating cuts for staff and services proposed in the last budget cycle and establishes these roles and responsibilities as essential fixtures

[Lungo-Koehn]: in the fiscal year 2025 budget and beyond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In addition, the Medford School Committee believes that timely and effective maintenance of the city's roads and sidewalks is essential for students' and staff's safety.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Increased staff capacity within the Department of Public Works improves accessibility and expands transportation options for all members of the school community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Question eight, concerning the expansion of educational offerings and services for the Medford Public Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This Medford School Committee is keenly aware of existing and emerging operational and instructional challenges in our schools, as well as increasing competition in neighboring districts to attract and retain staff.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The funds assessed by this initiative will allow the district to expand educational offerings for students, make long deferred improvements to infrastructure and increase compensation for educators and paraprofessionals.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In supporting the above measures, the Medford School Committee recognizes the multifaceted impact of these actions on Medford taxpayers and affirms Medford Public Schools' commitment to open and transparent budgeting as dictated by law and our professional and personal responsibility to the citizens of Medford, continued collaboration with our state delegation as well as public and private partners to increase revenue to the district in support of diverse and impactful learning opportunities, data-driven

[Lungo-Koehn]: pediologically sound decision-making centered on the educational needs of the students, access to high quality professional development for educator and staff professional development, and providing financial assistance for economically disadvantaged members of the school community as we work towards free enrichment and extracurricular activities while maintaining affordability of services and educational opportunities.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Reinfeld.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Member Reinfeld.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Branley?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Member Ruseau, Member Intapa.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So is there a motion to sever so we can- So I will motion to sever each question.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Second.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seconded by member Graham and Brimley.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor to sever?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed, motion to sever has been approved.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we have the first piece, which is question two, concerning the use of MCAS as a high school graduation requirement.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is there a motion on the floor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by member Intapa, seconded by member Reinfeld.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First section passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But is there a motion on the floor for approval?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.
