[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, well, thank you for being here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, thanks for showing your support.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 2024-34 offered by Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First reading of policy A, D, C, tobacco products on school premises prohibited.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Tobacco use on school property by staff members prohibited.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Use of any tobacco products, including but not limited to cigarettes, cigars, little cigars, chewing tobacco, pipe tobacco, and snuff and electric cigarettes, electronic cigarettes,

[Lungo-Koehn]: electronic pipes, I didn't realize there's so many things, or other similar products that rely on vaporization or aerosolization within the school buildings, school facilities, on school grounds or school buses or at school sponsored events by any individual, including school personnel is prohibited at all times.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Staff members who violate this policy will be referred to their immediate supervisor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is there a motion on the floor for approval?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, members.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Edward-Vincent just mentioned that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What about people that are prescribed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's gum or patches.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Patches, so.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So are we excluding that from the policy if people are prescribed and they're trying to quit?

[Lungo-Koehn]: The pouches are included in the policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That is a recreational activity.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But we're excluding anything that is prescribed by a doctor for those trying to quit, like patches and gum.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, motion on the floor for approval as amended by Member Ruseau, seconded by Member Branley.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes as amended.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 2024-35 offered by myself.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Consolidation language for facilities maintenance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The city facilities director would support school facility needs by being a resource to the assistant superintendent for enrichment and innovation and the director of building and grounds.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The support that the city facilities director would provide to the school department would include creation of policies and procedures to ensure preventative maintenance tasks are completed promptly, establishing regular maintenance contracts that comply with procurement law for school facilities beginning January 1 or sooner, depending on funding and need,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Review the RFP for the new cleaning contracts at the McGlynn and Andrews and serve on the review and selection committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Create a list of annual maintenance tasks to feed the deployment of operations hero.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Assess skill gaps and professional development needs and provide training as identified.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Set up a hiring committee for the planned MSBA operations facilities professionals.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Other related items as identified by the team.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The assistant superintendent for Richmond Innovation will continue to supervise the director of building grounds and the building grounds

[Lungo-Koehn]: Director will continue to oversee all school building staff with the support of the Assistant Superintendent for Richmond Innovation and Operations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: From the chair, this is the vote that was taken in June for consolidation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And at that time, the school committee wanted to make sure before we made any changes or consolidation, we came to you with language.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And this is something...

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham helped me with as well, but drafted this up with her edits to try to move this forward, especially where if we do have an override that passes, some of that funding will be going to much-needed preventative maintenance, and it's going to take months to obtain those contracts and do it the right way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the MSBA project is also extremely important.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We get the right professionals on staff.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: if i could make a friendly amendment to the title of the assistant superintendent in the opening paragraph to include um and operations and operations thank you and then i'd motion to approve that and operations so motion for approval as amended by member rousseau seconded by second member graham all those in favor aye aye all those opposed motion passes thank you everybody thank you

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do not have any requested reports.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have two condolences.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Francis Alf, husband of the former administrative assistant to assistant superintendent Stephen Maskell, Rosemary Alf, and uncle to the former school public information officer, Lisa Evangelista.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, the members of the Medford School Committee express their sincerest condolences to the family of Kevin Brine, brother of John Brine, who is a member of the Medford High School Buildings and Grounds Department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: if we all may rise for a moment of silence, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our next regular meeting will be October 7th, 2024, at the end here in the Alderman Memorial Chambers Medford City Hall, in addition to Zoom, and we will have a committee executive session meeting beforehand to finish our work from this evening.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is there a motion to adjourn?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to adjourn by Member Brandt.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Six in the affirmative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One absent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Meeting is adjourned.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Have a wonderful Fourth of July everyone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Good evening.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Bears and Councilors for allowing me some time to speak to you about the fiscal year 25 budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Before I begin, I must take this opportunity to thank everyone who contributed to the completing this budget and delivering it to your honorable body by the newly established deadline per the budget ordinance, compiling this comprehensive breakdown of the city's financial outlook took countless hours of preparation, debate, and insight from our department heads and our budget team.

[Lungo-Koehn]: led by our Finance Director, Bob Dickinson, Assistant Finance Director and Budget Director, Courtney Caraviello, and my team in the Mayor's Office, led by Chief of Staff Nina Nazarian.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I also need to credit both Courtney and our Communications Team, Director Steve Smerdy,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and Emma Tombley, our communications specialist for putting in so many hours of work on the nitty gritty aspects of the budget book that tend to get overlooked.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This work is invaluable and will hopefully lead us to a second Distinguished Budget Award from the Government Finance Officers Association.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Last year, I stood before you and laid out the challenges that lay ahead for fiscal year 25.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our looming fiscal cliff due to the expiration of ARPA and ESSER funding, the continued rise in consumer prices, as well as the decades of neglect of critical infrastructure upkeep as it relates to our roads, sidewalks, water and sewer infrastructure system that are catching up to us now, including our buildings.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Most of these are not new or surprising obstacles.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They have always been at the forefront of financial planning, guiding our strategy and shaping the decisions we make.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now, as we approach the end date, it's important to understand that measures we must take to ensure that our city and school services, programs and projects are properly funded and staffed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As I wrote in my budget message last week, the school's budget was by far the toughest one to develop.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Due to the timeline of the budget ordinance, we needed to supply the school department with an estimated operating budget figure in March.

[Lungo-Koehn]: At that time, we did not have concrete figures for the city's previous year's actuals or next year's projections, thus making the school's number more of a guide than a strict dollar amount.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But it's no secret that the schools used the remaining ESSER funds last year

[Lungo-Koehn]: and are operating at a deficit, committing one-time funding sources to plug this gap continually is not a long-term solution.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school budget was facing a cliff, and cuts had to be made to right-size our spending and balance the fiscal year 25 budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our city team then thoroughly reviewed each line item on the city side, dove deeply into expenditures, compared numbers with previous year's actuals, and worked to bring those figures down to a more reasonable and sustainable level in order to provide as much funding to the schools as possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, we reviewed our new growth numbers, workers' compensation numbers, assessed IT vendor contracts, and really dove headfirst into the fine details of the city budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The hard work over the last two months adjusting the city budget revenue projections and other city line items allowed us to increase the school budget from our fiscal year 24 numbers of 71,200,000 to 76 million for fiscal year 25.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's nearly a 7% increase of general fund allocated monies.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm immensely proud that we're able to come to this number and supply the schools with a significant increase from last year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: but it's still not enough to avoid cuts and creates additional obstacles to learning.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it's important to understand just how we've gotten to this point at both the school district and city hall, with each budget season being such a challenging and in many ways, a discouraging process for all involved.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Each year, the budget I propose and the budget that this honorable body votes on is balanced.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And while that allows us to pay for all our obligations, it creates a situation where most of our costs, which generally significantly increase year over year, exceed the amount we're able to raise in taxes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Per Massachusetts general law, Medford and all other municipalities in the Commonwealth cannot increase our tax levy, which is one of the major components of the city's revenue sources.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We raise from real and property taxes by more than 2.5%.

[Lungo-Koehn]: meeting the operating budget can't keep up the cost of living.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This in some cases creates the need for scaled back programming, staff reductions and other resource losses to properly balance the budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know there has been some discussion on rating our reserve funds to plug our structural deficit gap.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That is not sound financial practice.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dipping into our savings to fund something for one year is just simply a bad idea.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's why our team worked so hard to reduce our reliance on one-time funding to offset revenue loss in my previous four budgets.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The funding we received from the federal government with the passage of the American Rescue Plan Act, also known as ARPA, allowed us to inject capital to plug various gaps during the early years of the pandemic when revenues were down.

[Lungo-Koehn]: By making strategic one-time investments, we were able to save on annual operating budget space, which created more flexibility when crafting the budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The pandemic also caused us to reevaluate much of our thinking on the use of one-time funding.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It also changed the way the public interacts with government, so much so that we now must allocate funding to new items that have become essential as post-pandemic life continues.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For example, prior to 2020, City Hall did not regularly host meetings.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now that is common and expected practice, which requires more resources, technology, infrastructure, and staff training, which all carry an expense.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That brings us to an override measure, which I'm proposing to appear on the ballot in November.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This has been a topic of debate in the council chambers, my email box, in homes, coffee shops, ball fields, and around our squares for several years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think two things are simultaneously true as it relates to an override.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It would undoubtedly help us maintain and hopefully enhance our services, and it would create hardships for many people in our city struggling to stay afloat financially.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our financial task force established earlier this year has been meeting regularly to work through, negotiate, and discuss the best path forward for the city, schools, and community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Considering the financial pressures many of our residents are facing, as well as the need to increase our revenues to account for costs outpacing our 2.5% levy threshold, we have concluded that in November, the voters should decide on if they want to adequately fund our programs, positions, and projects.

[Lungo-Koehn]: one on a debt exclusion for a new fire headquarters, and two Proposition 2 12 overrides.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The first override question would ask voters to approve raising $3.5 million to stabilize Medford Public Schools funding, including but not limited to funding costs such as teachers, literacy coaches, behavioral specialists, administrative assistants, nurses, and for regular facilities maintenance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And for our Department of Public Works, 500,000 for additional staff for road and sidewalk infrastructure repairs.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The second override question would ask voters to approve raising 4 million to invest in Medford Public Schools to create a high school schedule that increases access to arts and vocational programming, expands classroom instructional opportunities, and for classroom teacher and paraprofessional compensation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The debt exclusion question would ask voters to approve funding of a bond of up to 30 million to be issued for the design and construction of a new Medford Fire Department headquarters at 120 Main Street.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The expected cost of these three combined questions would increase property taxes for the average single family home, which is assessed at about $770,000 by approximately $446 per year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That would be about $37 per month.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But since our schools need to be right-sized now, I've asked your body to approve an amendment to the budget to increase the school's budget allocation from 76 million to 77.75 million through the use of 1.75 million in one-time funding advance, 500,000 of which will fund the purchase of Chromebooks and laptops and begins an annual refresh cycle to maintain our district-wide technology.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now this is one-time funding, so if the first override question does not pass, then we will be right back here in the same position next year with cuts on the table.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But passing these overrides is by no means an easy decision, and I recognize that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In fact, coming to these numbers was a painstaking process, and I'm still wary of the financial burden increased taxes may have in our community, especially in those struggling to get by, and that weighs heavily on me.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Ultimately, I believe the question of pass would fulfill our greatest needs, mainly in our schools and for our children, but also help make progress on the number one complaint we get, which is the conditions of our roads and sidewalks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know this is the right decision because the alternative will mean more cuts and more challenges for our residents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And in my opinion, we cannot afford to continue on that path.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our residents deserve the right to take a vote on this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is a big decision that requires considerable thought.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I truly believe, however, that approving these ballot questions is the right thing, and I hope the majority of the community agrees.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There are, of course, other aspects to this budget than just the Proposition 2 12 override questions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: many of which are quite encouraging.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are making significant investment in several core city systems, maintaining as much service as possible and providing a sustainable roadmap for future big ticket expenditures, like a new fire headquarters and a new Medford High School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're making another significant investment in our library, increasing its budget by nearly 12%.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This coupled with last year's increase of about 18% has resulted in a more than doubling effect on the city's library budget in the last decade.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This has allowed everyone in our community to get better access to the resources and programs that our fabulous library offers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're increasing the budget for our department of public works to keep up with increased costs in services, as well as give us some flexibility as we continue to address the backlog of stumps, tree pruning, repairs,

[Lungo-Koehn]: et cetera, to update our aging water infrastructure and improve accessibility and pedestrian mobility in our squares and green spaces and throughout our entire community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The city continues to work towards goals laid out in our Climate Action and Adaptation Plan, which was finalized in fiscal year 23.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My administration is committed to removing barriers that would preclude residents from sustainable practices, including financial barriers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The city has partnered with Garbage to Garden to launch a free municipal curbside composting program for eligible residents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This program launches in fiscal year 25, which is July 1st, 2024, and aims to be widely accessible and convenient, making it easy for residents to participate in creating a greener, more sustainable future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The city has also received 300,000 in grant funding to expand public outreach and strengthen support specifically for underrepresented and underserved communities interested in decarbonizing their homes and vehicles through energy efficiency, solar, and electricification of heating, water heating appliances, and electric vehicles.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This program, Electrify Medford, will seek to educate residents on available resources and help them make these changes in their own homes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As part of our commitment to residents, we are always looking for ways to expand diversity, equity, and inclusion throughout the city and create an environment of belonging for our entire community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our DEI director has been working with our human resource director to update best practices for recruiting, interviewing, and hiring.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Due to this work, the city has been able to recruit, hire, and retain diverse candidates for a variety of city positions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This team also hosts trainings and other professional development opportunities to ensure employees have all the tools they need to uphold our values and mission, something that will be enhanced and continued through fiscal year 25.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have secured $850,000 to help transform the Dorothy T. Hegner Center into a municipal vulnerability preparedness site.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Hegner Center will be renovated into a community space that will be used to coordinate emergency responses and will serve as a resiliency hub for residents during climate emergencies.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The site will also host an afterschool program through the city's rec department and other community oriented events when not being used for emergencies.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Last year, our engineering team got to work on repairing approximately 90 roads that have been identified as prime candidates for crack sailing in the pavement report from 2021 and the updated report from 2024.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The city will deploy over 180,000 in ARPA funding to crack sail the additional streets on the list for the next several years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Crack sailing is a preventative measure that prolongs the life of roads and avoids having to make major structural repairs in the near future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The engineering division has also identified six roads that are among the most in need and are working through planning process with our administration with the hope of repaving the season.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our infrastructure needs reach beyond our streets, thoroughways and pedestrian paths.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A major component of the work being done by our DPW team is the ongoing water meter system replacement project.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Initiated in fiscal year 24, the team in the water and sewer division is continuing to install new state-of-the-art systems in homes across the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These meters are a crucial step in addressing the aging water infrastructure, delivering accurate readings for customers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's also evident that our water and sewer infrastructure is aging.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The system dates back

[Lungo-Koehn]: decades and after years of neglect to properly repair or place pipes, we are now in the process of devising a comprehensive strategy that will begin to assess the future needs of our system.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This will take years and will be very expensive, but it must be done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In addition to improving our public infrastructure, we're also been working to enhance and upgrade many of our public spaces for the community to utilize and enjoy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Current projects that are nearing completion include Gillis Park and Carr Park.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Gillis is a 1.4 million renovation project that will upgrade accessibility features, improve the baseball field and add new park amenities.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Carr Park phase two is additionally expected to kick off soon.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The City of Medford Public Schools have also begun construction on a new universally accessible schoolyard at the McGlynn School, which is expected to be completed by the next school year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The playground will go beyond federal Americans with Disabilities Accessibility Standards upon completion, making this space one for all to enjoy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As I toured the project a couple of weeks ago, I was in awe of how wonderful the space will be for everyone in our city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's no secret that one of the key measures of our financial health is the revenue we generate from commercial development.

[Lungo-Koehn]: While it's important that we expand our tax base in this sector, we must also consider the enormous barriers, both structurally and financially, for families, workers, and individuals attempting to find meaningful and sustainable housing in our city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are bringing over 500 new residential units to the community through eight new developments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To further support the housing crisis that is affecting nearly every municipality, we have allocated nearly 400,000 in funds from ARPA to offset permitting costs of renovations and upgrades to current and new affordable housing units at the housing authority as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Through successful negotiations, we've gained leverage with our 40B developers to bring more community benefits to the planning process, like better pedestrian accessibility, reduction of potential traffic congestion, more open space, more access to public transportation, and more affordable housing units were the priority for Medford residents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A lot of this hard work on the housing development side is thanks to the work of this Medford City Council and your push for zoning rethought codification, as well as establishing affordable housing trust, which will use various funding streams to help facilitate more affordable units coming to market.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Your honorable body in collaboration with our planning development and sustainability office are now working on the next phase of the zoning process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Before I conclude, I want to highlight a few other projects and programs that our staff has worked so hard to bring to life.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We secured a Massachusetts School Building Association loan to build a new state-of-the-art high school for our students and began the planning process, which will continue in fiscal year 25.

[Lungo-Koehn]: S&P Global affirmed the city's double A plus credit rating, the second highest possible rating for a municipality.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We continue to onboard several senior tax workers to assist with tasks across our departments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The city reached its goal of planting 200 trees in 2023, which built upon the 2022 goal of 180 trees.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We continue to install art murals.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our most recent was by artist Jamie Chan at Wright's Pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We unveiled the new art exhibit space and new home of arts collaborative Medford on Mystic Ave.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We installed five new electric vehicle charging stations and four new bike stations at high priority locations around the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the fall, we broke ground on Clippership Connector, a path located along the Mystic River that will connect more than 10 miles of continuous greenway and aims to provide a safer route between Medford Square, the Andrews, McGlynn, and Riverbend Park.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our tree warden secured $100,000 grant to help strengthen the resiliency of our urban forest network.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are continuing to partner and support amazing

[Lungo-Koehn]: community events like the Farmer's Market, Run Medford, Oktoberfest, Circle the Square, PorchFest, and so much more.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We continue to expand city communications offerings across our four environmental justice languages, Spanish, Haitian Creole, Brazilian Portuguese, and Arabic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In addition to the new city website having the capability to translate, the communications department is working with the Office of Prevention and Outreach to build a user base in the reverse 911 system to translate messages.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The city's digital permitting system is additionally now capable of translations into two languages.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We replaced parking meters throughout the city with new parking kiosks, offering more ways to pay and increase accessibility.

[Lungo-Koehn]: By establishing a new zoning district in partnership with the city council, we continue to prioritize mixed use development.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As I'm sure you know, this is just a brief overview of all the work that everyone has done over the last year and the investments we've made that will help build on the vision we share for our city's future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have worked in tandem on a variety of critical issues, be it zoning reform, the housing production plan, or the capital improvement plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I wanna thank the city council for being a thoughtful partner in government.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You all have worked extremely hard over the last year to move forward many key priorities and improve efficiency on a number of fronts.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Before you debate the budget, please know I'm here to answer any questions you may have.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Nice to see you too.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Deep breaths.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Well first, I wish I was at the Red Sox game.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Through the chair.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yep.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If the override, if the first override question, I mentioned it in my presentation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If the first override question fails, we will be right back in the same position in

[Lungo-Koehn]: March, April, May, June next year facing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The last one was,

[Lungo-Koehn]: late fall, it's on our city website and it outlines all the work that we've done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I just wanna point that out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also have the Great American Beer Hall, commercial, retail, mixed-use developments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's another whole list that has been moved forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think it's a shame to say that we've done nothing in the last few years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Second, I had our

[Lungo-Koehn]: planning department outline, because it's said quite often that we've lost opportunities on these 40 Bs.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First, there's one that keeps submitting and withdrawing, so that is what it is.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We did do our GLAM analysis and we did in-state Safe Harbor

[Lungo-Koehn]: there was two developments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One was Mystic Valley Parkway.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's the one that's moving forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then there's a Fellsway that's in the middle of, between the Fellsway commercial and then a fully residential neighborhood.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So by instituting Safe Harbor, we've been able to get these developers to come to the table and negotiate with us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we didn't install our safe harbor status, we would have had no seat at the table.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We would have been able to get no community benefits.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if you wouldn't indulge me, I'll just maybe I have multiple pages on the first two and I can just.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll actually read the first one that's moving forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's 4,000 Mystic Valley Parkway.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've reduced density from the original proposal.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We split it into two buildings for more manageable scale.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We asked them to put in a shared use path around the entire property, not accessible vehicles on two sides, improve amenity space for residents with intentional play areas, significantly improved architectural design,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Up to 70% of the affordable units will have Medford priority.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Significantly increased bike storage for residents including provisions for electric bike charging in parking areas.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Pocket Park on the corner of Mystic Valley Parkway and Commercial Street with public amenities including a commitment for public art to be improved by the Medford Arts Council, Medford Historic Society and the Medford Department of

[Lungo-Koehn]: DEI.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We building an all electric, the building will be all electric with the exception of emergency generator.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've improved the layout for loading and passenger drop-off zones on site on the commercial outside to improve area vehicle flow, significant pedestrian improvements to the intersection of Commercial Ave and Mystic Valley Parkway, including ADA ramps, pedestrian countdown indicators, pedestrian push buttons, improved crosswalk pave markings,

[Lungo-Koehn]: new streetlights on commercial street, improved curb cuts, sidewalks, and crosswalks on commercial street, a new blue bike station on site or in the vicinity, over 50,000 alone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Applicant will comply with the solar ordinance, 264,000 in linkage paid to our fire, police, and parks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's just one 40B project, and we would have gotten none of this if we didn't instate our, it didn't calculate our glam analysis and didn't instate

[Lungo-Koehn]: safe harbors.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'm so proud of the work that our planning development sustainability office has done on not only this, but also on the Fellsway and whatever the last developer chooses to do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then I just want to speak to the task force.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I wanna say that this is probably, in my 23 years, it's been the most collaborative that school committee, city council, and the mayor's office has been.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think I said that to you after the election in November, that I just feel like these three bodies are gonna be able to work better and more collaboratively than they ever have, because you all do the work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whether people like it or not, whether they think you're moving too fast, you're doing the work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'm proud of that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee is doing the work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And this has been transparent since day one.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was 2022 when Councilor Bears and Councilor Collins discussed it at the council meeting and wrote a public memo that you thought an override should be on the ballot.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I wrote a public memo back that I agreed, 12 million, 3 million, but that's that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And since then, we, yes, we talk on the phone, we talk behind closed doors, but it's all transparent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When we went through the budget last year, we did, we sat down, we discussed it, just, Councilor Tseng, you were also in the room, we discussed it, we said, what's the path forward, how are we gonna manage, how are we gonna build a better budget and a better budget process?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we did a press release, that was,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Correct me if I'm wrong on specific dates, but in June of 2023, we put out a press release on exactly what we agreed on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Nothing more, nothing less.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Transparency, that's transparency.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We started a meeting in the fall.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I believe our first meeting might've been the end of September, beginning of October.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Again, put out another press release.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We then worked through the struggles that we are facing financially over the last several months.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, the five of us were in that room for the task force meeting, but member Graham and myself were meeting with the CFO of the schools and our superintendent, quite regularly, as well as the school committee meeting on the floor to talk about the budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: myself and my chief of staff, as well as the councilors, I'm sure, we're talking to our CFO, who I also think has an amazing mind, regularly, my chief of staff every day, myself at least weekly, or sometimes multiple times a week.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So yes, we had two CFOs working on this process, not in the room every step of the way when we met as a group of five, but we talked through what we thought was the best path forward and how we could

[Lungo-Koehn]: get this budget approved and still provide for our city and mainly our students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'm proud of the work we've done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Gone are the days where we're negotiating jobs for friends.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That doesn't happen anymore.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're negotiating.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We truly care about this city and we care about the future of the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's why you have the three ballot questions before you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: People can vote yes, people can vote no.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They're split into three.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We could have done two, but I think three was the best way to do it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: People have a choice, and they have a choice in November.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is months and months away.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's gonna be campaigns on both sides.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's gonna be things we're restricted from doing after potentially the vote tonight if it passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: but it's up to the people now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, I mean, there's more I could go into.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I am listening to residents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This money will not go into a black hole.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's gonna go towards literacy coaches.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's gonna go towards a nurse so that he or she is not let go.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's gonna go to teachers because we wanna keep the levels as much as we can in our school system.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's gonna be the best way forward for our students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just wanted to address the councilor, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll only comment on a few things.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just take sincere offense to say that, for one, to say that things have been mismanaged financially for five years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've had two CFOs in the last five years and they've both done a great job.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I just want to comment on that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Second, and I know it's been said by my chief of staff a number of times, I have to address the legal costs of the city of Medford, because there is a number of us that sat and we reviewed budgets in 16 different communities, and we were the first or second lowest in legal, paying legal costs, and that includes- If I may.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Excuse me, I have the floor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That that includes outside legal counsel as well as Coleman and Page who we use as the 40 municipal attorneys that specialize in different things.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In comparison, I'll give you one city, Malden, very similar to us, spends about a million point two in legal costs.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford spends a bit over 400,000.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it was 450,000.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I just want to put that into perspective.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then the councilor also mentions cleaning things up.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Maybe he's offended by what I've done the last four years, but I've brought accountability to this community and I am so proud of it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, absolutely.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First, let me congratulate the class of 2024 on this momentous milestone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm so proud to be here to celebrate you and all the hard work you've put into the last four years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Graduating from high school is a huge accomplishment, and you all should be very proud of yourselves.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know there were obstacles, challenges, as well as learning transitions that you've had to overcome during these last four years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You entered high school during a pandemic, for goodness sake.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and had to navigate a shift in the way the world was operating, in addition to getting acclimated to a new school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Your resiliency and strength are inspiring, and those are gained skills that you will all apply as you move forward beyond Medford High School and into the next chapter of your life.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be ready for anything, continue to be curious, and remember that positive thinking is the first step towards future success.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There is nothing you can't do, and I know this because I've watched you all as you graciously have risen to meet your challenges.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have all the faith in the world that you will continue to do amazing things and leave your positive mark on the world.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I know your teachers, families, and friends are excited to see what you do next, as am I.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If I give you any advice, it's to never be afraid to try.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Try it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Try something.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Try anything that scares you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The best things out there are the things that are the hardest to try.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be kind, compassionate, and accepting to everyone in everything you do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Just to piggyback on that from the chair, there's a group of us that have been meeting since the early fall, maybe September.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham, myself, and two members of the city council, chair and vice chair.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And in, I believe it was late March, we did put out a press release where we just let the voters know, let the residents know that we are exploring two debt exclusions, one for the fire headquarters and one, of course,

[Lungo-Koehn]: flagship new high school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In that, we also mentioned that this fall, there'll be two elections, one in September, one in November, and we do plan on putting potentially two override questions before the voters, one to help fund our schools and one for a potential sidewalk street maintenance crew that could help and provide support to our DPW and focus mainly on

[Lungo-Koehn]: the lack of maintenance that we've been able to put in based on Chapter 90 funding to our streets.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that it has been discussed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's not been discussed as a full committee, obviously, because we have open meeting law rules that we have to follow, but it is something that we are putting forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't know if that will be September or November.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our next task force meeting is Friday, I believe, but obviously that is

[Lungo-Koehn]: The position we are in, we used one-time funding for the budget for the last four years because of the pandemic, because of the lost revenues.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have been able to dwindle that down, of course, because those large buckets, we're in this position because all expenses are up, as well as all of our salaries and expenses cannot be met by the 2.5% that we're able to tax the voters.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's just too much.

[Lungo-Koehn]: compiling that with these one-time funds that we've used, whether it be on the school side, I think about 1.5 million to 2 million, and then on the city side, luckily, we've been able to find a few grants.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Barr Foundation's one that's gonna be able to absorb some of the positions we have, but we're also doing some hard work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think tonight is where I really realized where the gap was, because obviously you haven't called each of us

[Lungo-Koehn]: explained fully other than when we've been in executive session or meetings or school committee meetings.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So my next several days will be trying to talk to my finance director and working through the city side budget to make the necessary cuts to be able to provide more to the schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: At first I thought that was about a half million and come this weekend and tonight I'm realizing it's much more and that's including with some significant cuts that we all feel

[Lungo-Koehn]: pretty upset about.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I mean, I don't think there's a person behind this rail that either doesn't have a headache or a stomachache because this is real lives.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is our students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is, this is real and it's, it's not a fun position to be in whatsoever.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And as I talked to mayors across the state and I've talked to many, it seems like everybody is in this position because of these large buckets of one-time funding and people are doing overrides or having major cuts.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think we're trying to,

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're trying to figure it out before we put a question for the residents, and I do think that will pass.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think that's a balancing act, because we need to make sure we get a debt exclusion for potentially several hundred million dollars approved for a new high school, but it's the hard work that we have to do, and it's a tough week that I have ahead on the city side to try to figure this out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that's where I am.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Obviously, the first time this presentation was before us, so there's a lot of things that I didn't even know until tonight, and I appreciate the presentation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Policy BEDB agenda creation and format for regular meetings of the school committee will be updated by inserting approvals of capital purchases immediately after existing policy language, approval of bills, and the consent agenda section of the policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to approve.

[Lungo-Koehn]: if you could explain, yeah.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, as long as we make sure that the administration talks to the city staff, especially where ARPA is, it is accounted for, especially with the air conditioning, reconditioning study, turnout gear, it's accounted for.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by Member Graham, seconded by Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to suspend the second reading by Member Ruseau, seconded by?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Second.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham, all those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Bruce So, seconded by Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Offered by Member Ruseau, Member Reinfeld, and Member Olapade.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Resolution on the end of fossil fuel building equipment purchases, whereas the buildings of the Medford Public Schools are exclusively the responsibility of the Medford School Committee pursuant to Mass General Law, Chapter 71, Section 68, whereas the Inflation Reduction Act and the bipartisan infrastructure law

[Lungo-Koehn]: both provided significant opportunities for schools to end our dependence on fossil fuel infrastructure, whereas the climate crisis is an existential threat to the survival of our species and countless other species we share our planet with, whereas the climate crisis is primarily caused by human activity through the release of greenhouse gases, whereas today's leaders must take action now to ensure a sustainable future for generations to come.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now, therefore, be it resolved that the Medford School Committee

[Lungo-Koehn]: One, bans the purchase of new or replacement fossil fuels powered equipment used to operate our school facilities, such as HVAC equipment and kitchen equipment, may authorize the purchase of banned equipment in emergency situations at a regular or special meeting of the committee, and must authorize equipment purchases covered by this resolution, regardless of the revenue source, such as municipal funding or grants from governmental or non-governmental organizations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know we have our team, our city team, and they brought some guests with us to discuss the HVAC system.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think I was talking to Brenda this weekend about the process to fixing our HVAC at the two middle schools, somewhat related here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I don't know if you want to hear from them or a member that has this resolution.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Reinfeld, do you want to say anything?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Director Hunt.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is there a motion to table?

[Lungo-Koehn]: If I may, just from the chair, and then I'm gonna acknowledge

[Lungo-Koehn]: Director Hunt and her team have taken on quite a bit to help, plus Paul Riggi, who's our facilities and maintenance director over in the city side and through requests coming from me, which obviously are coming through the school committee, they've spent a lot of time working on the light posts on Freedom Way, keys, new cameras, and now HVAC, so I understand you want to move this forward tonight, but

[Lungo-Koehn]: Director Hunt respectfully asked that we table this basically until they at least give their presentation and we can always go back to it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think out of respect for city staff working tirelessly for school needs because they want to help, I would ask that the committee respect that request.

[Lungo-Koehn]: member Rousseau and then.

[Lungo-Koehn]: approved funding.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have not signed a contract.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why they're presenting tonight on work that I asked them to do, but it was the committee that has discussed it over and over again.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's the teachers union who brought a grievance because our air conditioning doesn't work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have the seventh regular meeting of the Medford School Committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Taking it back, John, I didn't know.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Dapper, I'm like, what is that background?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Where are you?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Looks like a movie set.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seventh regular meeting of the Medford School Committee, April 8th, 2024, executive session at 6 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and our regular meeting at or about 7 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting is being held remotely via Zoom and it's remote only and can be viewed live on the Medford Public Schools YouTube channel through Medford Community Media or your local cable channel, Comcast channel 98 or 22 and Verizon channel 43, 45 or 47.

[Lungo-Koehn]: participants can log in or call in by using the following information.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Next up, we have new business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have offered by member and Tapa recognition of Autism Acceptance Month, whereas Autism Acceptance Month is recognized in the month of April.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas Autism Acceptance Day is recognized on the 2nd of April, now therefore be it resolved that the Medford Public Schools and Medford School Committee recognize Autism Acceptance Month within the Medford Public School System, recognize for future usage Autism Acceptance Day as April 2nd on all official Medford Public School calendars distributed

[Lungo-Koehn]: to the public and report to the Medford School Committee on steps being taken with the Medford Public Schools to support students impacted by autism spectrum disorder, ASD, and how we go about identifying students who may need these services that have yet to receive them.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Explanation, those within the advocates of the autism spectrum,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Community are looking to distance themselves from groups that treat autism as a disease and something that needs to be healed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The focus is not on awareness of autism spectrum disorder, ASD, but more of a focus on acceptance of the members of our community that fall under the autism spectrum and making sure there are equitable systemic pathways for their success, being conscious of decisions that may impact members of the ASD community, both systematically and socially.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is the first step in this process to better understand

[Lungo-Koehn]: and see how we as a city can better serve our community members impacted by ASD.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll turn it over to you Member Intoppa for a motion or anything else you'd like to add.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Member Intoppa.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'm going to assume you're moving approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is there a second?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I can second.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I second by member Branley.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Edward-Vincent?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Understood, Dr. Vincent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, so you're looking for information rather than us providing services to people that need them, even if they haven't been identified.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Right, I'm looking, yeah.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So you're looking to change that report to the school committee on steps being taken to provide supports for those impacted by autism spectrum disorder?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Correct, yeah.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Good, as an amendment?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, so then just strike the second half of that, number three.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the MCAS, MASC bylaws article nine, section one requires Medford School Committee to vote for the readoption of expiring resolutions for consideration at the annual conference.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 2024-12.

[Lungo-Koehn]: submitted by member Rousseau, policy BBBA slash BBBB, school committee member qualifications, oath of office will be updated with the following language.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To serve in the school committee, an individual must be registered voter in the city or town from which they elected or appointed and must take an oath of office as required by law.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Each new member will present to the committee secretary official certification of having sworn the oath before the city clerk

[Lungo-Koehn]: before entering on their official duties as a member of the committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: From the superintendent, newly qualified committee members by law will receive and sign a receipt of a copy of Massachusetts Open Meeting Law governing the conduct of committee meetings in general and in executive sessions in particular.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Newly qualified committee members shall, by law, receive and sign a receipt for, within 30 days of taking office, a copy of the Massachusetts Ethics Commission Summary of the Conflict of Interest Laws.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As Massachusetts employees, all school committee members shall receive a copy of said summary annually.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All school committee members shall, within 30 days of taking office, and every two years thereafter, complete the Massachusetts Ethics Commission's online training program.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Upon completing the online training program, members shall provide notice of such completion to be retained for six years by the superintendent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 2024-14 submitted by Member Ruseau, Member Graham, and Member Olapade.

[Lungo-Koehn]: resolution in support of a stabilization fund for the city of Medford, whereas the use of free cash only possible for a few months each year from one fee free cash is certified by the state through June 30 when the fiscal year ends, whereas the public schools may experience unexpected expenses, not planned for in the budget cycle such as a major

[Lungo-Koehn]: equipment failure, floods, fires, roofs, et cetera, whereas Medford Public Schools cannot borrow money to cover such expenses, whereas at present, the only mechanism for Medford Public Schools to receive additional funding to cover unexpected expenses is by a supplemental appropriation submitted by the mayor to the city council for approval, whereas the inability to use free cash for much of the year places the Medford Public Schools and the city of Medford in a precarious position

[Lungo-Koehn]: should a supplemental appropriation be required to ensure educational continuity for our students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas a stabilization fund provides a mechanism for the allocation and spending of money throughout the year, and whereas the use of a stabilization fund for resources requires a mayoral request to the city council for approval, now therefore be it resolved that the Medford School Committee thanks the Medford City Council for approving the creation of a stabilization fund.

[Lungo-Koehn]: urges the Medford City Council, when a request to add funds to the stabilization fund is received, to approve the request before the expiration of free cash, and requests the superintendent of schools sends this resolution in a record of the vote of the school committee to the Medford City Council.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you all for putting the resolution on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If I may, from the chair, I proposed a $5 million stabilization account the spring of 2023.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That did fail at the time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I wanna thank the current city council for approving, opening up the account so that we can hopefully next month add at least 5 million into that account.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Because as you wrote in the resolution, come July 1 until free cash is certified again, which has been mid to late March of the last year, and it will be this year, there is no money available except what's in our budgets to pay for emergencies.

[Lungo-Koehn]: or any any type of outside funding outside of the budget that we happen to need that free cash gets closed down and you cannot spend it so we have a situation where we need money for, like you mentioned a roof, or an emergency or even, we need a million dollars to get an OPM to do a new high school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is the account we would have to take it from because there will be no other account so that this is extremely important.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've been able to get by because we have that nine more months of ARPA.

[Lungo-Koehn]: this is important passing because once December 30th comes until free cash certifies in 2025, there will be no funding.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then the year after that, July 1, 2025 until March 2026, there will be no outside funding.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it's kind of unheard of that city, our size does not have one.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Some cities and towns have multiple.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is long overdue.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's going to be a huge accomplishment for the school committee, city council, and our office to get this set up and

[Lungo-Koehn]: we're going to be able to get us prepared for emergencies to come.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So thank you for the support, and I see this move approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's a stabilization account, but it would need to come from the mayor's office.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that would be a recommendation by the school committee if it was school spending.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then it would have to be every dollar that's spent out of the stabilization account.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm a 99.9% sure would have to be approved by the city council.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think there was a maybe a lot of emotions in that room.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think once you're clear on what a stabilization account which is a spending, putting, taking money from free cash and putting it into an account.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Some cities and towns have multiple stabilization accounts.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, capital improvement, stabilization account, stabilization account for emergencies.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is just our first of at least have something

[Lungo-Koehn]: on the books to be able to spend in case we do have an emergency or some sort of spending we need without that free cash being available.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And this is citywide, not designated for schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is not designated for schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is just a city stabilization account, but of course could be spent on a roof that collapses, you know, that needs major repair that we don't have 300-400,000 to fix.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Second?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion approval by Member Ruseau, I believe it was.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 2024-15, submitted by Member Ruseau, Member Graham, and Member Olaparte.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the resolution on the disciplinary practice of suspension was unanimously adopted by the Medford School Committee on October 14th, 2020,

[Lungo-Koehn]: whereas the language of the resolution on the disciplinary practice of suspension provides that the following actions will be taken by the Medford public schools, ends the use of out of school suspensions effective the first day of the school year 2021 except as provided by law, provides for the continuation of a learning environment for every in-school suspension, ensures that in-school suspensions will not occur in isolation without instruction or rehabilitative counseling,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Selects alternative tools for use in discipline, such as restorative justice wherever possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We'll complete a comprehensive program review of disciplinary practices across the district, including but not limited to system-wide disciplinary measures, reporting to the school committee, social and emotional supports for victims, as well as establishing a staff feedback process to be presented to the school committee in May 2021.

[Lungo-Koehn]: seeks to incorporate any funding requirements to ensure the implementation of the selected alternatives with fidelity in the next budget cycle and establishes an annual reporting process that includes, but is not limited to system-wide disciplinary measures, reporting to the school committee, as well as establishing staff feedback process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas it appears that there are occurrences of noncompliance with the policy happening in the district and the occurrences have been observed since the effective date of the policy,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and whereas the annual reporting requirements of the resolutions have not occurred, now therefore be it resolved that the superintendent will, number one, provide a description of the onboarding process that ensures district staff, including teachers, vice principals, principals, and our prides of the policy, two, provide a report of training available to all staff, including staff participation and training offered disaggregated by building,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three, provide a detailed report of disciplinary actions taken from the start of the 2023-2024 school year through March 1st, 2024.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The report provided should be a model to comply with the annual reporting requirement going forward and will contain the following minimum data.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Types of incidents, determinations, and discipline.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The above data elements summarized for the district.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The above data elements disaggregated by school, by grade level, and by school and grade level.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Four, provide a description of how central administration determines compliance with the policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Five, provide a report of the number of times the above policy has not been followed by building leadership and what actions are being taken to remedy these instances of noncompliance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Six, conduct a review of all suspensions from the start of the 2023-2024 school year through March 1st, 2024, and provide an assessment of how many suspensions were inappropriate

[Lungo-Koehn]: and provide information requested above at the April 8th school committee meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Oh, roll call, sorry, go ahead.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor Londo Kern.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, thank you, Vice Chair Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If you look at slide eight, it does show that our numbers are increasing at a school or two, so I guess my question is, we are doing better with staffing, and how much have we increased over the last two years with regards to staff levels?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, no, I only ask because I know that we have made requests to try to increase, especially at the three schools that are not at anywhere near the capacity as our fourth school, which is the Brooks, and just out of fairness to families from the three other schools, I think it's just important to try to continue to increase staffing so we can

[Lungo-Koehn]: increase those levels to make it more fair across the district.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You know, I think there's 90 people on the wait list for the Roberts alone, but we only have 66 spots where at the Brooks, it's about 125.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that's just my only plea to do whatever we can.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I know you're doing a great deal, Mr. McCarry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just hope that we'd be able to increase, continue to increase as it seems like we have at the Misita.

[Lungo-Koehn]: which I'm assuming means you must have found one or two more staff members there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So any push I can give to, we're working on things on the city side, our rec department's ready, willing and able to help set up a program.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's just a space issue.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The YMCA was, when they were gonna go into St.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Francis, rec was gonna open a program on Forest Street, and then that fell through for the YMCA.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I know how difficult it is to,

[Lungo-Koehn]: continue to increase capacity, but there's definitely over 200 people on the wait list, 200 families, and we want to try to do whatever we can, even if that's just a staff member or two more at each of the other three schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that's just my only plea for the families that are struggling in our community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham, if I may.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sure.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Can we put in a motion to get an update in May in hopes to expand capacity at our three other schools?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's putting the city at risk.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's causing $100,000 in overtime.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I believe it was an orchestrated event.

[Lungo-Koehn]: On the call with me, you just heard from Chief of Staff Nina Nazarian.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think the paper speaks for itself.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you for reading it fully, President Bears.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The position of Fire Chief

[Lungo-Koehn]: became vacant as of a week ago when the chief freedman put in his retirement papers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I want to thank him for his service to the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But it became an opportunity for the city, like many others that have come before us, to request to remove the position from civil service.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As you heard, out of 300 plus 51 cities and towns, there's only 100

[Lungo-Koehn]: um

[Lungo-Koehn]: In civil service and there's only 50 that haven't removed the position.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So out of 351 cities and towns Only 50 are restricted by civil service guidelines and what civil service does is creates a very stringent process not allowing the city to have a broad candidate pool, which includes members of our own department if they choose to have interest in the position and I think modernizing the position

[Lungo-Koehn]: making it more open, competitive, with the goal of hiring the best candidate from a broad pool of applicants, is in the best interest of the city of Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I ask that council support this paper this evening so we can move forward and modernize the way that it's done, the process, so we can get the best candidate for the city of Medford to lead our fire department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You're not part of this conversation here, we're not.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, Councilor Collins and the committee, the application pool would of course allow internal candidates to apply.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, that is the current salary, actually.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So if you took it out of civil service, there would not, it would not be an at will, fire chief, it would be a contracted fire chief from somebody either in the department in the state or even broader.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think

[Lungo-Koehn]: That is the way that it has to be versus last time where four deputies signed up to take the test, only one took it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it seemed like the chief was handpicked by the union.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that too, that did a disservice to our captains who could have signed up for and

[Lungo-Koehn]: Taken the test to be a potential candidate But once four signed up it blocked everybody else and you did hear from other people within the department upset with that process, too I'm gonna I think you want the best candidate in this situation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You had a situation at the beginning of the month Where it cost the city almost a hundred thousand dollars to pay for overtime

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it was not the entire fire department's fault.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it was just a misguided situation that got out of hand.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it's unfortunate because there are good members of the fire department that should be able to rise up.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We just want to make sure that the best person for this job is the proper candidate.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we need to gain some control

[Lungo-Koehn]: Of the membership we need to make sure that we're helping people rise rise up with integrity And that we have a respected department versus what we're seeing

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilor Scarpelli, we promote pretty quickly.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sometimes it does take HR a week or two or myself to review.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had a retirement several weeks back.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It came before myself and HR.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I started to review it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Hoping that I could just promote and push that and get that checked off the list But when I went to look to see who who was on the list because it's not an assessment center Like I I wish it was it's whoever's at the top is how we promote within our fire department and that that's all well and good That's how it's it's taken place and how the process has has landed the last several, you know

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think since I've been around.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But what we have now is not only a review of what happened the first weekend in February, not because I want to review it, it's because we had people

[Lungo-Koehn]: 21 people call out out of 23.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I, as mayor, have an obligation to look into why that happened.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it wasn't just Saturday.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had 12, 13 people call out on Friday.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 12 or 13 people call out on Saturday.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Monday got a little better.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Again, 12 or 13 people until we're scrambling to get a legal letter to the union president saying please stop this behavior.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's putting the city at risk.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's causing $100,000 in overtime.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Overtime has already been skyrocketing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I've been trying to get control of it and get a review on overtime.

[Lungo-Koehn]: because I did suspect what the data is showing, we're going to continue to review it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So if I have people on that list that should be promoted, that were misguided and happened to take time off during that, what I say is an orchestrated event, I have to take a time out and make sure we're promoting

[Lungo-Koehn]: Through this review, investigation, whatever this comes about, I need to make sure that the leaders in the department are going to lead the department with integrity and show their younger members how a department should be led.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and the behavior that should be in our proud Medford Fire Department who are risking their lives to protect us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It happened to me.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Pat Ripley, he's retired, came in when we had an electrical fire.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I will be ever, ever grateful.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm not taking away from what they do every day.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I respect that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I respect the job they do every day.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What I don't respect is the fact that we have a contract.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is settled.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And there was an orchestrated event.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I don't know what lesson they were trying to teach me.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't know what that was.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They just had met with our HR director and our diversity equity inclusion director the day before.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I said, how did those meetings go?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Everybody said they went fine.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They have questions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have concerns.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They have concerns.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But it went well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the people in the residents don't deserve it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we have an orchestrated event that's making it worse.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I have to

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, yep.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilor scarpelli referenced 42 38 which is trumped by the city charter The city charter says the mayor has appointing authority to all department heads So yes, I did offer the interim position to a candidate that I thought could really work with the membership as well as how to explain why Something like the beginning of what happened in the beginning of february was just not helpful um

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it is, but I think tonight is about what we want within a committee, right?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're going to get there, but tell me when within a committee, what are we going to be?

[Lungo-Koehn]: The superintendent, the chief procurement officer, the mayor or designee school committee member, principal, CFO, maintenance architect.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What are we missing?

[Lungo-Koehn]: How large do we want this committee to be?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if we want to take ideas from other surrounding communities, we'd have to do that research and whether you want to table this for tonight and everybody look at a community and we come back and brainstorm ideas, but every community has done it differently.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, we want to do what's right for Medford, what's right for us, and I don't know what the right answer is that's kind of what we're discussing tonight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Remember Graham and you go offline member Rousseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin, then Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, so is there a motion to send this committee the whole unless we want to keep talking and try to hash this out tonight?

[Lungo-Koehn]: 2024-6 offered by myself, Mayor Lungo-Koehn, whereas, oh, whereas all security cameras were recently fixed thanks to the collaboration of the school and city teams, be it resolved that the school IT director provide a monthly status report to the school and city administration and replace anything that breaks down within 45 days.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I put this on just as an update.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've worked over the last several months

[Lungo-Koehn]: get the 30 to 35% of cameras that were broken fixed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That was a collaboration, a lot of pushing from Paul Riggi, who's our facilities maintenance director, Rich Lane, the city's IT director, along with the school team.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we were able to get those fixed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So as of Friday, all of our cameras are working.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's been a huge, it's a huge accomplishment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know the school committee has been pushing to get that done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'm very happy to say that it is done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: want to make sure that it stays that way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think it's incumbent upon the IT director to evaluate the system monthly and give a report to the superintendent and hopefully myself so that we can make sure anything that's broken down is getting fixed so we don't land ourself in the same position five years from now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I do like a motion with a roll call if that's... Question, Mayor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do not have any presentations or continued business, but we do have new business under number 82024-2 offered by member Graham, member Rousseau, and Mayor Lungo-Koehn, myself.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas Medford High School has been accepted into the eligibility phase of the Massachusetts School Building Authority Capital Project Pipeline, and whereas the Medford School Committee seeks to accelerate the time spent in the eligibility phase wherever possible,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and whereas the building committee will require a substantial amount of information that only the superintendent's team can provide once it is established, we resolved the school committee requests the superintendent to begin working to collect the data necessary to complete key deliverables and the MSBA's eligibility process, including educational profile questionnaire, chapter 74 viability, and maintenance and capital planning questionnaire.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had further resolved that an initial draft

[Lungo-Koehn]: of the information required to complete these documents is created no later than March 31st, 2024.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Submitted on January 24th, 2024 for tonight's agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for annual school committee agenda, whereas the Mass Association for School Committees recommends best practice for scheduling and agenda setting for school committee efficiency, whereas communication, planning, and transparency is in the best interest of the community

[Lungo-Koehn]: whereas Medford Public Schools has an identified strategic plan and clear goals, whereas there has historically been an identified pre-schedule to the meetings primarily only known to the chair and superintendent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The result of the Medford School Committee working together through the chair and superintendent create an annual school committee agenda annually in August with agenda items identified and correlated to relevant goals to be published by September 5th of the same school year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We further resolved an ad hoc

[Lungo-Koehn]: ad hoc items to the school committee agenda be added the Wednesday prior to the upcoming school committee meeting as required by public notice and email to school committee members.
