[Lungo-Koehn]: Condolences.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have the members of the Medford School Committee express their sincerest condolences to the family of James Jack McDevitt, who taught business education, government, and law over the course of his 37 years of teaching at Medford High School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In 1986, Mr. McDevitt was instrumental in working with the Medford Cooperative Bank to establish a branch of the bank at the high school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The members of the Medford School Committee express their sincere condolences to the family of Mary Ellen Parks, sister of Larry Parks, custodian at Medford High School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Members of the Medford School Committee express their sincerest condolences to the family of Yvonne J. Richard, father-in-law of Maureen Richard, administrative assistant at the McGlynn School and grandfather of Megan and David Richard, physical education teachers at the Medford Public Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Members of the Medford School Committee express their sincerest condolences to the family of George Crook, father of Chef Matthew Crook of the Bistro, and loving husband of 54 years to Elaine Crook.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The members of the Medford School Committee express their sincerest condolences to the family of Elizabeth Betsy Schroer, a colleague and librarian with Medford Public Schools, wife of Gary Klein, and mother of Rachel, Lydia, and Josh Klein, all Medford Public School graduates or students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we all may rise for a moment of silence.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our next regular meeting is next Monday, February 5th, 2024, here in the Alden Memorial Chambers, as well as by Zoom.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to adjourn?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to adjourn by Member McLaughlin, seconded by Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All

[Lungo-Koehn]: Just a quick question.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In committee?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dearborn.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Lisa.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Terry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to this celebration of Dr. King's life and legacy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm honored to be here today to honor his life with all of you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you to everyone who's made this wonderful event possible, the West Medford Community Center for organizing and running the event, especially Executive Director Lisa Crossman and Terry Carter, St.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Raphael's Parish for hosting, the Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Director Francis Wojcicki, the Haywood Family Foundation, Medford Community Media, and Wegmans.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And thanks to retired Special Officer Daryl Owens from the Boston Police Department for being here and to share some words with us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Having the opportunity to talk openly about the challenges we face as a community, as well as the successes we've had crafting more meaningful relationships between one another, is a humbling experience.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'm grateful that we've been able to take this journey of equity and understanding together.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Of course, there's much more work we have to do as a government to not only solidify trust with our community, but better serve people who historically have not had agency with those making the decisions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm thankful that we're changing that in Medford, and with the help of all of you, we've made such significant progress, but we're not done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm looking forward to a wonderful event.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Bailey was a little under the weather, so this is my daughter Callaway.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I, Breanna Lungo-Koehn.

[Lungo-Koehn]: agreeable to the rules and regulations of the Constitution.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The laws of the Commonwealth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the ordinances of the city of Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You want to sit?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, thank you, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Rep.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Barber, for that introduction and your kind words.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Good evening, and thank you all for coming to the 2024 Medford Inauguration.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you to everyone who is taking part in today's ceremony.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you to Director of Community Affairs, Lisa Coliani, who did all the planning for this wonderful event, and Director of Communications, Steve Smearty,

[Lungo-Koehn]: for helping me work on this very long speech.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I took out all the dad jokes, though, that you put in.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I also want to take the opportunity to recognize the tireless work of our department heads, city staff, my fellow elected officials, and volunteers who have continued to do amazing things while navigating all of the challenges we have faced over the last four years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As I've always said, the successes of this administration are not due to a single policy or person.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They're a contribution of ideas from some of the brightest and most dedicated people I've had the pleasure of working with.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So to everyone who works in this building and for the city as a whole, thank you for your hard work to make Medford such a special place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'd also like to thank my family for supporting me while I continue this work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dave, Bailey, Calloway, Cody, Mom and Dad, I appreciate your patience, sacrifice, strength and love, no matter how hard it gets for us sometimes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With each new term brings a renewed sense of service and commitment to our city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All of us here standing before you, about to accept the immense responsibility you have bestowed, are filled with gratitude and humility.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I can safely say that taking this oath is one of the greatest privileges of my life.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And though I've been extraordinarily fortunate to be trusted with this honor several times, I never take it for granted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's a message I hope my fellow colleagues experiencing this again, or for the first time, take to heart.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Enjoy this day, cherish the road that brought you to this point, and never lose sight of the ultimate goal, serving the people of this city with pride, purpose, and professionalism.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Congratulations to you all.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are at the forefront of the future of Medford, and I'm excited to work with you all and continue the relationships with those re-elected, Jenny, Paul, Melanie, Zach, Kit, Justin, and George.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and forge new partnerships with those serving for the first time, Erica, Aaron, Nicole, Anna, Emily, and Matt.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Over the past two terms, we have taken so many steps forward in creating a vibrant, equitable, accountable, and forward-thinking city from our hiring practices to everyday decisions we make.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have done the hard work, faced many obstacles, and now look to keep moving forward and continue to build on the foundation we have created.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For years, it has been said that Medford has lagged behind other surrounding cities in terms of maximizing its development potential, increasing our commercial tax base, leveraging city-owned assets, and investing in its infrastructure.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I shared in those concerns and criticisms while on the Council and made it a priority as Mayor to redirect our development strategy to focus on growth that contributes both to the bottom line as well as addresses key needs in our community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: None perhaps more critical to our future than creating more affordable housing options.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To help make that possible, my office, along with the Office of Planning, Development and Sustainability, led by Director Hunt, Alicia Hunt, worked closely with the City Council to establish an affordable housing trust.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The trust will use various funding streams to help facilitate more affordable units coming to market.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I thank the Council for being a strong partner in that process and look forward to working with the new members

[Lungo-Koehn]: to expand on its potential.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Much of this progress is also thanks to the advocacy and work of the former council that passed a much-needed recodification of the city's zoning ordinances in 2022.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Through this recodification process,

[Lungo-Koehn]: My administration worked with the City Council to establish a new zoning district, called the Planned Development District, which encourages proposals that specify a mixture of commercial, industrial, residential, open space, or other uses, as well as a DIF district for Medford Square.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To help manage our lofty and complex development and zoning goals, it's critical that we have a top-tier team in place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why I'm grateful for the work that Bill 40 has done

[Lungo-Koehn]: during his tenure as building commissioner, and thank him for staying on in an interim role as we searched for our successor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our new commissioner starts in a few weeks, which is exciting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But Bill, please know, you have been instrumental in furthering our work here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And by doing this work together, we are seizing on the opportunity to bring real, transformative change to the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are in the process of bringing over 500 new residential units to the community through eight residential developments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To further support the housing crisis that is affecting nearly every municipality, we have also allocated $400,000 in ARPA funds to help offset permitting costs of renovations and upgrades to the current and new affordable housing units at the Medford Housing Authority.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The guiding force behind our housing development strategy is the Housing Production Plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This document serves as our roadmap to more meaningful community experience for our residents, and has been crafted with insight from housing advocates, local leaders, and the City Council.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I thank everyone involved who has lent their time, resources, and knowledge to help address this evolving and complex crisis.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In addition to increasing the housing stock, we are also working to bring new innovative industries to Medford that can tap into the talent pool and transform neighborhoods into technology hubs for the region.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There are currently four life science development projects underway.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And this is just the beginning.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To truly activate the economic engine of Medford, we must continue to support and invest in our squares and green spaces.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The next two years will bring about significant change to Medford Square, the central hub of our downtown commercial district.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With three undeveloped lots located in the heart of the square, we are continuing that work that is stretched back to 2010.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Armed with significant input from our residents, our past economic development director, Victor Schrader, and moving forward with the help of our newly hired economic development director, Sal DiStefano, we are finalizing an RFP to be released soon.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With that portion of the square poised for transformation, it's wonderful to see Salem, Forest, and High Street becoming a nighttime destination for families and the public at large.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seeing the square bustling during the evening thanks to Chevalier Theatre and our amazing restaurants, with more to open in 2024, brings such a great smile to my face.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That type of draw and that level of interest does not happen overnight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It takes commitment, dedication, and strong partnership between city staff, private partners, the council, and our Chamber of Commerce, now led by the new President Rocco DiRico.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Together, we've been able to help strengthen our local businesses in many ways and support their journey through the pandemic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Last year, we awarded many of our local businesses a total of over $100,000 through the Small Business Facade Improvement Grant Program.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, with so many people eager to frequent our commercial corridors, it only makes sense to fully activate our waterfront property.

[Lungo-Koehn]: which we have plans for, and make green spaces in our squares more accessible and pedestrian-friendly.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have officially broken ground on the Clippership Connector, uniting a pedestrian pathway between Riverbend Park and Clippership Park.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The path will allow people to walk, run, bike, and push strolls along a section of the river that to date has been blocked from public access.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I thank Mayor Burke, City staff, and our partners at DCR

[Lungo-Koehn]: especially new Commissioner Brian Arrigo for helping get that process off the ground and now in construction.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are also sitting on a truly transformative and generational opportunity with 28 acres of air rights above the Wellington MBTA station.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For decades, this city-owned area went undeveloped and we are now in a position to activate that area and transform it into a mixed-use, transit-oriented residential and commercial destination.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We received proposals on what could be feasible for the space and are now in the process of releasing an RFP to hire a consultant to help us move forward in the next stage of the development process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There are significant development projects that will have a substantial impact on not only the landscape of our community, but our projected revenues as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And while that is a profound positive for our city, it is not the highlight of our future project prospects.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That distinction squarely falls on the amazing news of our Mass School Building Authority application.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was recently announced that we have secured a spot in this year's process and we're on the path to reimagining a new state-of-the-art high school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm thrilled that through the work of Superintendent Maurice-Edouard-Vincent, our school committee, school district staff, community partners, and our team at City Hall, we now have the opportunity to collaborate with the state to make this project a reality for our community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This would not be possible without the advocacy and support from so many advocates, as well as the City Council who approved moving forward with the application.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The only project that may rival the high school in terms of size and scope is that we're also doing our fire headquarters over.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our firefighters need a facility that meets the needs of a 21st century department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Last year, we hired the Gallant Architecture Studio, Inc.

[Lungo-Koehn]: to design and envision a new fire department headquarters, and we are about to begin the design phase of a $25 to $30 million facility.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In addition, there has been nearly $4 million put towards our fire department projects that are complete or near completion at our substations, and $2 million going towards two fire pump trucks that have recently been ordered to upgrade the fleet we currently have.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have also solicited a reviewing proposal for architects to assist with designing much-needed additional upgrades and renovations to our stations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These needs were on the top of my list when I ran in 2019.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I thank Chief of Staff Nina Nazarian and Chief John Friedman for helping us make it all a reality for the department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In addition to all the work being done to our fire stations and high school, we're also now, through the hard work of Paul Riggi, the city's first ever facilities maintenance director, reviewing, planning, and investing in our facilities by taking important steps to ensure their longevity and usefulness.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're also making significant progress in all things IT related, thanks initially to Jim Silva and our IT director, Rich Lane.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our IT infrastructure,

[Lungo-Koehn]: IT's not fancy, but it's pretty important.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our City IT infrastructure is getting an overhaul with the buildings getting connected with fiber optics and important changes to the network inside City Hall to make our system more reliable and support the needs of our departments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In addition to the work being done in city facilities, we are also forging ahead with millions invested towards incredible upgrades and renovations to our parks and open spaces.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thanks to the hard work of staff planner Amanda Centrella, along with our entire parks team, which includes rec director Kevin Bailey, tree warden Aggie Tooden, our chief procurement officer Fiona Maxwell, and our DPW crew, this past year alone, a number of additional projects have either been completed or celebrated with a groundbreaking.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Including just this week, we upgraded, we did a groundbreaking for the accessible McGlynn Playground.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Many parks and recreation spaces have also been upgraded with new art murals, including our latest reveal by artist Jamie Chan at Wrights Pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our most ambitious park project, a major renovation undertaking at Carr Park Broke Ground this past fall.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The car park renovation project is split into two phases, and the second phase, which is going to have all seasons basketball court, thanks to Congresswoman Kathleen Clark, who secured us a $1.5 million federal earmark for that phase.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Investing in our parks and open spaces is a critical part of our effort to combat and reduce the effects of climate change.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Making our parks more sustainable, accessible and resilient is just one facet of our strategy to reduce emissions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are also taking the same approach to the City's infrastructure and operations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford's work with the Municipal Vulnerability Preparedness continues as the City was granted over $400,000 from the State in December to expand climate resiliency efforts and $500,000 more recently in grant money from the Barr Foundation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With this funding, the City is enhancing its climate resiliency and emergency preparedness efforts through Medford Connects.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford Connects, headed by our Board of Health Director, Marian O'Connor, and the Office of Prevention and Outreach Director, Penny Fanioli, will seek to expand and strengthen resources for community members who are most marginalized to build the community's ability to withstand and recover from climate crises in the future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Green Communities Division awarded Medford $100,000 to make Gulcani Ice Rink and the Department of Public Works more energy efficient and further reduce the city's carbon emissions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As a designated green community, we have committed to reducing municipal energy use by 20 percent from our baseline year, a goal we have in our sights.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The City is also committed to expanding its tree canopy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We set a goal to plant over 200 trees throughout the community during the 2023 season as part of this continual strategy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That number builds upon the 180 trees that were planted the year before.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Using Community Preservation Act funds and ARPA funding, the goal is to plant trees in greater numbers of species and varieties in locations where they can grow and thrive into maturity so they can have an impact and provide benefits to the greater community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're also heavily invested in removing tree stumps and repairing sidewalks damaged by the backlog of untreated stumps.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As a start, this past year, we removed almost half on the list by investing almost a half million dollars to the tree stump removal process alone, through CDBG, ARPA, and state earmarks advocated for by our state delegation and in partnership with the city council.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Rep.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Barber, Representative Donato, Representative Garbally, and Senator Jalen, for all the earmarks you got us, including on the stumps.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And thank you to our CPA coordinator, Theresa DuPont,

[Lungo-Koehn]: CPA committee led by Roberta Cameron and our CDBG coordinator Laurel Siegel for making this and so many more projects a reality for Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To aid in our climate goals, the city is in the process of transitioning its parking fleet and police department cruiser fleet to fuel-efficient, climate-friendly hybrid options.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Just a few weeks ago, the Police Department took delivery of six hybrid vehicles that will be utilized by officers in the field, and the Parking Department took delivery, before that, of three hybrid vehicles.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I thank the Police Chief Jack Buckley and Parking Director Faye Morrison for their support and patience in making sure we all transition to a more fuel-efficient way of doing business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The City also secured a $230,000 Diesel Emissions Reduction Act grant from the State to assist with the purchasing of an all-electric commercial-grade street sweeper that we just took delivery on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: While we've made those strides on the City side, thanks to Traffic and Transportation Director Todd Blake, we've also benefited from a public-private partnership with Lyft and Blue Bikes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: About three weeks ago, we completed installation on two new stations, one in West Medford and another at Logan Park, bringing the network to 10, with more coming in the spring.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our EV charging station count has also gone up from 2 to 10 over the last four years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Over the last term, we also cut the ribbon on the Tufts-Medford branch of the Green Line Extension.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Reducing our reliance on gas-powered vehicles and investing in green transportation options will only make our community more sustainable, equitable and accessible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But, of course, we cannot forgo our responsibility in fixing our roads and sidewalks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why this year alone we've made significant progress in extending the life of our streets through preventative maintenance and leveraging private partnerships to repair portions of major arteries like Winthrop Street, Pinkert, Haines Square and Riverside Ave.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the fall, we began an extensive patchwork program on 34 streets identified in the pavement assessment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, over the last year, we crack-sealed 94 streets, which extends their use and improves navigability and drainage on those streets.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To coincide with our patchwork strategy, we also invested nearly $3 million in repairs to our sidewalks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: About one-third of the total sidewalk funding, roughly $800,000, was used to address sidewalk issues logged by constituents in our C-Click Fix platform that also coincide with sidewalk locations identified in the 2021 sidewalk assessment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thanks to the incredible work of our DPW Commissioner Tim McGivern, City Engineer Owen Wartella and their staffs, we have repaired nearly two miles worth of sidewalks this past season.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're continuing this work into the next year thanks to the $1.5 million bond that the City Council approved at the beginning of last year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We'll deploy the rest of the funding to address sidewalks and curb cuts on Salem Street and beyond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Leadership within the City Council, School Committee, and City have also been and will continue to meet to figure out our projected assessment, budgeting, and borrowing needs for sidewalks, our major building improvements, and more.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thanks to the support of our Finance Director and Auditor Bob Dickinson, our Treasurer-Collector Judy Johnson, Assessor Ted Costigan,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and our budget director, Courtney Cadello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have come a long way in our new growth projections, how the city borrows and budgets, and we'll continue to work together with the council to enhance that process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And everything we do in Medford is informed through the lens of diversity, equity, and inclusion.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With the help of our director, Frances Wojcicki, we are working towards ensuring that services, programs, and events are not only accessible, but share in the values and meet the needs of our diverse community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For the past two years, Frances and her work with stakeholders has strengthened relationships with community members and created lasting partnerships that have yielded meaningful experience for everyone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whether it be reaffirming the City's commitment to human rights, championing accessible language options for visitors to City Hall, or building on the success of our first-ever Pride Month series events in 2022 with the help of our Pride Planning Committee, the City's desire to be an inclusive and welcoming place for all would not be possible without the work of our DEI office and department heads who support these goals.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our DEI endeavors, however, are not siloed to one office.

[Lungo-Koehn]: they reach across departments, programs, and communications.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The interdepartmental cohesion is best exemplified by the work being done through our human resource department, led by our director, Lisa Crowley, who, along with Francis, works diligently to ensure our hiring practices are based on best practices and that our workforce is more representative of our community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why we've been focused on training our staff and diversifying our staffing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have made progress, but my commitment is to keep pushing to do better.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need our staffing to represent the community we live in, and I promise to continue this work no matter what it takes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: An important part of this project...

[Lungo-Koehn]: was the hiring of our Medford Connectors and liaisons who serve communities across the city and are fluent in four environmental justice languages.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They have been working to listen and support Medford's diverse communities and help us improve communication policies and programs.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are committed to making Medford safe, welcoming,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and are always looking to improve communication efforts and policies to continue to make that a reality.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Through this initiative, we have been able to offer expanded translation services through a variety of communication methods.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Of course, our multilingual resource line is always available.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are also working to ensure that important information on our website and sent through the City Alert System and other avenues is translated into our five major languages, main languages.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is a first for the City and will allow us to message important City-related information to populations that were previously underserved in this area.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Office of Prevention and Outreach, with the help of these teams, is also working to strengthen resources available to community members who have been affected by the opioid crisis with an over 830,000 settlement from the Opioid Settlement Fund, with the potential for more funding in the future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Using interview surveys

[Lungo-Koehn]: and other community outreach, the team is currently working through recommendations and strategies for investing these funds.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm also happy to announce, as of last week, we hired our new Veterans Director, Veronica Shaw, who will continue the hard work of Jeremy Johns servicing our veterans and their needs.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you for joining our team, Veronica.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You're a great addition to the staff we have here at City Hall and beyond, such as Pam Kelly, who runs our Senior Center and our Tax Workoff Program, Director Barbara Kerr, who operates our new Medford Public Library, Kevin Harrington, who helped video this tonight, who runs our Medford Community Media, and so many others.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For those of you worried that the speech will be wrapping up soon, I'm almost halfway through.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's very hard to try to get every department in there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I can't not do it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm sorry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Just kidding.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A few brief highlights and we're done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Just today, thanks to Clerk Adam Hurtubise, we were able to swear in and promote two firefighters in the department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And just last week, we welcomed six new police officers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The highlight of our police hires last week is that, once again, we were able to hire a diverse group that represents our community, which was not only a goal of Chief Buckley and I's, but something we are proud of to actually see become a reality.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Run Medford, hopefully we'll be back for our third year in 2024, thanks to Dave McGilvery and Dempsey Sports.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our Charter Study Committee is deep into their work, gathering input, researching and holding community meetings on how to best shape our charter and how to move this city forward into the future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thanks to our election manager, Melissa Ripley, and crew.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you to them.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They're getting ready for the smooth presidential primary and election season this year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you to our parking team for working on two phases of meter installs to make sure our squares have upgraded equipment, the remainder of which are going live, I believe, this month.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you to our police department, who are now equipped with body cameras for their safety, the safety of others, and for accountability purposes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's so much more, but I've had enough, and I know you all have.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We want to listen to Stacey in the Corral, I know.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To conclude, I'm often asked what some of my most notable achievements during my time as mayor are, and I always say that no achievement is earned by one person, or in many cases, by one department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Every positive piece of progress that happens here is the result of the team we have here in the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So thank you again for all your hard work, and in advance for your hard work coming in the next two years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I would also be remiss if I did not give a special thanks to my assistant, Daria Tajera.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Her patience and kindness is felt by all.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And she has dealt with me for eight years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Bless you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I am so excited for what the next two years will bring and thank you for entrusting me to lead our city for another term.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I am dedicated to keeping the promises I've made to you and delivering on this vision for a better future for Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I know City Hall staff and my fellow elected officials are ready to do the work necessary to make that happen.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No matter what challenges we face, we have proven that we are able to unite as a community and as a result are ready to take the next step into the future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're at the forefront of a more sustainable, equitable, and prosperous time for Medford, and I can't wait to share that experience with you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, the first regular meeting of the Medford School Committee, January 8th, 2024 at 6 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have no presentations of the public.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have no continued business and we do have one item under new business 2024-01 offered by member Graham, whereas the Metropolitan Public Schools recognizes the vital role of play in the development and wellbeing of students, whereas the current playground facilities at McGlynn Elementary are in need of replacement

[Lungo-Koehn]: to create a safe and fun environment that meets the growing and diverse needs of our student body.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas the creation of new inclusive and engaging playground is a priority of the enhancement of our educational environment, now therefore be it resolved that the Medford School Committee, number one, establishes the McGlynn Playground Replacement Initiative and a donation campaign pursuant to policy FF, policy for dedication and naming of school buildings, facilities, and grounds.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number two, requests the administration establish a mechanism

[Lungo-Koehn]: to account for and report on the donations, and three, request the administration set up a public relations campaign to solicit donations to the playground fund to offset the cost of replacing the playground.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The promotion of the initiative will occur through school newsletters, local media, social media, and community events.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The campaign will have the following objectives and donation tier structure.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Objective, to raise funds for the construction of a new playground at McGlynn Elementary.

[Lungo-Koehn]: that fosters a safe, inclusive, and stimulating environment for all students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Donation tier structure.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Hopscotch Hero tier, donations 50 to 250, sorry, 249.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Swing Set Superstar tier, donations 250 to 499.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Slide Savant tier, donations of $500 to $999.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Climbing Frame Champion tier, donations of 1,000 to $4,999.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and the merry ground mastermind here donations of 5000 and above donor benefits will be the recognition in a district wide press release personalized thank you note signed by the school committee superintendent and school principal name on a plaque is a good one name on a plaque at the playground entrance and invitation to the playground ribbon cutting offered by member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Maybe some sort of picture of Emily.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you for sharing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And just from the chair, I don't know if we wanna leave it a little bit open-ended.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we have hundreds and hundreds of people donating five, 10, 50 to $100, just leave it open-ended for either a subcommittee or the superintendent to decide whose name would go on a plaque.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A lot of times,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Or do we just put it on the website?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just think if you have hundreds and hundreds of names, I don't know how you're gonna, it will take up a whole fence.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If that's what we wanna do, that's fine.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And just from the chair, if I may, I just want to thank everybody that had anything to do with this process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it started for us two years ago with our last application and making sure we had a strong application.

[Lungo-Koehn]: all the way through to now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know a number of us on the committee were on those calls this last week, and we're going to be following the process and helping them how we can with our Dr. Edouard-Vincent leading the charge.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we're going to get this done and get it hopefully done sooner than five to seven years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're so excited.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is beyond time for our students and faculty and staff to have a building that they deserve, that is conducive to

[Lungo-Koehn]: learning in a better environment than they have now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we're excited.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And finally, some good news.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So wonderful.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, everybody.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Next up, we do not have any presentations of the public, continued business or new business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we do have a reports requested by member Hays and member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'm reminded if I read it, whereas the Medford School Committee passed resolutions

[Lungo-Koehn]: on 12-6-21 and 11-7-22 to provide funding for an assessment of Medford High School and Medford Vocational Technical High School to include recommendations to address moving forward in a manner that prioritizes a healthy school community and outline organizational, structural, professional development and curriculum-based changes needed to address the findings and achieve our district-wide mission.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas an assessment was completed by Mr. Welch in the spring of 2023,

[Lungo-Koehn]: the findings and recommendations discussed at school committee on 5-1-23 and 6-12-23 be resolved that the Metropolitan Public Schools Administration will provide a presentation by the end of February 2024 to update progress on the following recommendations provided by Mr. Welch's report and during subsequent school committee meetings with Mr. Welch.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number one, creation of MHS committees recommended in report

[Lungo-Koehn]: That motion was passed on 6-12-23.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Committee of the whole meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A, safety and security team.

[Lungo-Koehn]: B, diversity, equity and inclusion committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: C, committee on norms for student behavior.

[Lungo-Koehn]: D, unified MHS, MVTHS schedule committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Two, invitation to Mr. Welch to attend an executive session to advise in the next set of teacher contract negotiations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three, updated memorandum of understanding with the chief of police regarding school resource officers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: for development of consensus about a vision for MPS with community, caregiver, teacher, and student involvement.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Five, provide more opportunities for teacher input in decision-making and build relationships between teachers and administration.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Six, parent-caregiver surveys about culture and climate at MHS and Medford Vocational Technical High School during 2023-2024 school year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seven, MHS and MVTHS associate assistant principal

[Lungo-Koehn]: Person position focused primarily on logistical and management pieces to allow the principal to focus on a role as the academic and instructional leader.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Eight, mentoring for new administrators.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A, at MHS, individual mentoring with mentors exterior to the district for the new principal and new APs along with group mentoring for all.

[Lungo-Koehn]: B, mentoring for new principals at the Roberts and Andrews.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And nine,

[Lungo-Koehn]: MHS security personnel and building monitors review titles and job descriptions to consolidate into fewer titles, clarify the scope of responsibilities and training provided for each position.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Hays, would you like to speak on it or do you want a motion for approval?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Just a motion for approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford Public Schools lost two giants this Thanksgiving week.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Former Medford Heights Assistant Principal Stephen Maskell and physical education teacher Paul McEwen.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Assistant Principal Maskell was one of the first African American administrators appointed in the district.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He was also a history teacher, track coach, and mentor to many

[Lungo-Koehn]: during his service at Medford High School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mr. McEwen was not only a physical education teacher at Medford High School, but also served as a trainer to the Mustang football team and was the advisor to the Mustang M-Club.

[Lungo-Koehn]: OK.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Try to watch maybe one TV show a week just to clear the mind.

[Lungo-Koehn]: OK.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah.

[Lungo-Koehn]: OK.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Oh, good question.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My friend, who's still my good friend, she was over for Halloween.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've been friends since kindergarten, and she was dating somebody from Long Island to New York, and said, I think my boyfriend's friend, you'd really get along with him.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You should come meet him.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that happened for about three, four, five, six months.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Finally, I said, OK, I'll go and meet him.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then we went up to, at the time they were living in Connecticut, and we hit it off the first night, and we've been together ever since.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A little bit.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Every anniversary for my husband and I, she sends me a, you're welcome, text.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You're welcome.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Not happy anniversary, but you're welcome.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Like, thanks for the 20th time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've been together 20 plus years and we've been married 15 and a half years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Congratulations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Very good.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He's always very supportive.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I tell the story that he is a physical therapist, and he's local now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He's Medford, Arlington, and Winchester.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But before he opened his own practice,

[Lungo-Koehn]: he was down in the Walpole-Sharon area.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So from 6 in the morning until 8 at night, 9 at night and then also on Saturdays he was working and I was practicing law, taking care of the babies and that was 10-12 years so finally when we were deciding

[Lungo-Koehn]: if I should run for mayor, was it the right decision for the family?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we decided that, yes, we want to do it because we have kids in the schools and we do want the best for our community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He said, it's your turn.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, so he's extremely supportive, you know, he does a lot of the athletics especially on nights that I have meetings And yeah, yeah, I think it's a little overwhelming.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's tough for him the social media a part of it and the negativity Yeah gets to him a bit especially just like around now and it really heats up.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've been lucky.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's been a very good campaign season, you know, I think Councilor Caraviello and I really trying to run a a

[Lungo-Koehn]: as much as we can.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know it's going to get tough today, but otherwise it's been a pretty calm, not too much negativity, which is great.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But when it turns up, yeah, that gets to my husband a bit.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, and I do too, you know, one weekend I'll have a couple, an hour and I'll do the food shopping, the next weekend he'll do it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And my kids, we taught them how to turn on and put in soap to the laundry machine, you know, they have to do their own dishes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have chores in the house, so we really try to

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's all they've known me in politics, whether it was Councilor or mayor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I try to teach them the good of the job and the good that you can do in the community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think they understand it and want to pitch in some.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we make it work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My son is affected by the goods.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So if we do a community-wide cleanup, he'll clean up an area and then he'll never forget it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And he has to tell me every time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Or we put flags on the graves for Memorial Day.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And every time we drive by Oak Grove, he's like, that's where we go in May, and we put flags on the graves.

[Lungo-Koehn]: but I think they're all impacted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My other two are older teenage daughters, so they watch the debate and they're learning and understanding.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Do they want to talk about politics much?

[Lungo-Koehn]: No, no, but there'll be times that I just make sure I tell them a story about something that I think will affect them in the future, whether that has to do with working hard or holding somebody accountable or recently,

[Lungo-Koehn]: that we'd got the verdict for the bribery case in Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I like you try to explain that to them so they know what integrity is and what that scheme was about and do my best to not not infiltrate them with it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But once in a once in a while, tell them a story that I know will impact them in the future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yep.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three and three and a half years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think the first term we about eight weeks in, we got hit with covid.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So a lot of that a lot of the first term was getting through covid, making sure everybody was healthy and safe and then getting the city back up and running while we were doing the planning.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You know, we're doing the housing production plan and the climate action and adaptation plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and our comprehensive master plan and our street and sidewalk assessment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And so we were really people didn't see us out much, but we were in City Hall.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The whole City Hall was always open unless the governor shut it down.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We were grinding and doing the work and trying to have the community meetings, even if they were on Zoom.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and getting that planning done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So now it's exciting to see more and more projects breaking ground and ribbon cuttings, because that's the work we did the first two years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have the largest park project where just broke ground on, which is Carr Park, and then Gillis is halfway through.

[Lungo-Koehn]: because that needed some accessibility improvements, and it's going to be a great park for people of all ages and abilities.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But then you see the Great American Bear Hall.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I went to go visit the site yesterday.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's broken ground, and that's going to be done in June.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's going to have 90 bears on tap and all kinds of food and games.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That went wild on social media yesterday, so people are seeing all the projects.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're finally able to see the work getting done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We did two miles of, I know we have a lot more miles due, but two miles of sidewalk repairs just this year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've removed half of our tree stumps, which was just, it took two years to, we've been removing them every year, but we finally got to a point where we found the funding, we're applying for grants, we're receiving the grants,

[Lungo-Koehn]: moving forward on a municipal vulnerability preparedness work through our liaisons and connectors, and you're seeing the different events pop up that, you know, it takes time to plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Understood.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we have a lot going on, which is just the positive.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The positive is so positive, and that's why I love the job.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You know, it outweighs the negatives.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have I merged early on in the term, merged the Office of Community Development with Energy and Environment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we have our Planning, Development and Sustainability Department, which is run by Director Hunt.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then we have our Diversity, Equity, Inclusion

[Lungo-Koehn]: director who's been at it for quite some time now with us, Francis Wojtyla.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a good strong Department of Public Works and engineering team with Director Blake, Director Wartell and McGivern.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We finally had a place with our parking department with Faye Morrison where

[Lungo-Koehn]: And our special projects manager, Jim Silva, that's helping with any parking issues we see that pop up.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And people finally are getting, follow the rules of the road, and we're making progress there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then the list goes on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a really strong finance team.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have procurement, treasure collector, CFO, budget director, that are all, we had a budget, we won a budget award two years ago, applied again.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, I mean, I feel like we have a strong team, good chiefs in place, and yeah.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm sure I'm missing people, so I could keep going, but.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Plan it our Board of Health with our Office of Prevention and Outreach, you know Nobody's ever perfect.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a lot more we have to do but we You know, we're able to really work together doing a new we're almost done with our emergency management plan For the city, so we'll be prepared if there's a flood or if there's an environmental disaster We'll get in the Andrews ready

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know this location is also a good one, too, in the Hegner Center.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we're trying to map out where people can go to get what they need, water, food, services, and hopefully never need for housing, but emergency housing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But yeah, we're doing a lot of work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My day is filled with the, or half of my day, I guess, is filled with some of the HR pieces, which can be, whew, in themselves.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I always say that I drive home and then I think of all the good that people are doing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So not even just in City Hall, just throughout the community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All the boards and commission volunteers and people that are just working together, all the organizations we have in Medford, so really,

[Lungo-Koehn]: blows my mind at how hard so many, not everybody, but so many people worked and and how many people just really work for the city that care about its future and care about the people of Medford and making sure that we do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Everybody does have what they need and everybody feels welcome and included in that process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it's it's a large task, but we're working hard at it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think the one of the biggest things COVID did for me personally in my governance is helped not help stay prepared and ready and

[Lungo-Koehn]: have the for anything that comes our way so every day there's you know every week at least there's a crisis or two and just for me to stay calm cool and collected and you know even my communications director says how do you stay so calm like well I have to and

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have to, so then my team does, and my team can stretch very far.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But also because we have to be thoughtful, even if we have to act quickly, we still need to be thoughtful and think things through and work together.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So staying calm is something that COVID taught me, because my first eight weeks I would go to bed at night going, I don't know if I can do this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Oh, the ABC is going to help the MBTA with the MAPC and the funding will come from the MT.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was just words that, you know, letter salad.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But then Covid hit and just kind of had to slap myself across the face and say, it's time to lead.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You know, you can do this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, knowing that I could make the right decisions, not that everybody would be happy one way or another, but that I really thought things through and I took my time and when I had to, to do what I thought was the best and listen to both sides so I could figure out what was needed to be done to keep people healthy and safe is definitely

[Lungo-Koehn]: helped me know how to manage stress, how to stay mentally ready.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that's probably my best answer I have.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have so we have so many things on our plate that are that are unfinished and so much more good to do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and keep the team in place that we have.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I go to bed at night knowing the work was hard, but that I am doing the right thing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I just wanna continue to lead this great community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, okay, fair enough, fair enough.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's a long list.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know, I know.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and an assessment comparing the cost benefits for replacing the HVAC system with code compliant equipment versus energy efficient versus all electric, including all utility rebates, professional cost estimator will provide a solid estimate for each option and two options in kind replacements.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we do have high hopes that we'll be able to get this done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Unfortunately, and from the chair, I sat in my office last week and just felt completely terrible about what was going on in our schools, getting texts from my daughter and emails from parents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know we all felt the same way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That will be in September, where the City's working with DCR to do a groundbreaking ceremony.

[Lungo-Koehn]: but that is going to connect our bike path and be an amazing addition to the city of Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please take our charter study committee survey.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That is now open and will be open for several months, but we want anybody and everybody's input so we can update our very, very outdated charter.

[Lungo-Koehn]: for applying for and receiving a $45,000 digital literacy grant that will help our seniors throughout the fall and winter and into 2024 to help them with tech access.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So thank you, Pam, for applying.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're so excited you got that grant.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we did receive that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's an over $100,000 grant.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So congratulations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Very exciting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it definitely goes towards all the work we're doing on municipal vulnerability preparedness.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Next up,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Todd Blake, our director of traffic and transportation, has applied for a number of grants and received two community connection grants, one for over $30,000 for bike parking and one for close to $150,000 for blue bike stations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As you know, the city, with director Blake and planning, has expanded our blue bike network and we are not stopping.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we're trying to get them at our schools and some of our parks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: City Hall, Police Station.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a lot in the works and we're excited about that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We start school on the 30th of September, which is Wednesday, and we hope everybody has a great day and a great week and a great school year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Hello, happy Monday, and this is Brianna Lungu-Kern, Mayor of Medford, just here with some good news.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First up, if you've been up to Wright's Pond, you will notice that the art mural is pretty much complete.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our artist, Jamie Chan, has been working on that over the last several weeks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It looks amazing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So please go check it out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if you haven't got your pass to the to the pond, please do so.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then Tufts pool is also open for use.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, there's a free summer park program put on by recreation from 7-11 to August 15th at Hormel.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's 9 to 12.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's in the morning, so go check it out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And from July 12th to August 16th, it's at Tufts Park from 9 a.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: to 12 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, Medford Recreation is putting on its movie nights.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There'll be a series of three movies on

[Lungo-Koehn]: was one Friday and our second one is on July 21st.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's at Tufts Park and the third is on August 18th which is at Wright's Pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So you get there around 7 30 you set up and the movie starts right at 8 30.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So please join us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also we are doing a lot of work on our streets.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have almost 50 streets that we're patchworking.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You'll see that work was done recently on Lawrence Road and we have another

[Lungo-Koehn]: 30, 40 to go.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also got bids back for the remaining crack seal projects that we're working on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's 94 streets.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we're doing about 150 streets just with patchwork and crack sealing over the next several months, which is very exciting and well needed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also good news on some of our park projects.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have Gillis Park.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are breaking ground on that mid to end of July.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have Carr Park that's going to be late July, early August, that will break ground on phase one.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Morrison Park will be done at the end of August.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then Hickey Park, because we needed time to let the pavement settle, those basketball courts and tennis courts will be done end of August, beginning of September.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then also great news, a lot of people ask all the time, Riverside Ave is in bad shape.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we were repaving, milling and paving and doing a lot of the additional work that's needed on that road.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That will be done, hopefully start next week and take several weeks to complete.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And things are a little bit delayed because of the rain.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So just keep an eye out that any projects that we have going on are a bit delayed due to the rain.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But as you can see, a lot in the works, a lot is going on in this city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we're super excited and thankful for all the hardworking employees that are making it happen.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Otherwise, have a wonderful, great week and talk soon.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Just to answer that as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do do the full application process so everything gets posted on the city website and on better teams, so that everybody has access to apply for these positions and we do try to take obviously Medford residents it's working out well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Um from the chair, if I may, I just want to thank you, Penny and Doctor Cushing for working with Penny as well as Stacey Shulman who I know is on the call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Um collaboration is is going to only benefit not only our youth but the entire city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, I hope that we do

[Lungo-Koehn]: get another presentation right when the 2023 survey is completed and the data is analyzed so that we can have a better understanding of where we're at.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But the work that you and the team and under our health director, Marianne O'Connor, who's also on the call, have done, we're making progress and we need to make more, obviously more progress, because we all know what our children are going through.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know that the schools have a seat at the table at the behavioral health meetings.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That was set up about a year ago and it's it's moving along so anything I can do as mayor and I know the school committee probably feels the same way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do not have any presentations of the public or continued business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do have one resolution under new business offered by Member Hays and Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Stone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Resolution in support of LGBTQ plus youth in Medford, where as June is LGBTQ plus pride month, whereas the human rights campaign has already identified in 2023 over 540 anti-LGBTQ plus bills

[Lungo-Koehn]: introduced in state legislatures across the US, over 220 bills specifically targeting transgender and non-binary people, and 45 anti-LGBTQ laws that have been enacted so far this year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the 2022 National Survey on LGBTQ Youth Mental Health by the Trevor Project found that 45% of LGBTQ youth seriously considered suicide in the previous year, and nearly 20% of transgender and non-binary youth attempted suicide.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas data from GLSEN and the Movement Advancement Project found that Massachusetts students' reports indicated a 686% increase in homophobic remarks and 256% increase in transphobic remarks from educators between 2019 and 2021.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas the Trevor, the 2022 survey by the Trevor Project found that nine in 10 LGBTQ plus teens in Massachusetts said political rhetoric weighs on them.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas rates of self-harm are much lower among LGBTQ plus students who feel affirmed in school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas Medford Public Schools stands for the education of physical and mental health of every child, be it resolved, the Medford School Committee reaffirm our support for the rights and dignities of LGBTQ plus youth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it further resolved, the Medford Public Schools will continue to develop and improve its supports for LGBTQ plus youth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: be resolved, the administration will work with the Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Subcommittee of the Medford School Committee to address any policies, procedures, and practices that may need to be created or changed to improve our supports for our LGBTQ plus students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That was submitted on the 31st of May and requested to be on June 5th's agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is there a motion for approval?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I remember McLaughlin seconded by- Second.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham, all those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No reports requested.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Condolences.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee expresses sincere condolences to the family of Rosaline M. Dello Russo, mother of Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Guillen, custodian at the Missittuck, grandmother to Anthony Guillen and Christopher De La Rosa, both teachers at Medford High School, and Christine Hunt, a teacher at McGlynn Elementary School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just want to point out a few things from your comments, because I do think we are planning as best we can on the city side, especially because the school's ESSER funding runs out at least six months prior to ARPA funding.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are plugging the entire gap with the ESSER funds because they need to be spent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They can only have the summer of 2024.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and then they will run out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we do know that we're using about 3 million of outside funding through ESSER for the entire budget, schools, city side.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm talking about it as a collective whole.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why on the city side, we've made very tough choices and we are not using any ARPA funding for revenue loss.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There are, like you said, positions that are being funded through ARPA.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're making sure we don't use, we're not doing

[Lungo-Koehn]: more spending other than that on the ARPA side, because this year we did have new growth of 500,000.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I expect that to hopefully double next year, but you're right.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We wanna keep these positions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're forecasting, we're looking at the numbers, we are trying to collectively take a look at potentially funding a brand new high school with a $200 million debt exclusion ask of our residents

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's a call for street improvement, and there's a call for, obviously, more general fund revenue.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I knew we were in this position.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why when the council proposed an override in August, I agreed that I would approve, I would campaign for, and I would support a $3 million override, which is what you're seeing now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is going to be needed into the future, potentially, maybe a little less, obviously, hopefully with new growth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think we're all on the same boat and understanding that there is additional monies that are going to need to be raised one way or another to support 33 people and about five to 10 to 10 people on the city side, but we do have plans for that we are forecasting I do see potentially an override in, in the future, whether that's November or March.

[Lungo-Koehn]: the ARPA funding does not run out until December 31st, 2024, so it's a little bit different, but we all, including on the city side, wanna do the best we can with contracts, but with that comes the need for more money, and we have been planning accordingly, and I think it can seem dire, but considering that we're doing the forecasting, you have a school committee, a city council, and a mayor that are ready, willing, and able

[Lungo-Koehn]: find the funding one way or another or ask our residents for it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's just something we cannot depend on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why I think a lot of survey work needs to be done in the fall.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What will our residents support so that we can move that forward on a ballot?

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we're doing the hard work and the schools are using the ESSER funding because it runs out and the city side has some for fiscal year 25, but for the second part of fiscal year 25 and fiscal year 26, we will need additional funding if we want to maintain increasing

[Lungo-Koehn]: City services and school services.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that's just a little tidbit but I member Hays I know you wanted to comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We'll go to $350 million, but I'm going to go with $400 million, just to be safe.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, we have no presentations of the public or continued business, but we have a few items under new business, which is number eight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First one is 2023-09 offered by member Hays and member McLaughlin, whereas up-to-date policies prohibiting discrimination, harassment, sexual harassment, and retaliation are fundamental to ensuring a safe and equitable learning environment for Redford Public Schools students and working environment for Redford Public Schools staff

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the Massachusetts Association of School Committees has recently updated their sample policies regarding discrimination, harassment, sexual harassment, and retaliation in order to reflect the most current laws and regulations, clarify language, and add protected classes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it resolved, the Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Subcommittee will meet to review Medford policies AC non-discrimination, Title IX, Chapter 622, ACAB harassment,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and ACABR policy prohibiting sexual harassment and violence.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The subcommittee will consider the following MASC policy updates, AC non-discrimination policy, including harassment and retaliation, ACR non-discrimination policy, including harassment and retaliation, ACA non-discrimination of the basis of sex, ACAB sexual harassment, and JICK harassment of students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Note policy ACE

[Lungo-Koehn]: Non-discrimination of the basis of disability is not included in this resolution as a separate resolution addressing the policy is being written by another school committee member.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is there a motion for approval or would member Hays or member McLaughlin like to speak at all?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by member McLaughlin, seconded by member Hays.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 2023-10 offered by Member Hays and Member McLaughlin, whereas the Medford Public School is committed to ensuring that all students are afforded a safe and healthy learning environment, whereas Title IX legislation is a federal civil rights law enforced by the Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights that provides protections for students and staff by prohibiting sex-based discrimination, including sexual harassment, in programs or activities that receive federal finance

[Lungo-Koehn]: financial assistance from the Department of Education, whereas Title IX requires public schools to take steps to prevent and remedy two forms of sex-based harassment, sexual harassment and gender-based harassment, whereas the Office of Civil Rights requires public schools to disseminate their non-discrimination policy in the Title IX coordinator's contact information to ensure accessible channels of reporting sex-based and gender-based discrimination and harassment

[Lungo-Koehn]: and to notify students, employees, parents, and others of how the school respond to the reports.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the Office of Civil Rights requires public schools to prominently display on their websites the required contact information for the Title IX coordinator, whereas all Title IX training materials must be publicly available, be it resolved that the Medford Public Schools website will be updated to include a page section that provides a full description of the Medford Public Schools

[Lungo-Koehn]: Title IX policies regarding sex-based and gender-based discrimination and harassment, and includes the Title IX coordinator's name, title, email, and phone number, procedures for reporting allegations of harassment and filing a formal complaint, description of the grievance process, and materials from Medford Public Schools Title IX trainings or information about how to access those materials.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For reference, please see the Bedford Public Schools Policy or the Cambridge Public Schools Policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had further resolved the 2023-2024 online parent and student handbooks for each school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We'll provide a summary description of these policies, including the Title IX coordinator's name, title, email, and phone number, and a link to the page with the full policy, printed versions of the handbooks if provided.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We'll also include a summary description of these policies, including the Title IX coordinator's name, title, email, and phone, with instructions about how to obtain a copy of the full policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by Member McLaughlin, seconded by Member Hays.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Offered by Member Hays and Member Bestone, 2023-11.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the mission of the Medford Public Schools is of a caring educational partnership of school, family, and community designed to ensure that all students are afforded a safe and healthy learning environment in which they develop the knowledgeable skills,

[Lungo-Koehn]: the knowledge, skills, and attitudes to reach their full academic and personal potential, whereas the Medford Public Schools hired Michael J. Welch of leadership advisors consulting LLC to provide an evaluation of the culture and climate at Medford High School complex with recommendations for areas of improvement, whereas Mr. Welch's report and presentation to the school committee on 5-1-23 detailed the number of areas of significant concern that warrant additional discussion.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have continued business 2023-01 offered by member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: On April 26, 2021, the school committee voted unanimously to amend policy GAD, permanent staff positions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The amended policy included this language.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All job descriptions were reviewed every three years and presented to the school committee for approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Job descriptions will contain a last reviewed date.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Superintendent will establish a review cycle for all positions descriptions within 60 days of the adoption of the policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The initial review cycle lasts no longer than three years and conclude on September 1st, 2024.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Back to October 21 2021, the comprehensive list of current job descriptions professional staff positions are available for view by the public on the Medford public school website.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Each time a new position is established by the committee, the superintendent will present the committee's approval job description for the position which specifies the job holders qualifications and the jobs performance responsibilities, although such positions may remain

[Lungo-Koehn]: temporarily unfilled, only the committee may abolish position it has created.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All positions unfilled for the entire prior school year will be reported to the committee annually no later than June 1st with an explanation for the vacancy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All positions that remain unfilled for more than two consecutive school years will be presented to the committee to be abolished no later than June 1st.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event the superintendent wishes to maintain any positions that have been unfilled for more than two consecutive school years, the superintendent must explain the rationale and plan to fill the position

[Lungo-Koehn]: and get approved from the committee to continue the unfilled position for an additional year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be resolved that the superintendent provide an update and timeline to comply with the September, 2024 completion of the initial view cycle here in member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sorry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Offered by Member Graham, 2023-02, whereas the Medford School Committee heard a presentation from the Andrews Middle School Global Scholars Program.

[Lungo-Koehn]: on June 6, 2022, regarding the results of their composting pilot, including an annual cost to the Andrews School of $720, whereas the school committee unanimously voted to ask the administration to investigate the cost of composting district-wide for possible implementation in school year 2022-2023 via resolve that the administration provide an update on composting efforts in Medford Public Schools this year and plans for the upcoming 2023-2024 school year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Grant.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if I may, through the chair, I met with the chair of the Energy and Environment Committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I believe it was maybe Thursday or Friday, and they have five goals.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And one is to learn more from students and get more active in the school system.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So maybe your daughter can go to the committee, one of their meetings.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think they're on Monday nights.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But they are looking to interact more with students and try to get more involved.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And they could be a huge asset to trying to get composting in our schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I will also talk to Director Hunt.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And on the city side, we're working on, we have a task force in place, because we're doing a new RFP for recycling, composting, and trash pickup in the city, as we want to encourage more composting and recycling versus trash.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we'll see if they have anything in mind for the schools as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Update from the school system.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yep.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Presentations of the public, we do not have any presentations of the public or continued business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do have two items under new business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First, 2023-06 offered by member Hays and member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the Met for Public Schools is committed to understanding the needs of our diverse population and supporting the academic, social, emotional, physical needs of our students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the Trevor's Project 2022 National Survey on LGBTQ plus youth mental health found

[Lungo-Koehn]: that 45% of LGBTQ plus youth ages 13 to 24 seriously considered attempted suicide in the previous year, and 14% of LGBTQ youth and nearly 20% of transgender and non-binary youth actually attempted suicide.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the 2019 Massachusetts Youth Risk Behavior Survey found that compared with heterosexual side gender youth, LGBTQ plus youth were twice as likely to be bullied at school

[Lungo-Koehn]: four times more likely to attempt suicide and significantly more likely to skip school because they felt unsafe.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the Trevor Project found that LGBTQ plus youth who found their school to be LGBTQ plus affirming reported lower rates of attempting suicide.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the 2019 Massachusetts Youth Risk Behavior Survey found that social support from adults is associated with lower risk among LGBTQ plus youth for adverse experiences

[Lungo-Koehn]: such as skipping school, being bullied at school, being bullied electronically, considering suicide and attempting suicide, be it resolved that the Subcommittee on Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion meet to review guidance on policies and supports for LGBTQ plus students from the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education, the Massachusetts Commission on LGBTQ Youth, the Trevor Project, the NGLSEN,

[Lungo-Koehn]: as well as policies and supports implemented in surrounding school districts to consider policies to recommend to the entire committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dates submitted March 30th, 2023 for this week's agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Pass it off to Member Hays.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to approve.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you for putting this on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Hays, Member McLaughlin, motion to approve by Member Graham, seconded by Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also under new business offered by Member Hays and Member McLaughlin, 2023-07, whereas the Medford Public School recognizes, respects, and celebrates the diversity among our students and staff, including diversity of gender identity and gender expression,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education states that schools should be sure that your handbooks and other school documents are updated to reflect the amended laws.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Note that the gender identity law explicitly states that gender identity should appear directly after sex in enumerated categories.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Therefore be it resolved the 2023-2024 parent and student handbooks of the metropolitan public schools will be updated with the following.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas pronouns are used, gender neutral they there,

[Lungo-Koehn]: or gender inclusive, she, he, they, her, his, their pronouns will be used.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Alternatively, the specific group name may be used in place of the pronouns, student, teacher, staff member, parent, principal, et cetera.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number two, whereas enumerated categories are used, gender identity will appear directly after sex and gender expression will be added to the protected categories.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Submitted on the 30th of March for today's meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Hays, Member McLaughlin, or a motion for approval?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by Member McLaughlin, seconded by?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I
