[Lungo-Koehn]: So, charter review is very difficult to understand, so we brought it down to grade level terms, so everybody would be able, and that's actually how I understand it best anyway, so everybody will be able to understand what that means, what changes we could possibly make, how to make those changes, although it takes

[Lungo-Koehn]: Some great deal of time, but we are we're doing all we can to get resident involvement and make sure everybody understands the process Thank you very much Okay So

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll just speak briefly on this, on the city side, um, because fire police, um, city hall was mentioned as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Um, and I think it just piggyback on Dr. Edouard-Vincent, you have to be intentional about wanting to diversify your workforce.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's what we are doing on the city side.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Um, I think over six months span, 25% of our, um, new employees were of diverse backgrounds and we're, we've made great progress on the police side.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have far more females than ever.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have far more,

[Lungo-Koehn]: employees that speak a second language.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's really important to us to the point where the chief of police, myself, and our diversity equity inclusion director.

[Lungo-Koehn]: two years ago, petitioned civil service to ask that bilingual candidates be moved up on the list after veterans.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That became a big hoopla, if you remember, but I wasn't afraid to do it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need to diversify our workforce.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have some work to do on the fire side, but we've only hired once since I've been mayor, and I made sure that there was diverse candidates that moved forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'd like to give the example, and I gave it last week in front of the students at Medford High School, when you talk intentional,

[Lungo-Koehn]: The best candidates obviously have to get the job but we had a situation in the city for City Hall employee and it was a Medford resident who I happen to know versus a candidate from another city who was bilingual and who did we pick?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Person from another community that was bilingual because we want City Hall and our entire workforce in the city and schools to represent the people that we serve.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number six is report on Medford Public Schools budget process for fiscal year 24.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Marice Edouard-Vincent, superintendent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So good evening.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm going to be presenting

[Lungo-Koehn]: Last year was a tough time because we didn't have CFO for many months, 11 months to be exact.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Currently we have a full-time CFO and a new budget director working diligently on the city budget and forecasting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we should have a number of schools within the next several weeks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's very good news.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Good news for now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The last two years, three years, we've cut from the stabilized, tried to go even on the city side so that we could give it the most we could to the schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Obviously there comes a breaking point.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think we're somewhat at that, but we'll do our best to give as much of an increase as we can.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we have this year and next year that we are able to use

[Lungo-Koehn]: funding to plug any gaps.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Last year we used about $7 million.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It needs to be decreased.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then eventually after there's no more opera money, that's when we have to, we're already doing forecasting to project what, if any, of an override we would need.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If I recall how we handled it last time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number two, second reading.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Recommendation from the strategic planning subcommittee meeting held Thursday, February 9th, 2023.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham, Chair, Member Hays, Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Proposed policy for dedication and naming of school committee buildings, facilities, and grounds.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee has sole authority over the naming or renaming of buildings, interior facilities, and grounds in the public schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee recognizes that the names of school facilities must be undertaken with care and scrutiny.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This policy is intended to ensure that names and or other wording associated with school facilities will promote and or be consistent with the goals of the Met for Public Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The naming process should include student, family, community, and staff voices.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Bless you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When naming a school facility, preference is given to those persons, organizations, and events which had a substantial impact on the education of Medford students, persons or events that reflect the increasing diversity of Medford students' population,

[Lungo-Koehn]: This guidance shall not preclude consideration of names or persons of local, state, national, or international significance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Names of persons employed by the school or city at the time of dedication shall not be considered.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee reserves the right to remove a name at any time if it is in the best interest of the district or donor to do so, or to protect the reputation of the district and or the donor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In order for a building facility grounds to be named that is accompanied by a financial contribution, the following procedure shall be followed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A written request is placed on the regular school committee agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The item should specifically specify the intent of the requester and the details of the intended financial contribution.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It should offer appropriate background information and the person or organization in the request.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee will consider the request and invite public input at least two consecutive meetings before a vote to approve or deny the request is taken.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A gift agreement between the donor and the school committee must be approved simultaneously as the name is voted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The standard agreement must specify the building interior facility or grounds to be named, the duration of the naming period, as well as payment terms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These agreements will be considered for the public record, kept on file by the school committee for access by the public.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In order for a building facility grounds to be named that is not accompanied by a financial contribution, the following procedure shall be followed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee shall pass a resolution identifying building facility or

[Lungo-Koehn]: school grounds to be named.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee shall establish a naming advisory committee pursuant to policy BDF advisory committee to the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The naming advisory committee shall adhere to the charge established in forming the committee, including public participation, timelines, and other criteria.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee shall receive recommendations from the naming advisory committee at a regular school committee meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee shall by majority vote adopt a name

[Lungo-Koehn]: While the school committee is not required to accept the recommendations of the naming advisory committee, it looks forward to supporting those recommendations whenever possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In order for a classroom or space within a school building to be named, the following procedure shall be followed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A written request is placed in the school committee agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The item should specify the intent of the requester and the reasons why this particular name would fit with the space.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It should offer appropriate background information on the person or organization in the request.

[Lungo-Koehn]: School committee will consider the request and invite public input at two consecutive meetings before a vote to approve or deny the request is taken.

[Lungo-Koehn]: School committee may choose to send the request to a naming advisory committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In order for a community giving program where donors will be invited to give to a project in exchange for physical dedication, the following procedures shall be followed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The program rules and required donation levels will be placed in a regular school committee agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The item should describe the program placement of

[Lungo-Koehn]: the physical dedications, donor levels, and other rules.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee will consider the request and invite public input.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee may make a decision at any time, provided that public input was received before the vote of approval or denial.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval of second reading, as amended, this will go into effect July 1, 2023, by Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if I may, from the chair, I've got some people speaking out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think member Kreatz had mentioned this last meeting, just very concerned about the process that we went through before and just creating more division in the community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I know member Graham, one of the big things about this is

[Lungo-Koehn]: all the work that's being done by you, the committee, Dr. Cushing, a whole host of people on the McGlynn playground, rehabilitation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we are gonna be looking for donors and I believe that would be prior to July 1st, 2023.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I too think that we should be getting the donors in many different ways for that project.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's gonna be wonderful, but expensive and we'd like to be able to implement this policy to see that happen.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't know if member Ruseau has this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We'll withdraw his motion, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So motion for approval by member Graham, seconded by member Hays.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Paper passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: New business offered by member Hays, McLaughlin, and Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Stone, whereas the Medford School Committee values the thoughts, concerns, ideas, and experiences of the students who attend our schools,

[Lungo-Koehn]: be resolved the school committee will seek to encourage student participation in regular school committee meetings through the addition of an agenda item to every regular meeting agenda titled presentations of students with the following description.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Presentation of students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Regular meetings of the Medford school committee include this presentation of students agenda item to give any Medford public school student the opportunity to place a presentation before the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Student may only present once at any meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These presentations are an opportunity for students to make a presentation to the committee, but are not opportunities for dialogue with the committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: one or more members of the committee wishes to have a conversation about the topic, a member may request that the item be added to the regular school committee meeting, the next regular school committee meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The details for submitting a presentation can be found within the policy, pursuant to policy BEDH, public comment and presentations to the public.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Any resident in the audience may be given permission to speak once on any agenda item for up to three minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The speaker is expected to keep their comments to the item on the agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The speaker must begin their comments by providing their full name and full Medford Street address where they reside.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A welcoming, inclusive community is both a value of the Medford School Committee and an aspirational goal.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We ask for your help in achieving this goal and value your perspective.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by Member Hays.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seconded by Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have number 10 condolences.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford school committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of former city Councilor, Robert L Maloney, senior father of athletic director, Bob Maloney,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilor Maloney served the city for over 25 years, as well as being an active member of the Medford Kiwanis Club, the Irish American Club, and the Medford Elks Club.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Rosetta DeVita, aunt of city councilor and former school committee member, George Scarpelli, and Lisa Charay, a teacher at the Roberts Elementary School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Paul Howard,

[Lungo-Koehn]: owner of Jim's Market in North Medford and a former Providence College D1 basketball player, United States Army veteran and longtime supporter of the Medford community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Often, Mr. Howard could be found playing basketball with the kids at Carr Park well into his 50s.

[Lungo-Koehn]: During the blizzard of 78, Mr. Howard made sure the elderly residents around Jim's Market had food items until they could get to the supermarket.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number five, reporter of the superintendent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First up, we have our superintendent's updates and comments, Dr. Marice Edouard-Vincent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Good evening.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Dr. Edward-Vincent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Can I ask a question?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have recommendation to approve travel to University of North Carolina UNC for the ethics team to compete at the Ethics Bowl National Competition.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Eric Eisner, English language arts teacher.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Welcome.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Good evening, everyone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have presentations of the public not to begin before seven.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Regular meetings of the school committee include this presentation of the public agenda item to give opportunity to place a presentation before the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A resident may only present once at any meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These presentations are an opportunity for the public to make a presentation to the committee, but are not opportunities for dialogue.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If one or more members of the committee wishes to have a conversation about the topic presented, a member may request that the item be added to a subsequent regular meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The details for submitting a presentation can be found within the policy BEDH, public comment and presentations to the public.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Pursuant to that policy, public comment and presentation to the public, any resident in the audience may give

[Lungo-Koehn]: be given permission to speak for up to three minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The speaker is expected to keep their comments to the item on the agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The speaker must begin their comments by providing their full name and Medford Street address where they reside.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A welcoming, inclusive committee is both the value of the school committee and an aspirational goal.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We ask for your help in achieving this goal and value your perspective.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Employees in Medford Public Schools are exempt from this residency requirement of this policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The voice of our employees is welcome on all matters before the body.

[Lungo-Koehn]: when a non-Metro resident employee is participating in public comment or submitting a presentation to the public, they will include their home address and identify themselves as an employee of the Metro Public Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With that being said, Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Continued business is tabled.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now onto new business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First reading recommendation, which we spoke about earlier in the meeting minutes of the strategic planning subcommittee held on February 9th, 2023.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham chaired.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Hays is a member.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau is a member.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Proposed policy for dedication and naming of school buildings, facilities, and grounds.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee has sole authority over the naming or renaming of buildings, interior facilities, and grounds of the Medford Public Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee recognizes that the names of school facilities must be undertaken with care and scrutiny.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This policy is intended to ensure that names and or other wording associated with school facilities will promote and or be consistent with the goals of the Medford Public Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The naming process should include family, student,

[Lungo-Koehn]: family, community, and staff voices when naming a school facility, preferences to be given to those persons, organizations, and events which had a substantial impact on the education of Medford students, persons or events that reflect the increasing diversity of Medford student population.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This guidance shall not preclude consideration of names, persons of local, state, national, or international significance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Names of persons employed by the school or city at the time of the dedication shall not be considered.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee reserves the right to remove a name at any time if it is in the best interest of the district or donor to do so, or to protect the reputation of the district and or donor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In order for the building facility grounds to be named that is accompanied by a financial contribution, the following procedure shall be followed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A written request is placed on a regular school committee meeting agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The item should specify the intent of the requester and the details of the intended financial contribution.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It should offer

[Lungo-Koehn]: appropriate background information on the person or organization in the request.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee will consider the request and invite public input at least two consecutive meetings before a vote to approve or deny the request is taken.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A gift agreement between the donor and the school committee must be approved simultaneously as the name is voted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The standard agreement must specify the building interior facility or grounds to be named, the duration of the naming period, as well as payment terms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These agreements will be considered for the public record and

[Lungo-Koehn]: keep on file by the school committee for access by the public.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In order for a building facility grounds to be named, by a financial contribution, the following procedure shall be followed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee shall pass a resolution identifying the building facility or school grounds to be named.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee shall establish a naming advisory committee pursuant to policy BDF advisory committee to the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The naming advisory committee shall adhere to this charge established in forming the committee

[Lungo-Koehn]: including public participation timeline and other criteria.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee shall receive recommendations from the naming advisory committee at a regular school committee meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee shall by majority vote, adopt a name by the school committee is not required to accept the recommendations of the naming advisory committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It looks forward to supporting those recommendations whenever possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In order for a classroom or space within a school,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sorry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: School committee by, where did I lose my train of thought?

[Lungo-Koehn]: School committee shall, by a majority vote, adopt a name.

[Lungo-Koehn]: While the school committee is not required to adopt the recognition of the name of some committee, it looks forward to supporting those recommendations whenever possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In order for a classroom or space within a school building to be named, the following procedure shall be followed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A written request is placed on a regular school committee meeting agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The item should specify the intent of the requester and the reasons why this particular name would fit with the space.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It should offer appropriate background information to the person or organization in the request.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee will consider the request and invite public input at two executive meetings before a vote to approve or deny the requests taken.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee may choose to send the request to a naming advisory committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In order for a community giving program where donors will be invited to give to a project in exchange for a physical dedication brick with donor names, the following procedures shall be followed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The program rules

[Lungo-Koehn]: and required donation levels will be placed in a school committee agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The item shall, should describe the program placement of physical dedications, donor levels, and other rules.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee will consider the request and invite public input.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee may make a decision at any time provided the public input was received before the vote of approval or denial.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sure, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Second.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to approve the first reading by Member McLaughlin, seconded by Member Mustone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: approved as amended.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sorry, as amended.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, all those in favor as amended.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Any opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yep, and I'll just add, I mean, the morning commute from three to nine is when we're expecting the most snow.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're only gonna see two to four, but it is gonna be during the commute.

[Lungo-Koehn]: City Hall will be closed till 10 a.m., and as Dr. Edouard-Vincent said, the schools will be closed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We don't have a delayed start option due to the MBTA, so I'm making that decision.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We'll try to run the school committee meeting and make those decisions as we work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That was a reward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Keep everybody in suspense, because we want to be thoughtful and we want to make sure we're following the weather, because weather does tend to change.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If it changes from now until 7 in the morning, we make our best decisions, but we get held accountable either way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Last, we have three condolences that I'd like to read.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Meeting is, all those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Meeting is adjourned.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I see superintendent evaluation rubric regarding standard one to make instruction indicator and data informed decision making indicator.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The standard one measures motion to from the mass dusty superintendent evaluation rubric regarding standard to management and operations to make the environment indicator and the standard to measure motion three from the mass dusty superintendent evaluation rubric regarding standard three family and community engagement

[Lungo-Koehn]: to make the engagement indicator, 3A, sharing responsibility indicator, 3B, and communication indicator, 3C, the standard three measures.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion four from the DESE superintendent evaluation rubric regarding professional culture, to make commitment to high school standards indicator, 4A, cultural proficiency indicator, 4B, managing conflict indicator, 4F, the standard four measures.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion five, the committee will use the words exemplary, proficient, needs improvement and unsatisfactory in the superintendent's evaluation for each measure being evaluated.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion six, the superintendent's evaluation will include the raw data from all members in addition to the summary evaluation of the subcommittee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion seven, the school committee will create a new standing subcommittee, the evaluation subcommittee with three members for compilation

[Lungo-Koehn]: of the notes and evaluations of individual members and provide a recommendation to the full committee at evaluation time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion eight, members Graham, Hayes, and McLaughlin will be assigned to the evaluation subcommittee with member Hays as the chairperson.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My check one, two, my check one, two, one, two.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Good evening, everybody.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Feel free to have a seat.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're going to get started somewhat on time because we want everybody to get home safe with the weather.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we're trying to keep the program to less than an hour.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So thanks for everybody for being here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First up, I want to announce that we have a very special guest to start us off tonight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have our first ever Poet Laureate, Terry Carter, who's going to read us a poem.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Terry is a published author of five books.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Currently writing his sixth, which will go to print very soon.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He's a huge asset to every part of our community, the schools, the West Medford Community Center, and the community as a whole with his poetry and so much more.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So without further ado, Terry Carter.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you so much.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First, I wanna start by thanking Steve.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I wanna start by thanking Steve Smerity, the director of communications and Emma Tombley for helping me write this speech you're gonna hear tonight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think Steve and I had a tougher job the last week cutting it down from 25 pages to nine.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So you can thank me for that later, but there's so much that has been accomplished in this city that I wanna speak about.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'm gonna do that tonight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'm not gonna rush, usually I rush, I feel so bad, I'm long-winded, but I'm not gonna rush because this work that everybody's doing on a daily basis is worth taking my time for.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And just before I start, please know that just because something's written on a sign doesn't mean it's true.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'm sorry that the horns are beeping.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'm sorry to Terry, but the horns were beeping.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you for those joining us here tonight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, if you're watching from home or on Zoom, I do know that we have many elected officials here, Representative Donato, School Committee woman, Kathy Kreatz, Member Ruseau, and City Councilor Rick Caravielloa, and Member Hays.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And former member, Paulette Van der Kloots.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you for joining us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you to Terry Carter, our poet laureate, member Jenny Graham, and President Nicole Morell for kicking off the event.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Before I begin, I must thank the tireless work of our department heads, city staff, and volunteers who have committed to doing amazing things under the difficult and ongoing conditions caused by the pandemic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You're all integral to the success that I will be highlighting here tonight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You're the reason why we're here tonight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I stood before you last January and outlined my vision for Medford, listing many long-term goals, including numerous projects that are currently underway, and laid out our roadmap for the next two years and beyond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now, as we begin this fourth year of growth and progress, I want to give an update on how things are going, what challenges lie ahead, and how we continue to deliver on the promises we made, the vision we shared, and the future we've imagined.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Walking through the city, visiting places I frequented as a child, young adult, and city councilor, what struck me in many instances was how infrequently some places change.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A community that does not grow does not thrive.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And here in Medford, because we have done the planning the last three years, we now are about to see growth mode.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've been able to make this transition and kickstart our economic engine because of a key goal,

[Lungo-Koehn]: tapping into the unrealized potential of our squares, our green spaces, and our city-owned properties.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The most obvious opportunity to begin our next generation of development is at Wellington Station.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The untapped 28 acres of land has been in city control for over half a century.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since 1969, and in our community was completely missing out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: not only on the potential revenue streams, but also the exciting opportunities that could be realized with diverse transit oriented mixed use development designed to attract new families, workers, and students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since we issued the request for information in September, we have spent the past few months reviewing proposals from eight highly qualified developers and released those to the public earlier this month.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Each plan had a unique vision

[Lungo-Koehn]: for the area's potential and suggested bringing much needed housing options and other mixed use features, such as retail, office, hospitality, and green space.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We will take you through these proposals and use them to help inform a future RFP in 2023 that fits the needs of our community and brings about generational change to the Wellington area.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In addition to Wellington, we're also attempting to reimagine a few underused city-owned lots in Medford Square.

[Lungo-Koehn]: with the help of the Metropolitan Area Planning Council working to develop priorities and criteria for future redevelopment through a community-driven analysis and visioning process that will incorporate the needs of residents and stakeholders.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We will finally see progress on this project in the coming year and get out an RFP for Medford Square in 2023.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have an opportunity with these lots to implement smart resident-focused development that aligns with our community's priorities and vision.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we do this the right way, it will benefit our downtown square by creating a more sustainable and accessible future for the area.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But as I said, we can't do this in a silo.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We must engage and work with our seniors in the neighborhood, our local small businesses, Chevalier Theater, and residents to access their needs, assess their needs, and implement a strategy that recognizes their importance to building a more vibrant and thriving downtown area.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One of the three 40B projects we are negotiating on Mystic Ave has been a topic that has garnered much debate, controversy, and discussion over the years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's an opportunity for meaningful, lasting development on this strip that we can't afford to miss.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Director Alicia Hunt, Economic Development Director Victor Schrader, now part-time, and I would not settle for thousands of luxury apartments at this site.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and have been working with the developer on a different vision, one that can bring innovation and lasting possibilities to Mystic Avenue, a $1 billion life science development equipped with open space and first floor retail.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As we look to strengthen our commercial corridors, we must not lose sight of ensuring that people who will use these new developments also have the ability to continue to live in our city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's no secret that there's a housing crunch in the region,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Cities across the Commonwealth are feeling the pressure to create lasting solutions to this problem and Medford is no different.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our city, however, is finding solutions that will bring more housing, especially affordable housing to Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We'll have a comprehensive master plan, which is being released very soon, will help guide our housing policy in the future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We currently have two other 40B projects that my administration is negotiating and working on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We worked with the developers on the project on Mystic Valley Parkway to resubmit plans to the Zoning Board of Appeals that includes 350 units, 25% of which are affordable housing units.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're committed to using ARPA funds to support and assist with affordable housing projects, like the ones at our Housing Authority complexes at 121 Riverside Ave and Walkland Court.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've allocated 400,000 to help offset permitting costs of renovations, thanks to the help of Bill 40,

[Lungo-Koehn]: for upgrades and renovations to new affordable units at 121 Riverside Ave just this past week.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Using existing funding sources like ARPA are helpful and allow us to make immediate expenditures to ease the burden on partners, but we're doing so knowing that we need a long-term plan for additional revenue sources.

[Lungo-Koehn]: ARPA will end in 2025 and we don't want our partners left holding the bag.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why establishing affordable housing trust is so important

[Lungo-Koehn]: and will help allow us to fund new projects in the absence of ARPA.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've done the work, communicated with stakeholders, and are ready to move forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The next step in the process is working with the council, who I know is supportive and understands the value of the trust.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those are just a few of the over 30 development investments we are working on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A special thanks again to our planning team led by Director Hunt and our now part-time economic development administrator.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thanks to the work of our police chief, Jack Buckley, Medford PD is setting an example for how to operate as a diverse professional police force that continually engages with the community, builds new lasting partnerships and promotes inclusion and empathy with the way each of our officers conduct themselves.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aiding in that mission is the remarkable facility that the MPD calls home.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I have made it a priority to see that the fire department has a headquarters that is just as dynamic

[Lungo-Koehn]: and meets the current needs of our firefighters and emergency personnel.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, one of the ongoing initiatives that has been moving forward over the past year is upgrades to all six of our stations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have already spent over $1.3 million on over 20 projects to upgrade each of our stations, including lighting projects in each substation, roof repairs or replacements, kitchen upgrades, and one final one to go.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we will continue to ensure these

[Lungo-Koehn]: are the best working environments to keep Medford safe.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since day one, bringing our fire stations up to the standards of the 21st century department have been a priority of mine and my chief of staff, Nina Nazarian and chief John Friedman have been working tirelessly to get an owner's project manager hired and an architect contract signed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are happy to announce that we do have an owner's project manager that we have hired and are very close to signing a contract with an architect firm

[Lungo-Koehn]: for the design of the fire head quarter building.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A special thank you to Medford residents, Luke McNeely and Paul Holian Jr.

[Lungo-Koehn]: who have also done a lot of work, a lot of reading as it relates to this project.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please know that these things take time, but there is a committed group pushing these projects as fast as they can with me nagging them every step of the way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In addition to the efforts underway for the fire headquarters, our fire substation, engine three on Salem Street, is going to have the garage floors replaced this year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thanks to the work of this team, as well as the dedicated help of our chief officer, Fiona Maxwell, and her team, and available community block grant funding, we can move forward on this project exponentially.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Finally, this year, we'll begin IT work of over 500,000 and are designing window repairs or replacements at all the substations too.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's an additional over $2.2 million investment in new projects at the fire stations with a potential over $20 million bond after that for the headquarters.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And in order to help fund these infrastructure improvements, I spent months negotiating to have cannabis dispensaries in Medford that would benefit our community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our terms were eventually met and in addition to receiving the maximum 3% gross revenue coming back to the city,

[Lungo-Koehn]: which will be used towards roads and sidewalks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We were also able to secure funding for our library, fire stations, DPW vehicles, cruisers for the police department, local nonprofit aid, veteran aid, and so much more.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With all of these new projects coming online and countless more already completed, it's critical that we have sufficient transportation infrastructure in place to handle the demand and allow people to get to move about the city safely.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why we commissioned a street and sidewalk infrastructure assessment early in my first term and showed the city, and the city has 200 million in backlog of road and sidewalk work that needs to be fixed due to the decades of neglect.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is a huge task, and although the city does not have the funding or capacity to complete this work in a year or two, we are not shying away from planning and implementation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have been diligently working to complete our most critical roadways.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the past few months,

[Lungo-Koehn]: With the help of our city engineer, Owen Hortella, we outlined a pavement strategy for Freedom Way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The road was in dire need of repair and was used regularly to access schools and city facilities.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm happy to report that we have done the initial repaving with plans in place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Owen, there's more work to do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For a complete road rebuild in about two years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've made a significant investment in upgrades to our sidewalks as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This past year, we bonded a million dollars and we'll be going to the city council for an additional bond of 1.5 million that will include equipment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So even more work can be done in-house by our DPW team.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you to treasurer Judy Johnson for always helping us whenever we need her, when it relates to bonds.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've also identified more cost-friendly options for some road repair.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Recently, 94 streets were identified in our assessment as prime candidates for a process called crack sailing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Over 30 streets have been completed with roughly 60 more to finish this spring.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are also working on a comprehensive patchwork plan that will be finalized and released to further repair our roads.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Engineering and our Department of Public Works Commissioner Tim McGivern have been instrumental in this planning.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With an eye on maintaining and improving the structural integrity of our streets and sidewalks, we've made tree stump removal and tree planting a priority.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Working with our tree warden, Aggie Tudin, over the past year, we've secured over a half million dollars in funding for this work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we'll continue to invest our resources towards this over the course of the year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I want to thank our state delegation, Rep Donato, Rep Garbally, Rep Barber, for providing some of that funding for this project and many, many others.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As we upgrade infrastructure, we additionally want to continue investing in our local businesses that are so important to the fabric of community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A few weeks ago, the city awarded $75,000 to 23 local businesses for storefront improvements.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With this second round of funding completed, we have awarded over 100,000 through small business facade improvement grants.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I spoke about revitalizing Medford Square in my inauguration speech last year, and I'm proud to say we are working towards that goal with programs like this

[Lungo-Koehn]: that inject funding and create opportunity for local businesses to thrive.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I can't mention local services without mentioning directors, Pam Kelly, Kevin Bailey, and Barbara Kerr, who have done an excellent job running our senior center, recreation department, and library through the last few years of the pandemic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And of course, without the leadership and expertise of our board of health director, Marianne O'Connor, and the staff in the health department, we would not have been able to navigate our way through the early days of the pandemic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Marianne and the team, including Board of Health Nurse Sarah Harris, provided clarity and calm during a truly chaotic and scary situation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So thank you to all, including our volunteers who helped administer over 2,800 COVID vaccines and 600 flu vaccines just in 2022, including close to 190 homebound vaccinations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Vaccines were administered throughout the city with the help of our community liaisons.

[Lungo-Koehn]: who connect the community to city resources and expand communications and accessibility to our non-native English speakers in Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Expanding opportunities to showcase Medford's growing diversity and culture offerings has been a key part of our development strategy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our parks and recreation spaces have also been upgraded with new murals.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And just today I was at Wright's Pond working on the next with a local artist and Kevin Bailey.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Chevalier Theater additionally renewed a five-year contract with the city back in September, bringing world-class entertainment to our hidden gem for years to come.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have signed a contract with a cannabis dispensary company, Theory Wellness, to construct our first-ever art center on Mystic Ave.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They have broken ground, and we cannot wait to see this become a reality.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford's waterfront will also become a new place for residents to enjoy, with plans in the works to create more recreation areas and beautify the area

[Lungo-Koehn]: with murals and other art from the community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We hope to release the initial design for community feedback late this winter.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our city services and facilities are not the only community driven spaces that deserve our investments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've also been able to prioritize our local nonprofits that have been instrumental to providing critical services and resources to our community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In addition to CDBG funding, we awarded over 230,000 to 25 nonprofits through the

[Lungo-Koehn]: Community Fund Committee earlier this month.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Included in this round of funding was the American Legion, Temple Shalom, the Medford Chamber of Commerce, and all four of our elementary PTOs, just to name a few.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We expect to open up the second round of funding of grants later this year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've talked a lot now about our progress and excitement for future projects, but we have also been met with some challenges this year, especially in our high school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our schools, especially the high school, have needed

[Lungo-Koehn]: to make change to better address the growing issues stemming from the pandemic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I've spent, thankfully spent a lot of time over the last month with our superintendent, Dr. Maurice-Edouard-Vincent, as well as other district leaders, pushing for plans that are sustainable, adaptable, and work in the best interest of students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have two newly trained student resource offices, a revised bathroom plan, and are engaging with students on a much more personal level.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But most importantly, we have heard the students' concerns and listened to their lived experiences.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We must strengthen our relationships and trust with both the students and caregivers and ensure that our school system is safe and an inviting place for all.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As Jenny stated, we're still looking to obtain an MSBA loan to build a new high school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The building we have now is not amenable to quality education, and we believe we have a strong case for the next round of loans due in April to rebuild a state-of-the-art flagship school that our students and faculty deserve.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I thank the school committee, the superintendent of schools, Dr. Marice Edouard-Vincent and Mr. Dave Murphy for all their work on that application and we will be resubmitting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As our community continues to grow as a destination for families and professionals, there is a significant opportunity to expand accessible and efficient public transportation options.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As I'm sure you've all seen and hopefully written, the Green Line Extension finally opened in December after many challenges, delays and questions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That was probably the happiest I've seen people at 5 a.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: on a Monday morning cramming in line to get a spot on the T. That just proves that the extension is a turning point for Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I want to thank the community group that advocated and worked on this project for years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I will never stop pushing for better public transportation in and around our community as I did with the MBTA new better bus redesign and the closure of the orange line over the summer.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I thank director Todd

[Lungo-Koehn]: director of traffic and transportation, Todd Blake, for being the expert this city needs, advocating with us, working with us, and advising us along the way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With his help and many others, we've also increased the scope of blue bikes around the city this year with three new docking stations at Tufts Square, Brooks Park, and Medford Square.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are working to expand this network further as alternative green transportation options support our climate action and adaptation plan, including efforts to provide residents with clean, sustainable, and affordable alternatives.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm happy to announce that we have secured funding for seven additional Blue Bike locations, with the next three coming online later this year at Hormel Stadium, Harris Park, and Spring Street.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For the four remaining, we're tentatively exploring Riverbend Park, Haines Square, West Medford, and the Hillside.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As outlined in our Climate Action and Adaptation Plan, we have lofty goals of reducing our emissions by 50% by the end of this decade and have been working to achieve net zero emissions by 2050.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To do this, we've taken a series of steps aimed at making our city operations, facilities, and policies more conducive and adaptable to climate resiliency.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The last time I spoke at this podium to you all, I mentioned that we were in the process of securing funding for two additional electric charging stations with the hope of installation this year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thanks to the work of the Planning, Development and Sustainability Office, especially the work of Planner Yvette Niwa, we've delivered on the promise and have two new stations, one at Hormel and one at Carr Park.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'm happy to announce that we're expanding on that growth with two more, one at the Missittuck School and one at Tufts Park, coming online this summer with an additional seven being planned over the next year or so.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But to implement real changes in the way we conduct our operations, we must commit to reversing our reliance on fossil fuels internally as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is also a priority of our city council and school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm happy to announce that we have secured $230,000 grant Diesel Emissions Reduction Act from the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act from the state with the help of Mike Wentzel from DPW to assist with the purchasing of an all electric commercial grade sweeper, which will replace our diesel engine vehicle.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also made concerted efforts to transition our other vehicles in our fleet to more green friendly options.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The police department has purchased new hybrid vehicles and is patiently waiting for their arrival, hopefully in June, which will make their daily operations much more efficient, cleaner, and adaptable to challenges.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also thank director Faye Morrison, who will also be transitioning her fleet in the near future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The city is additionally enhancing its climate resiliency and emergency preparedness efforts through our MedFit Connects program led by our office of prevention and outreach manager,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Penny Fanioli.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This program seeks to expand and strengthen resources for our underserved community members.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we recently secured a grant, another grant for over 400,000 from the state to accomplish this work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: An important part, I'm almost done, I'm sorry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: An important part of our commitment to expanding resources and programming for residents is our investment in our green spaces.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford's many parks are a source of pride for the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and we have plans for upgrading the construction in many of them, close to 50, actually.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I engaged an internal team who have been meeting close to monthly for three years to plan, gain community input and secure funding.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In projects scheduled to start this spring and summer alone, we have secured over $5 million for renovations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One of our largest upcoming projects is Carr Park.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Carr Park's vision plan was released the end of 21,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and we are proud to say that phase one is fully funded and in design and expected to start this spring.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Carr Park recently secured additional funding for phase two, which is on the horizon as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In phase two, we can get excited for new basketball courts, one which will be covered by solar panels, a new playground and much more.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Car's solar infrastructure will be funded by $1.5 million earmark in the federal 2023 budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I wanna thank our federal delegation, including Congresswoman Clark, Senator Markey, Senator Warren, for their work in passing this budget and helping fund community projects here in Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our planning office has been instrumental in this work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thanks to their work, especially again, Director Hunt and Planner Amanda Centrella, we have not only secured opera funding, but a match of $1 million from another grant from the Land and Water Conservation Fund for phase one.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Awesome job.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Upper funds have made a huge impact on our community in the work we are able to do throughout the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Unlike other communities that set specific funding amounts for various sectors, Medford has taken a needs-based approach, allowing us to invest funding where it is needed most.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The data we collected from the community focus survey released this past summer helped inform many of the projects I've mentioned already tonight, with many others that I don't have time for.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With the help of our amazing federal funds manager, Lorena Escalero,

[Lungo-Koehn]: We will be continuing to invest in areas like affordable housing, public health and infrastructure, as well as plan for the future while being transparent with the work we're doing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Throughout our opera planning process, we have been open and transparent about our financial outlook and the need to allocate a percentage of funding to revenue replacement.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Like many other cities and towns in the Commonwealth, the economic effects of the pandemic left a sizable gap in several revenue streams that we traditionally have counted on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For the past two years,

[Lungo-Koehn]: the years we have reduced our reliance on ARPA dollars and expect the trend to continue in fiscal year 24 and 25.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's no secret that the city has incurred a structural deficit.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And though we have several dynamic development opportunities on the horizon that will inject revenue into our bottom line, thanks to our assessing team, especially, I see Jim O'Brien and Ellen as well have been great.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are analyzing the potential need to come to a solution as to how to fill and address the gap.

[Lungo-Koehn]: especially when ARPA is gone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are closely monitoring and reviewing the need for an override in the future to ensure we keep performing work at this level.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These decisions are not easy and we must balance the need and the ability to pay while taking into account that we will need a debt exclusion to build a new high school in the not too distant future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since hiring CFO Bob Dickinson and budget manager Courtney Cordello,

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are back to our baseline staffing levels in the finance department, and my office and the finance team have been hard at work with department heads, collecting information early in the process for the formulation of the fiscal year 2024 budget, especially given the global economic issues that persist, such as inflation and supply chain, in addition to recovering from the structural deficit of the pandemic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Fiscal year 24 is expected to be another difficult year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: However, we continue to work hard to get the city's revenue stream to the needed levels to sustain the city's needs.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Again, I want to thank everyone at City Hall that made all this work possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: While we're still working to optimize our staffing levels, the strength of the team that I have put together over the last three years in office has completely changed the culture of City Hall.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and other places and helped usher in much needed modernization and efficiency updates in city hall operations and policies.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Together, we are building the groundwork to professionalize Medford like never before and create a more meaningful and welcome experience for our residents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have so many new hires that have been instrumental to that change.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those that I've already mentioned, as well as Jeremy Johns, our director of veteran services, Melissa Ripley, our elections manager,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Jim Silver, our special projects coordinator, Bill Forty, our building commissioner, Paul Riggi, the city's first ever facilities director, a position the council and I advocated in favor for for the last 10 years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And thank you to HR and our director, Neil Osborne, and the efforts of so many others for keeping this process moving forward and helping fill roles.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Accountability has been key to transforming the way our city works and serves our residents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Without accountability, it's impossible to get a professionalized government that the city needs and the people deserve.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Part of accountability is ensuring every city employee and resident is aware of the importance of diversity, equity, inclusion, and has the means and support to actively promote equity and accessibility.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's part of our social justice roadmap.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And with the help, amazing help of our director of diversity and equity inclusion, Francis Waje,

[Lungo-Koehn]: The city has and will continue to expand DEI training for all staff, city, fire, and police, including implicit bias and cultural competency training.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I've said it before, there are things I will not tolerate and no one will discourage me from doing this hard work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We can do hard things.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We can transform this city and rid ourselves of the antiquated, outdated, and inefficient policies.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But it takes time, it takes focus, and it takes trust.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'm asking you to trust me.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Trust me to do this work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Trust me to make decisions that are in your best interests.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And trust me to lead this city to where we all know that it should be.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Because there is much more to do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is often not comfortable or fun having to make

[Lungo-Koehn]: these hard choices and do the necessary work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I've seen and heard about governments run without accountability and they quickly become chaotic and corrupt.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I will not let that happen here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I am committed to a transparent ethical administration for the city and thus will not tolerate city employees who do not share that same work ethic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That said, to be clear, the vast majority of our city employees come to work every day and try their best to move the city forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: many of whom I've mentioned tonight and all of whom I just don't don't don't have all the time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I do and I will continue to do all I can to support them in every way I can.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To conclude, please know that so much work has been put work has been put in over the last year to find creative solutions to any roadblocks the city faces.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When searching for funding, we find grants and secure them.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When presented with differing

[Lungo-Koehn]: When we say we are going to do something, we do it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I am dedicated to keeping my promises to Medford and delivering on projects, no matter the challenges we face along the way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And finally, and thankfully, we have the personnel to make it happen.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm the emcee, too.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I want to just thank you all so very much for coming tonight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those who are watching from home or on Zoom, past and present employees of Medford, we just, again, appreciate all your hard work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you so much.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a reception outside, so please stay, have a bite to eat, and get home safely.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you to the chamber, to the panelists, to Jim for the opportunity tonight to talk about the issues facing our city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My name is Breanna Lungo-Koehn and I am proud to have served as your mayor since 2020.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm proud to call Medford home, raise my family here, and serve my neighbors first as city councilor and now as your mayor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have led the city with the same values that this community instilled in me.

[Lungo-Koehn]: that integrity, hard work, and helping the people of Medford come first.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Over the past three and a half years, we have worked together to deliver key wins for Medford, recovering from the pandemic by delivering the supports to our businesses, schools, neighbors in the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We did a street and sidewalk audit assessment to start working on the backloads

[Lungo-Koehn]: backlog of decades of neglect.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've developed Medford's first comprehensive multi-year capital improvement plan, including millions of dollars for improvements to our streets, sidewalks, fire stations, schools, parks, tree canopy, and so much more.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We drafted the first ever master plan to create a 30-year vision for our future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We finalized the Climate Action and Adaptation Plan and have been hard at work implementing so we can meet our climate goals.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We reworked the city's website and budget process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We received the city's first ever Distinguished Budget Award.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have completed a housing production plan to help guide us in our work to make Medford more affordable for all.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We hired the first Economic Development Director

[Lungo-Koehn]: and the city's first facilities maintenance director, and I have built a team that gets things done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There is still important work that remains as our city faces great opportunities and tough challenges, which is why I'm running for another term as your mayor of Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm looking forward to answering your questions tonight, and I hope to earn your vote on November 7th.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's a great question.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First of all, I think all the work we've been doing is so important, so it's a hard question to answer, but I'll start with answering it with regards to housing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think we see a crisis in the Commonwealth, and we also see the crisis here in Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So what we've been able to do is create a master plan as well as a housing production plan that we are enacting currently and want to continue to enact.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We work with the council, we got that approved, and we also built in an affordable housing trust, which was also approved.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That trust is gonna, we're gonna create a board of members of our city, experts to help create more affordable housing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're also going to continue to work with our 40B developments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The first one we just finalized was Mill Creek.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That is going to add 350 new units to Medford, 88 of which will be affordable.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are going to continue to work with the Medford Housing Authority.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They are rehabbing all the units on Riverside Ave, and they are adding 22 additional units.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've supported them through the city with helping offset some of their permit costs.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also have the development at Walkland Court.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a hundred additional affordable housing units that will be added and then a rehab for all of our seniors and disabled population to have a quality living situation and to add 122 units.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we're going to continue to support the Housing Authority.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're going to continue to bring in development like we have over the last

[Lungo-Koehn]: several years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We did a lot of planning to get here and right now we have about 10 additional projects bringing in over 185 additional units to create housing in this city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have commissioned a team with MAPC and our planning and development team to redo Medford Square to also bring in new housing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor, you have a minute?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When I came into office January 2020, I had three 40B developments dropped on our table.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we commissioned the team led by Director Hunt and myself, as well as help from engineering and other departments, and we created, we assessed our landmass area.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and we met that threshold.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That gave us the leverage to push these 40 bees and have a seat at the table so they just didn't come in and do whatever they wanted in our community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We made sure that the buildings are sustainable.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We want updates to walkability around the facility.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We want to make sure the residents in those

[Lungo-Koehn]: complexes have green space.

[Lungo-Koehn]: By doing the tough work, we were able to turn what was promised 12-story high-rise luxury apartment complex on Mystic Ave into a $1 billion life science proposal that is before us today.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We did it right, and I'm proud of it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Penny.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's a great question.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we have a lot of needs, as I saw when we came into office, a lot of infrastructure needs.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think the top priority for me as your mayor is what we've been doing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee and I commissioned a consultant to review Medford High School and to submit a high-quality application to the MSBA.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We were 14th in line last year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: because of inflation, they only took 10.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We resubmitted in April, and we have our fingers crossed in such high hopes that we will get the MSBA loan to fund potentially half of a new construction of a new high school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That would be almost $200 million.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So for me,

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need to obviously see where our taxpayers are at, but we will need a debt exclusion for a new high school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our children deserve it, and our faculty deserve it, and it is in deplorable condition.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're working on updates, but it's just not enough.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I do feel that the top priority is a debt exclusion.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I also plan, we have a meeting scheduled with the president and vice president of the council, because

[Lungo-Koehn]: priority number one for me when I came in was a new fire station.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need a new fire station.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I always planned to go out to Bond and we'd put the debt service on our general fund budget, but the Councilors want to explore debt exclusion for that as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My stance has always been we need to

[Lungo-Koehn]: to know where our taxpayers are.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need to give them the facts on what it will cost to do those two things and decide if we have the ability to additionally, I know there's a push on the council for additional override for the general fund budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's something we need to explore.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have people that

[Lungo-Koehn]: you know, hate us that we won't do, we won't do it immediately.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then we have people calling saying they can't afford food for their table or these high rents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we need to take a approach where the council and the school in the school committee and myself, as well as the residents make those tough, tough decisions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilor, you have two minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll have to unload there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With regards to the MSBA loan, I think it's important to point out that if we desperately need that funding and we need to match that funding 50%, and the MSBA doesn't allow us to choose where to put the high school or how to rebuild, they're gonna tell us what belongs in a high school built for 1,200, 1,300 students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that is a $350 million price tag.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we have to be serious about committing to our students, committing to our educators, and get a new high school built the right way, and let the MSBA lead that process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm very hopeful.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're not certain, but I'm very hopeful that we'll be able to be successful in that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we need leadership that can get the job done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think I've proven that over the years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You know, we talk about infrastructure, our roads, our sidewalks, our trees, we're getting it done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This construction season alone, we've done two miles of sidewalk, two miles.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That doesn't come easy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It comes with hard work, it comes with leadership, and it comes with a team that can get it done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And they have been doing a lot of work, our engineers and our Department of Public Works, and we're getting it done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilwoman?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think the ratings show what students have gone through with the pandemic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And a lot of that has to do with mental health.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And to be in a building that's 60 years old that doesn't have the proper AC and ventilation and heating at times can do wonders for students' mental health and create an atmosphere that is more conducive to learning.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, I do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilor, you have any thought on that?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll start by saying that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: About a year ago, most of the contracts in the city, in the school side, became due.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it was, other than fire, it was the first time we had 20 contracts that we were trying to negotiate.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have since settled with our teachers, we've settled with clerical, we've settled with our Department of Public Works, we've settled with our security monitors, we've settled with a whole host of unions, and there are still a few that we're working on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've been going through good-faith negotiations with all of our unions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A few were held up due to, once the leadership changed with the Teamsters, we were doing flying with settling contracts, especially over the last couple months.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I think the question, Mark, comes down to the very way you approach the question.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's how do you fund what our employees deserve?

[Lungo-Koehn]: You know, if you're in the private sector,

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's sometimes more money out there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When you're in the city side, you tax to 2.5%, and you have the responsibility of people tugging and pulling from 25 directions, in my case, 25 different departments wanting more, wanting different things in the contract, and I have to be the one to make tough decisions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have to be the one to do a number of things.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First, to be fiscally responsible to the people we serve, to treat our employees well, and to be fair to our employees.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I had unions at one time asking for, and it wasn't too far away, 9.1 percent a year, where we only taxed at 2.5 percent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it's important that we take that collective picture

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I know, it's an election season.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I respect the push that is on me to get additional contracts settled, and all I can say is we're doing it in good faith while trying to be fiscally responsible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think I'll respond with a compliment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilor Caraviello is a very nice guy and I don't think it's in him to say no.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So negotiation strategies, whether it's sitting at the table every time or sitting in a side room, or sitting in a side room.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You have about 40 seconds.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm always present.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I sit usually in a room with my chief of staff, we have our human resource director, and we have an attorney.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In my case, we choose to have Copeland and Page

[Lungo-Koehn]: who have 40 attorneys on staff that are experts in their field.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's the reason why you see Medford moving forward at the rapid pace you do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They're helping planning, they're helping engineering, they're helping the police department, they're helping a number of, all of our departments to get things done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'm doing my best on a strategy to negotiate in good faith.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It shows because we've been able to settle contracts.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I've already spoken about housing, so I think our next greatest challenge is infrastructure, from buildings to streets to equipment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's why we've commissioned a capital improvement plan back in 2021.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was complete in 2022, end of 2021.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We just recently updated that plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It took a year's time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 200 million in needs and hundreds of projects in queue.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor, 30 seconds, proudest accomplishment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Oh, it's hard to pick one.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think back when I was younger, starting a girls hockey team to getting through a global pandemic, creating the plans that need to be put in place to move the city forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also have our pride events that we've celebrated the last two years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have our run Medford events, community aggregation, saving Medford residents a boatload on their bill.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've built a team that gets things done.
