[Lungo-Koehn]: transportation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Representative Barber is working to do an environmental study, pushing to do an environmental study to expand the Green Line.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also want to make sure that the current Green Line that just opened is moving at a speed that our residents deserve.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if we do need to do upgrades, we need to make sure that we have leadership in place to push the T to not only communicate

[Lungo-Koehn]: but to make sure our residents and all commuters are safe.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Do you mind repeating the question, please?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Oh, sure.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thanks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think I agree with the Councilor with regards to trying to get cars off the road.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Not only is it going to make things safer, but it's going to help with our climate change issues.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What we have in place, and I cannot take credit, is Director Todd Blake.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He's Director of Traffic and Transportation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the work he does on a day-to-day basis for the last five years is

[Lungo-Koehn]: something you can't even write about.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There are 730 streets in the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There are 16 intersections.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since he's been here, we've updated, with safety improvements, 200 of those intersections.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So as you can see, there's a lot done, but there's a lot more to do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also have been working very hard to create alternate means of transportation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Not only do we have the Green Line that opened, but we have implemented

[Lungo-Koehn]: 10 blue bike stations throughout our community and more to come.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know Tufts University, I'll give them a shout out, is dedicating, they're gonna donate two to the city of Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also are exploring any and every location for EV charging stations to try to push people to drive hybrid.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're trying to electrify our vehicles as well as a way to help with the climate change issue.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But transportation, we have drivers, we have walkers, we have people in wheelchairs, people trying to get to school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So there's a balance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think our traffic commission is doing the best they can to, through Director Blake's advisement, to make sure we accommodate, you know, some parking, but then also make sure we have travel lanes for all means of transportation so that people can get safely to and from work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and we've been doing that work for a long time and we need to continue that work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So you'll see Winthrop Street, South Street, Main Street, Mystic Ave, we have Haines Square, two complete street projects that we're doing, Haines Square and Riverside Ave, and the work's not done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor, I think that goes for you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's me?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford Square has been talked about for many, many years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've had a number of studies done, and I feel like the last study, which took into account what was done in 2017, was that that was done by our planning department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've partnered with the MAPC, Mass Development, to reimagine our downtown.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have three parcels.

[Lungo-Koehn]: in Medford Square that we are gonna go out to bid with an RFP on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now that's after months and months long of communication, surveying, community meetings, listening sessions with all of our residents, especially our seniors at the senior center who have needs, as well as the Chevalier Theater, because it just needs to be done right.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So my vision is multi-use on two of those properties,

[Lungo-Koehn]: I would like to see affordability on housing at all different levels on at least one of the properties, commercial on the bottom floor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Then you have the parcel, which is in between the Hyatt and City Hall, where we could create some parking.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We could create potentially a rec center.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'd love to see a nice restaurant up top.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Then we also have an unactivated riverfront that is going unused.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we've partnered with a consultant and we have created a vision for the waterfront from the senior center all the way down to Sleepy Hollow.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it's important to me that we get that done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I envision, you know, a bear garden and an art mural and a safe place for our children to play and then a dock out to the water with some art floating in the water.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Then you have Sleepy Hollow that definitely needs some updating.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So there is so much to do, but we're getting ready to release an RFP for the three parcels, and I hope to see a lot of action on the waterfront by next spring, summer.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we're able to get that done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've doubled our planning staff since I've taken office.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have the planners.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have the people in place, which Director Hunt leads, to get the job done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll just respond with things do take time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I've been in office a little bit over three years, and I've explained during my opening statement all the plans we put in place, all the work that we've been doing over the last three years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't think it goes unnoticed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: by me saying we are at the point where we're gonna put an RFP out for Medford Square, we are at the point.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've done the hard work, the finalized work, and we will be putting out an RFP, we will be activating our waterfront, and thankfully, we do have the people that can get that done, and that's something I'm very proud of.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No, I don't think so.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's so many people that don't have the means or the ability to ride a bike, so I think it's about creating that balance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had a project on Winthrop that spans the whole stretch of the street, and our director came up with a plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: People were

[Lungo-Koehn]: for the plan, they were against the plan, we were able to, the Traffic Commission was able to tweak it and really think about the different properties that were along the route so that we could create the parking where needed for the American Legion and for our residents that live in the high-rise development.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it's about creating balance and it's about creating a space for all of Medford residents, whether you're walking, whether you're pushing a stroller, riding a bike, driving a car,

[Lungo-Koehn]: We want to be able to share our roads and share it safely.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's the work we've been doing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we try to listen to everybody and create that balance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor, two minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think I spent two minutes talking a lot about affordable housing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was my, I think when the question was asked about the top priority.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I don't want to repeat myself, but maybe go into a little bit about the trust and bringing in revenue for the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And just to set the record straight on a few things, new growth is how we do a lot of things.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's how we increase our budget and how we fund

[Lungo-Koehn]: infrastructure needs as well as funds different things that will help with affordable housing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So just some facts.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In 2011, we brought in $688,000 in new growth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In 2015, we're at $999,000.

[Lungo-Koehn]: New growth was just projected.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's on the DLS website.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For fiscal year 24, which is the year we're in, we're projecting $2.75 million in new growth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we have gone over $2 million

[Lungo-Koehn]: for the first time in 2021, and we've gone over three years so far.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it's just something I'm proud of, and it's something that our assessing department and our building department have all worked to make a reality, coupled with our planning department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And what's best about the planning that we're doing and

[Lungo-Koehn]: 20, 40 shovels in the ground because you took two years to get to that point.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The great thing about it, it is bringing in the new growth and it's not going to stop here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I had to point that out as something that's important for budgetary purposes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is actually one of the top three reasons I ran in 2020.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was the fact that our commercial tax base was declining, steadily declining.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And since I took office, it is now increasing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also had an issue with public trust.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had a zoning board of appeals that violated open meeting law.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They ended up resigning.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And over the first year in my term, while going through a pandemic, we were building that trust back.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As I met with developers, with our planning team and our economic development team, we sat with them and we said, please, just have a community meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need to build trust back among our residents, and that's what we do every time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So the 20 or 30 properties, including the eight-story life science complex that's going above the Bertucci site,

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's finally out of a court with a neighbor, and that is moving forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's just one of tens and 20, 30 different projects that we are moving forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It takes time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's not something I could fix overnight with the snap of a finger.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But we're doing it right, and we're going to continue to do it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Penny.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Charter review is extremely important.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a 40-plus-year-old charter.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's about a page and a half.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It only references the male gender and to name another whole host of other issues with the charter.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So early on, I committed to doing charter review as a Councilor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was proposed by Councilor Marks in 2016, and I was one of four.

[Lungo-Koehn]: that approved charter review.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I then put it forward to the city council twice during my first year and a half.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I thank the four that voted to move forward with the charter.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It just wasn't enough in the state house to get it moved through that way, so I chose another way and we commissioned

[Lungo-Koehn]: a task force of 11 capable individuals, Medford residents, led by our chair, Milva, to create, it's gonna take 12 to 18 months, but we're already deep in, at least halfway through, and we've done, we have a community survey out now that's due in December, it's open for many months, so that we can get as much input from our business owners, our residents,

[Lungo-Koehn]: in the city, and it's exploring everything that has to do with our charter, including term limits, ward representation, how many members should be on the council, should there be at-large members, and a number of those things I do support.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I was interviewed for the Charter Commission, and it was very basic for me.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What do the people want?

[Lungo-Koehn]: What do the people want to see in our government?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if we can figure that out, I will support it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I want to see term limits.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I've said that for years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I want to see term limits.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You can see what happens when somebody's been in office for 30 years, and that needs to change.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it's clear with my vote in 2016, the fact that I put it before the council twice, and the fact that I put a committee together to do it another way, that I am for charter change.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't believe my council colleague

[Lungo-Koehn]: to my left, has supported charter change on the council those three times, so I just want that to be clear.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Secondly, we have hundreds of people serving on our boards and commissions, and my number one priority is diversity.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have to also take in what was before me as far as who applied.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And you also have to remember that diversity is not just about the color of somebody's skin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's about LGBTQ, disabled.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It has a whole host of things that we need to think about and review when putting a committee together.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'm proud of the committee we put together.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know two of, one is running for city council, one got a job in Medford, thankfully, and we have replaced those members, and those replacements are also diverse.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilwoman.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Two minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The safety of our students is our number one priority.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So when that incident happened at the high school, I think the first thing that we had to do was listen to our students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I was lucky to have a number walk on over to City Hall, and I welcomed them in.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And for three hours, we discussed

[Lungo-Koehn]: everything from A to Z as it relates to Medford High School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We then had the superintendent and the leadership created, not only did a survey go out in the spring to learn more, but we had listening sessions at the high school that I also went to.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was important to assess leadership.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was important to assess the handbook and the rules and how they were being administrated and followed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'm very happy and have very high hopes for the new principal of the high school, Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Cabral.

[Lungo-Koehn]: She seems to be creating, making sure that handbook is fulfilled, and I think it's creating a great atmosphere.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's not to say that we didn't necessarily have good leadership.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's that we had a global pandemic where our students' lives were turned upside down.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our students were the ones that suffered the most, from mental health to being isolated in their homes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's something that we need to deal with.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've been able to hire staff and social workers and guidance Councilors.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We put a 10-point plan in place, led by our superintendent of schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: to create a safe environment the best way we could right after that incident.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it's, it's been, we've been successful and we're gonna keep making sure we make security upgrades.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I've commissioned a team, city and school staff, to make sure that gets done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now the team at City Hall is, wheels are turning pretty fast.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So there's a lot that still needs to be done and that just has to be our top priority, safety of our students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To respond to that, I don't think anybody does a perfect job at anything, but I take just offense to treating our superintendent that way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our superintendent has great skills, and she cares about our students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What we dealt with before her was on a whole other level.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Marice Edouard-Vincent cares about our students, and you said

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't think we can blame the principal either.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He was, which I think is what you did, but the current principal was leading a student body of 1,100 that just went through a global pandemic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our students are suffering.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They still are.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why we have the extra supports in our schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And not one person was to blame.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need to take responsibility as parents, as educators, as principals and administrators, and as a superintendent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Nobody was to blame.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That incident was an unfortunate, awful incident.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They were in the bathroom, they were kicked out of the bathroom, and then when the monitors walked away, they were back in the bathroom.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was an awful, awful situation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you for the question.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it's a great question.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it goes along the lines of what we've been doing for economic development and new growth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Two years ago, we commissioned a consultant along with our economic development director to review the air rights.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We own 28 acres above the Wellington T stop.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was, we've had these air rights since the 60s and nothing was ever done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we commissioned an RFI, request for information, and we were able to solicit, it was months long, but we were able to solicit eight developers that came forward with their plans and ideas.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All can be reviewed in our city website.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And what we're doing now is we went out to bid with an RFP to hire a consultant so we can do an RFP for the air rights.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I envision multi-use, all levels of affordability, retail, restaurants, potential hotel on that site, working with the T building on that property.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I can't remember the second part of the question now that I... Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also have the MBTA Communities Act that we need to comply with, and we are complying, and that's extremely important.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've done the work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have the planners in place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know Danielle Evans and Director Hunt have been working on this diligently.

[Lungo-Koehn]: through the MBTA Communities Act, we have to create thousands of units next to transit.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So the Wellington location is the perfect spot to do that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So between going out to bid with an RFP for those air rights,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and complying with this MBTA Communities Act, we'll be able to really revitalize and redevelop that area.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And of course, community input and community meetings will be powder that as it always was.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'll just add, this is work we've been doing over the three years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Malden and Everett, and Somerville started 30 years ago, and you're seeing it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Everett, Malden started 10 years ago, and now you're seeing it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I've started three years ago, and you're seeing it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 30 seconds mayor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For quite some time I did meet with the president and vice president monthly and I do try to present the budget and present different things, go once in a while to the council.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's a tough political environment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I wish I had the answers, but what we're going to do with regards to budgeting and council relationships, we're going to start meeting again.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a meeting next week, and it's important that we try to collaborate.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we have been collaborating, even if I don't attend every single meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think you have to, again, balance the need of local landscapers with the noise element and pollution element, so I think maybe

[Lungo-Koehn]: either doing time frames or staggering it out where they would have to go electric in hopes that there would be less noise would be the answer.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Let landscapers get new equipment over a three or five year time frame while limiting potential hours or seasons would probably be the best answer the council will decide on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think there's a number of qualities you need as mayor, but I think having integrity is probably one of the top, and integrity leads to being fair to all, being fair to all of our employees.

[Lungo-Koehn]: being fair and making sure every developer has a seat at the table, not just a select few, being fair to our residents, listening to all, making sure like streets and sidewalks, we don't just do a sidewalk because we know somebody, we do a sidewalk because we did an assessment and that outlined how we get the work done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor, two minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, we have a climate crisis on our hands.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We all see it in the news every day.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It happens close to home now, too, with what we saw over the last month, especially in Lemonster and Andover.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But what we've done is we did a climate action and adaptation plan back in 2022.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It outlines 32 strategies and four focus areas.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we have been actively, while it was being prepared and continuing to this day, and we need to continue it into the future, we've been actively initiating that from transportation to our municipal vulnerability preparedness work, composting contract that we signed, our recycling contract.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also have a

[Lungo-Koehn]: textile contract with help see But I think the most important part of this this work as well as electrifying and making sure we start buying hybrid vehicles Which we we've done Is the work that we're putting in?

[Lungo-Koehn]: To make sure that all residents know what's going on that we're able to communicate with all residents we were able to secure $400,000 for municipal vulnerability

[Lungo-Koehn]: preparedness.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was a grant that has come in and through some ARPA funding we've been able to hire over 10 community liaisons and connectors and those liaisons and connectors speak other languages.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's something the city's never had before and it's something that we so desperately needed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are able to reach all communities

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are able to translate things, we're able to find out what the needs are, and we're able to prepare to be resilient in the future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If there is an emergency, we've built trust, so now our residents have people they can lean on, they know they can trust the city, they know where they can find help, where our shelters will be, where our food sources will be, and water.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's a crisis, but we're working on it, and we're gonna continue to work on it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilor, two minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor, one minute.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just want to point out some good work from not only the Board of Health, but our communications director, who's a jack-of-all-trades.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We applied for a $2 million grant from the federal government that's hopefully in queue to create a municipal vulnerability preparedness site, and that is the Hegner Center.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's a building that the city owns that needs to be rehabbed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we're hoping to get that 2 million so that we can create a site to create a safe space in case of a climate emergency.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that will be important, too, because we have the additional time where there isn't an emergency, we'll be able to use

[Lungo-Koehn]: that as rec space or senior space, and our rec director has been hard at work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He's always there when we need a helping hand, and what we need now is some help with our after-school crisis.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have hundreds on the wait list, and that site would be able to allow Medford Recreation to house and create a program, which we already have the plans for.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We just need the space to create an after-school program.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just want to point out, because I know there was a council meeting last night, and it's been talked about the last week.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm not sure who did the homework, but there was talks about how the budget was wrong.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now, the budget was done by my chief of staff, budget director, and CFO, and it was given to the council the earliest I ever recall.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we gave the budget in May.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What's being talked about over the last week is that the actuals were wrong.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The actuals were as of the May timeframe.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We still had another month and a half to bring that up to what we actually budgeted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we did budget correctly.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I just want to point that out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Can you repeat the question?

[Lungo-Koehn]: With the federal pandemic relief money.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you so much.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we have ESSER funding that has been spent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You can only use it through September of 2024.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have

[Lungo-Koehn]: ARPA funding that can be spent through December 31st, 2024.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we are strategically budgeting in preparation for that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is it going to be difficult?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, it is.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But we have gone from a $12 million revenue loss in fiscal year 21 down to $4 million this year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And what we've done is we've saved $2 million

[Lungo-Koehn]: to continue to go down for fiscal year 25.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That doesn't mean we don't have a problem.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've put on positions in our schools and in our city that are funded through this revenue, but we've already started thinking about it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With our social worker, we're going to transition her to the opioid settlement, $830,000 that we've been able to receive over 18 years.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With our economic development planner, we are going to be able to use some of our CDBG money because we've been able to be strategic with that funding.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're going to do everything we can to keep positions in place, but it will be a struggle, which is why it's another pull of the budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilor, one minute.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've spent over $500,000 to enhance communication systems between stations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The whole list, there are hundreds of projects that we've been able to do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've had presentations to the council.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, I'm not sure where you've been, but I just hope you take a look at the website.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My question?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Could you repeat one more time?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sorry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilor, two minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor, one minute.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm just going to touch upon the staffing, not only on a diversity lens, but also just in general, because it's been brought up many times tonight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First of all, we've done everything we can to professionalize how we hire.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For the first time since I took office, we have a human resource department, where the hiring goes through, and Francis Wojcicki has helped us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: create an even better process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have interview panels.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We take notes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We make sure that the best candidate gets the position.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There was also a time where Vivian Wright was working for us, and I asked her to just take a look at the last six months, nine months, what is the percentage of diversity that we've hired, and we were over 25% for the first time in what I think is Medford's history, and that's something that takes

[Lungo-Koehn]: thought, it takes making sure that the right person gets the job, and it takes work, and we're doing it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And as far as staffing, I am in charge of 400 people.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There is always going to be 12 job postings on our human resource board.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You know, we've been able to hire such a great crew, and we're continuing to do that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There are a couple vacancies, but we're working through them.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a great economic development director we've been interviewing, and we're taking one step at a time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor, two minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think the question was about our residents and

[Lungo-Koehn]: not only in Medford, but the Commonwealth and the country, and how people are feeling.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I just want to bring it back and bring a little bit of hope.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What I see in Medford, because that's where I lead, I do, I see two sides fighting on social media to the point where sometimes you just got to put it down.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But if you put that aside, I see a community of which I know is 90 to 95% of the people that have values where we care about others, where we are kind, where we have the same concerns like building a new high school and

[Lungo-Koehn]: fixing, making sure we go net zero by 2050, and making sure we have transportation for our residents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I see people stepping up every day, whether that's serving on a board or commission.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I see people putting food in the food pantry, and now we have nine of them.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I see our Department of Public Works who built those food pantries.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One minute.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I too think Councilor Caraviello has stepped up, and I thank him for that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You were out delivering groceries with my husband when people were afraid to leave their homes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I give you tremendous credit, and I thank you for that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I wasn't insinuating otherwise.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I too do what is best for the community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You know, I lead a city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I am really digging into school issues.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three children, they don't even do Girls on the Run, but I coach 27 little cuties every week because I want to make an impact.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think that's one thing we have in common, Councilor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You're always stepping up, and I always try to be the best person I can, no matter how tired I am.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My poor family is the one that probably suffers the most if I'm, you know, exhausted on the couch by Friday night, but that is something we do have in common, and I'm proud of that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Jim, moderators, the chamber, and Kevin at Medford Community Media, and the audience for tuning in.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When I came into office, the city was not only facing incredible challenges like a global pandemic, but we were contending with lack of plans and long overdue investments to our infrastructure.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since 2020, I have focused on leading in a way that was fair to all and accountable to Medford residents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: While navigating us through the pandemic, my team and I also focused on doing the planning and the work needed to secure state and federal funding to address our infrastructure needs and address decades of neglect.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And most importantly, I focused on delivering for Medford by hiring highly qualified professionals.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We focus on smart budgeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are professionalizing city services and embed accountability and transparency in all we do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's because of my record of getting things done that I've been endorsed by Governor Healey, Lieutenant Governor Driscoll, Congresswoman Clark, Representative Barber, organized labor, school committee members, Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Stone, McLaughlin, and Hayes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: to name a few.

[Lungo-Koehn]: With all that we have accomplished in just two terms, we all know there is still so much work to do and so many challenges ahead of us, from the impacts of climate change and increasing mobility through our streets and public transportation to addressing our housing crisis and improving our public schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need experienced leadership, trusted leadership that can continue this work and continue moving Medford forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the past, there was a culture within the city where connections were valued over community, which led to an unfair system and missed opportunities for the growth we need.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We cannot go backwards.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We just can't.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Remember, you have two important decisions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You have ahead of you the decision to get out and vote and the decision to vote for which candidates you think will make a positive difference in the lives of all Medford residents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It would be an honor to earn your vote on November 7th so I can continue leading this city and our strong team in the right direction.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Dr. Edouard-Vincent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Good afternoon, everybody.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's an honor to be here with you today, celebrating women and sharing stories about our lives and careers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I thank the superintendent and the team at Medford High School for putting this wonderful event together.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's not a secret that there are barriers and challenges that attempt to prevent women from achieving our deserved place as equals in society.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I wish I could tell you that by the time you students are ready to face the world outside these walls, you'll be met with recognition and support in all your endeavors.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Unfortunately, that's not the case.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You will be faced with adversity, with roadblocks, and with situations that are just frankly unfair.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But as you'll hear from women here today, there is no reason for that to be accepted as an outcome.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You have to be your own advocate, and above all, you must believe that your worth is not measured by anybody other than yourself.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These are hard lessons, and it takes a lot of tough situations to learn them.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But what you hear today from strong women who have repeatedly crashed through the glass ceilings, toughness is not attributed to just one gender.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Anna.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As a female leader, I think you have to lead by example and you also have to break through the status quo and how things

[Lungo-Koehn]: maybe were run in the past.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So when I became mayor three years ago, I promised myself that I would always do what was right no matter what, no matter if it cost me votes or led to somebody being unhappy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'll just give you an example.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Systematic change, changing the system, part of that is the hiring process and making sure we have a diverse

[Lungo-Koehn]: staff, especially within City Hall and our school department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I had to interview for a position in the city, and I was stuck with, I had two candidates left that got moved to my office for the final interview.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One was a Medford resident who, I knew her children, and one was a resident, it was not a resident, and it was a woman that was more qualified and spoke a second language.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I knew I would get a little pushback, potentially, for not picking the candidate that was a Medford resident that I knew personally, and I did.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I chose the candidate that had more experience and that spoke a second language, because that's what Medford needs.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need to embrace diversity.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need to have a culture where City Hall represents the entire city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, breaking through the status quo.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Lisa.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Good morning, everybody.

[Lungo-Koehn]: People of all ages, it's wonderful to be here today.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you to Lisa for planning this amazing event.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was community senator Terry and the board to celebrate Martin Luther King Jr.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Day.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I also just want to recognize a few people.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Edouard-Vincent, superintendent of schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have State Rep.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sean Garvalli, State Rep.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Christine Barber, and then Redford City Council President, Nicole Morell, and City Councilor, Brittany Yellow.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think I've...

[Lungo-Koehn]: hosting today, and we know our diversity, equity, and inclusion director, Frances Wojcik, who's watching at home due to car trouble.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We were happy to help support this, and we thank you for your partnership.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you to the Royal House who also partnered with us to make today happen.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you for all who are attending, and thank you for inviting me to say a few words as we celebrate the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So happy to be here to share thoughts on his impact, reflect with you all, and enjoy the music, poetry, and conversations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The past few years have definitely tested us, but Dr. King's message of equality, love, and hope are still as relevant today as when he originally spread them some 60 years ago.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One of the prevailing messages that Dr. King referenced on multiple occasions is the quest for a better future for the youth of America.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's something I constantly grapple with.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Will I leave this city and the world a better place for my children and your children?

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's a tall task, but it's one we must achieve in order to build on the legacy that Dr. King forged.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In Medford and in all communities, we need to continually address the systematic issues that can erode the people's trust.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're trying to do that through our advocacy on many different issues, including the MUP grant,

[Lungo-Koehn]: including transit, development, and the environment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need to lift up the voices of those who often go unheard and champion causes that lead to a more sustainable and powerful future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Embracing Dr. King's leadership and ideals will help us take accountability and honor his legacy and reach those lofty goals of unity.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I look forward to the conversation today, to hear everyone talk about their experiences with Dr. King and his message.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It has had a profound impact on so many and has helped shape so much of what we are trying to do here in Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's truly special to be able to come together, reflect on the life of Dr. King, and speak on the shared experiences we have dealing with diversity, social equity, and building a foundation of trust in our community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you again to everybody who made this happen, who's here today, who's watching from home.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All right, let's do it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We can do this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Members of the same present.

[Lungo-Koehn]: meetings, they were by grade level on the first day back last week.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And so 12 total mental health professionals in the building

[Lungo-Koehn]: six guidance Councilors, principal, three assistants, and the list goes on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the students were shown every name and picture so that they have an idea of where they are in the building, who they are.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And between Peter and Joan, I know you're working on it a great deal, the survey.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm pushing very hard behind the scenes that it not be a form survey, that we have a survey

[Lungo-Koehn]: that we develop, take our time, an extra couple of weeks to develop that is gonna fit the needs of our students and our teachers and our families.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Then some of the questions are gonna be based off of what we've learned in the listening sessions, in the class meetings.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And for an example, it's, do you have a trusted adult in the building that you can go to voice a concern to?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if not, do you want one so that you can connect students directly?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's just one example.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The administration is trying to do this right and be thoughtful, and I appreciate that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm pushing for it, and I'm getting good response.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I just wanted to point that out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There are trusted people in the building, plenty of them that our students can go to.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is another means of, I want to be completely anonymous.

[Lungo-Koehn]: During the class meetings,

[Lungo-Koehn]: it was not clear on what the discipline would be, other than the first would be reported to your parent and potentially the assistant principal.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the students in the listening sessions actually said, because it's going to be based per student.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But in the listening sessions, the students actually that came to the listening sessions wanted stricter discipline

[Lungo-Koehn]: to be known by the student body.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And of course, if there is a special situation of a child in an IEP, then you would treat them on a case by case basis.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I do ask that the administration does work on a plan that's tight, that the student body would understand.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They weren't happy their parents were going to be called to be notified, which is fine.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But they didn't want to even said, I feel like I might be discriminated against because it's a case by case basis.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I do it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: ask the administration to have a team meeting on this to identify what the levels of discipline will be to then follow up with the student body.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And of course, if there's a special situation, then that will be handled accordingly.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I think that's important.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think you're on the right track.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It should be report home every single time, but then discipline comes into play depending on how many times a class is cut.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm glad it's working.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I think we need to just tighten it up and firm that up and let parents, caregivers, teachers, students know, because it will happen less and less if they know what the consequences are.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Absolutely.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It has to be a team effort between home and school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Next up we have number six report of the superintendent superintendent superintendents updates and comments, I'm going to turn it over to Dr. Reese Edouard-Vincent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you from the chair if I may, I want to thank the superintendent for comments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First and foremost, our teachers who navigated the almost two hours in the shelter in place while the police were able to do their work at the high school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We thank the teachers, staff, the nurses, thank the police department for being there and obviously going to be a presence throughout the week.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do have chief of police here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: also Captain Covino, who will be able to answer questions if we do have any questions, and maybe give us an update right off the bat.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But please know we are taking this extremely seriously.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Safety of our students is our utmost priority.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think you've heard from this committee that we recognize there's a systemic issue, and there's a culture and climate study that needs to be done, and that's just one thing that needs to be done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know many of you have said it on the floor,

[Lungo-Koehn]: I say what I need to say quite often behind the scenes, especially out of respect and pushing for that change.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Everybody knows I'm making the changes on the city side, and we do want to see positive changes for our students on the school side too.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do recognize that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have asked for a culture and climate study a year ago, and I know that's out in procurement now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Cushing told us today.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Just also please know, as soon as I heard about this, I was at the high school with our communications team, also our board of health director, who is our emergency management coordinator for the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We went to the high school just to make sure we could lend a hand any way possible, work with central administration to get communications out, to make sure we were crossing all our T's and dotting all our I's, and the students are our utmost priority in their safety.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There is no imminent threat.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll ask Captain Covino to maybe come up and give a little more detail.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's no imminent threat.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a plan for tomorrow between the bathroom plan, extra staffing in the hallways and the cafeterias.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're asking our teachers for support.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do have a plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're gonna implement that tomorrow and any other details you can give Captain Covino.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know you're actively working the situation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You could tell us a little bit.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know everybody's been watching the news and

[Lungo-Koehn]: Schools have sent out a number of communications to parents and faculty and staff, but is there anything else you can share about the incident that we don't know about in the last hour that we've been in executive session?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we'll have additional professionals and Councilors in the high school to deal, along with the police presence.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We'll have additional supports in place for our faculty and staff tomorrow.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've called in outside agencies as well as additional Councilors from the other schools to come help.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Any?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know that people may be here to talk,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Um, ask questions, voice your concerns.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do not have any other presentations in the public or continued business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do have one item.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Under new business, 2022-54 offered by members Rousseau, Graham, and Mastone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas on February 3, 2020, the Medford School Committee voted unanimously in favor of a proclamation to make Medford hunger free.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas in the ensuing 35 months, our world has been devastated by a pandemic that has taken more than 1 million lives in our nation alone, and at least 6.6 million lives worldwide.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the pandemic can be measured in many ways, nearly all of which involve significant loss.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One of those bright spots, childhood hunger in the United States is reduced through pandemic food relief programs through federal and state governments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the Medford School Committee has no funding authority, cannot raise taxes or have any effect on the revenues we are allocated from city, state, and federal access to execute on the authority we do have.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas our mission is to provide a caring educational partnership of school, family, and community in pursuit of providing the very best education our children deserve for them and for the future of our world.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the Medford School Committee,

[Lungo-Koehn]: democratically elected body with exclusive local control.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Public schools must press on the city, state, and federal governments to supply us with the revenues we need to meet our obligations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now, therefore, be it resolved, the Medford School Committee join the Feed Kids Coalition as a sponsor in urging the Massachusetts State Legislature to make free school meals permanent, directs the superintendent to transmit official copies of this resolution to the following governor-elect, Mara Healy, Senator Elizabeth Warren,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Senator Edward Markey, Congresswoman Catherine Clark, Senator Patricia Jalen, State Representative Paul Donato, Sean Garbley, and Christine Barber, directs the superintendent to transmit an official copy of this resolution to the Medford City Council in accordance with Medford School Committee Rule 77, directs the superintendent to transmit an official copy of the resolution to the Mayor of Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to approve.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to approve by Member McLaughlin, seconded by Member Hays.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do not have any reports requested tonight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have condolences.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number 12, the Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Joseph P. Lennox Jr., a World War II veteran and uncle, to former Mayor Michael J. McGlynn and former school committee member and state representative John R. Granara.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Anne T. Quill, a lifelong Medford resident and mother of Julianne Morrow, a cosmetology teacher at the Medford Vocational Technical High School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Eric Lundberg and Brian Arch, both Medford High School graduates, and the nephew and brother, respectfully, to Janet Connors of the Medford High School Security Office.

[Lungo-Koehn]: committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Margaret Eisenhower, mother of Joan Bowen, director of student services, and also the Metro School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Lisa Olsen Caggiano, a former early childhood teacher at the Metro Public Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Next up, we have number four, Labor Relations Report, Mr. David Murphy, Assistant Superintendent of Finance and Operations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mr. Murphy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't know if there's any questions from the committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion on the floor by Member Ruseau that one school committee member be present at any negotiating sessions, seconded by

[Lungo-Koehn]: Second, member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is real call or all those in favor aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I was opposed motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If I may, from the chair, I don't wanna be repetitive in any way,

[Lungo-Koehn]: maybe just speak a couple minutes because I know Mr. Murphy, Dr. Edouard-Vincent, we were working all through the weekend on this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I know the committee has been inundated with emails.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know they're hard to read, and I myself, I felt as mayor, I did need to respond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So the number that came from Pennsylvania or California or Arizona, obviously I did not respond to, but I did take the time one morning, 5 to 7, 7.30, and this morning at 4 to respond to

[Lungo-Koehn]: several hundred emails, and it was very simple.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I stated that, of course, this committee, as well as the city and school staff, I said, we aimed to do what's right, because I think that was part of the email.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Do what's right.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We always aim to do what's right.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's how we did get to a signed tentative agreement.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The union leadership, our administration, with the vote of the council, got to a signed tentative agreement.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That wasn't easy because, as you can see on the documentation, the average is 6.5 potentially on a three-year contract over the 10, 12 prior years, and we're at

[Lungo-Koehn]: something and we saw what happened budget time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was tough budget with the numbers of the average of 2% for most unions per year, sometimes a little bit more.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We wanted to get this done so badly.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We know our teachers, we all know our teachers deserve a fair salary.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We wanted to bring them up over 90,000 average.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This contract would bring our teachers up to an average of $93,000 a year plus bonus checks that we want to give our teachers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I took the time to respond, and I did say that even though we have the tentative agreement, it was signed in October, that I was asked to have a meeting within 24 hours, like Mr. Murphy said.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I gave my times and dates that I'm available this week.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a meeting scheduled on the 7th, which is this Wednesday.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When I did speak to Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Douglas this morning, I was a little heated.

[Lungo-Koehn]: She mentioned, she called to let me know that there'll be no confidence vote against the school committee and myself.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I just don't think that's fair to the committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If it's against me, that's one thing because in the email, it also mentioned be a leader.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They want us to be leaders.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I just have to tell you as my colleagues that I do feel you are leaders.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are leaders together because we've stuck together to understand

[Lungo-Koehn]: And you have the responsibility of the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I feel like I have been a leader as mayor because I have a lot to juggle as the schools, but also the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have almost 20 CBAs, 20 unions that we have negotiated with, are currently negotiating with, and need to continue to negotiate with.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have an annual budget that is maxed out, and we can get into that argument.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Potentially, we will need an override, potentially, even just with 2% raises.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But we went above and beyond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We want to get this done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it's really hard.

[Lungo-Koehn]: you know, as to get those emails and to know you're doing the right thing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we've, we, we listened to, you know, the park, the needs of the parks at the schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, so as a leader of the community, not only worried about the 20 CBAs and keeping our personnel, um, getting cooler percentages each year,

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have streets and sidewalks that are falling apart.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have parks that we are finally getting ahead of, not ahead, we finally have 50, 70 projects in the works, some complete, some we're working on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Four, including the McGlynn, or five large-scale park projects that we're working on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have funding sources that we're being creative with.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have personnel issues that we're dealing with on a daily basis.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Maurice, Dave, and I know that, and they're not fun.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So a leader to me is what we have done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A leader to me is to say, Charlene, if you have to take a no-confidence vote, I can't lead this city into receivership.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have mayors who are colleagues that, you know, a lot of cities and towns are going through this, and they're dealing with the pressure

[Lungo-Koehn]: And to a couple of them, I've said, how are you going to afford that?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And in person, I've seen a couple of them and they say to me, I don't know.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't know.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I said, where are you going to cut?

[Lungo-Koehn]: How are you going to fund something like that?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I've said to even one, I said, you have a responsibility.

[Lungo-Koehn]: to the entire community, to the taxpayers, not just one union, you have responsibility to the entire community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it is a struggle, there is pressure, we're all feeling it, but we are sticking together and I feel like we are being leaders.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it's unfortunate, from the very beginning, it was the narrative that was being portrayed as we're disrespectful, we're disrespectful.

[Lungo-Koehn]: At one point, it was a few months in, and I said, I called Dave, Mr. Murphy right away, and I said, what was our first offer?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Because all I keep hearing is we're disrespectful.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What did you offer?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the answer was, well, the teachers are asking for 6% a year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we offered, I forget exactly what it was, 1.5 to- To 1.75 and 1.5.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And my point, thank you, Mr. Murphy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And my point is when I initially heard the offer and 6%, I said, you know, I went back and I said that it's not disrespect.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To me, that's negotiations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's how it works, back and forth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And you get to that number just like we did.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Higher than I think we should be, but we're at 7.25 with 1% at the end of the year, plus three $1,500 bonuses.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think we never would ever, ever want to disrespect

[Lungo-Koehn]: any of our teachers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I don't feel that we have.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But the narrative got everybody so anxious and angry that we had to do something to calm it down.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we did.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we reached this tentative agreement.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had the union leadership sign.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We did sign.

[Lungo-Koehn]: could, for some reason it wasn't ratified.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think that was Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Douglas's job to get it ratified and it didn't, it didn't happen.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So here we are.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we go and agree to a meeting on Wednesday, hoping to get it done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We also have mediation on the 20th, but instead what I told Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Douglas this morning, and I'll say it publicly is it was disingenuous to ask me for a meeting, which I agreed to.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have it scheduled and then to go back

[Lungo-Koehn]: another rally, declare no confidence to rile the membership up again.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I mean, are we going to lead this to the spring?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I sure hope not.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But what I would ask is, could we, or would somebody propose that we take a vote to ask Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Douglas the same thing?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please do what's right.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please be a leader.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please bring this back to the membership in a meeting to do one thing, not to hear whatever he has to say, and then some people don't show up because they don't want to hear it, because there's many teachers not showing up.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They don't want to be there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They don't want to deal with it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Have a meeting this week to just take a vote.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Take a vote.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Everybody can take a little time and look at these slides.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Take a vote.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We want to get our teachers

[Lungo-Koehn]: this average of 93,000 as soon as possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We want to get them to two checks would be issued in the next several weeks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know you'd start the process right away for $1,500 a piece.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We agreed to move up the third payment to July one, I believe.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have made movements since the tentative agreement, because we are really trying to do this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if no confidence vote came after the meeting, that's one thing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But now it's the narrative that we're disrespecting them again.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And again, I think it kills us all because you all have children in the schools or had children in the schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These teachers have been and are my children's teachers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They're my children's, have been tutored by our wonderful teachers, have been coached by our teachers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They're my friends.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My sister left the district recently, but they're family, some of whom won't even look at us, won't write recommendations for our kids.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I mean, I can't talk personally about that,

[Lungo-Koehn]: so that students with disabilities are provided access to post-secondary education and a college life.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Presentations of the public not to begin before 7 p.m., regular meetings of the school committee include this presentations of the public agenda item to give any resident the opportunity to place a presentation before the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A resident may only present once at a meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These presentations are an opportunity for the public to make a presentation to the committee, but are not opportunities for dialogue with the committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If one or more members

[Lungo-Koehn]: committee wishes to have a conversation about the topic presented, a member may request that the item be added to a subsequent regular meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The details for submitting the presentation can be found within the policy BEDH, public comment and presentations of the public.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So to the policy, any resident in the audience may give permission, be given permission to speak once on any item on the agenda for up to three minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The speaker is expected to keep their comments

[Lungo-Koehn]: To the item on the agenda speaker must begin their comments by providing their full name and full met for the street dress where they reside.

[Lungo-Koehn]: welcoming inclusive communities, both the value school committee and aspirational goal, we ask your help in achieving this goal and value perspective, please admit schools are exempt from this policy, the voice of our police welcome on all matters.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When a non-Metro resident employee is participating in public comment or submitting a presentation publicly with their home address and identify themselves as an employee of the Metropolitan Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know we have an associated motion that I'll read under new business, which we move suspension of the rules for 2022-51 offered by Member Graham and Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the Medford School Committee unanimously approved the following resolution on 12-6-2021, whereas the school committee is committed to achieving the mission statement of the Medford Public Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford Public Schools is a caring educational partnership of school, family, and community designed to ensure that all students are afforded a safe and healthy learning environment in which they develop the knowledge, skills, and attitudes to reach their full academic and personal potential.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas the effects of the pandemic have exasperated challenges in school climate and culture nationwide and here in Medford, therefore be it resolved that the Medford Public Schools will issue an RFP to perform a climate and culture assessment of Medford High School

[Lungo-Koehn]: to be completed before the end of the academic year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The RFP will seek a qualified and independent vendor to conduct a survey of staff, students, and families who are part of the high school community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And be it resolved that the project scope will include recommendations to address moving forward in a manner that prioritizes a healthy school community and contends with the district's past handling of incidences that are race, gender, and bullying based.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had also resolved the recommendations will outline organizational, structural, professional development, and curriculum-based changes needed to address the findings and achieve our district-wide mission.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had further resolved that the school committee authorizes an expenditure of up to 50,000 to complete this important initiative, and that the superintendent will return to the school committee to seek authorization for additional funds should the qualified bids received at the bid opening be in excess of this authorization.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and whereas the resolution was amended to include the middle schools in the scope of the assessment, now be it resolved, the administration provide a report of all actions to date to fill this resolution, including the reasons for any delay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specifically, the Medford School Committee will be discussing ongoing collective bargaining negotiations with multiple bargaining units in a pending litigation matter.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm happy to announce that by unanimous vote, we took a major step to pay equity for our Kids Corner and paraprofessionals.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that was a 7-0 vote, and those contracts have been ratified, which is great news.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have number seven, presentations of the public, not to begin before seven.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Regular meetings of the school committee include this presentation of the public agenda item.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To give any resident the opportunity to place a presentation before the school committee, a resident may only present once at a meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These presentations are an opportunity for the public to make a presentation to the committee, but not an opportunity for dialogue of the committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If one or more members of the committee wishes to have a conversation about the topic presented, a member may request the item be added

[Lungo-Koehn]: to a subsequent regular meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The details for submitting a presentation can be found in our policy, public comment and presentations to the public and pursuant to policy BEDH, public comment and presentations to the public, any resident in the audience may be given permission to speak once on any item for up to three minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The speaker is expected to keep their comments to the item on the agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The speaker must begin

[Lungo-Koehn]: their comments by providing their full name and full Medford Street address where they reside.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A welcoming, inclusive community is both a value of the school committee and an aspirational goal.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We ask for your help in achieving this goal and value your perspective.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Employees in Medford Public Schools are exempt from the residency requirement of this policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The voice of our employees is welcomed on all matters before the body.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When a non-Medford resident employee is participating in public comment or submitting a presentation of the public,

[Lungo-Koehn]: they will include their home address and identify themselves and as employee of the Metro Public Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do have a resident on the call who would like to make a presentation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The votes of the member school committee are considered binding on the delegate unless the language as presented that 9-12-22 meeting is different from the language up for final adoption at the delegate assembly on November 4th, 2022.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The reason votes are otherwise considered guidance is that the exact language voted on during the assembly can be modified by amendments during the assembly and returning to the school committee for a vote on the final language is not possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just think if you want to, if you want to come to the microphone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Name and address of the record?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: if I could just address that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I've attended in June with member Graham, the meeting and the bargaining session, which was a couple of weeks ago, I believe.

[Lungo-Koehn]: August 25th, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I attended those because we were at a point where we really couldn't financially move any further.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think the union pointed out in June

[Lungo-Koehn]: the capacity for the city based on the budget analyzation was 2.25%.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So Anthony, I hear you, but we have no more room to move.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a bargaining with almost 20 other unions that all deserve increases.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are at an impasse.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we knew that when I was there on the 25th, if I knew we had already voted for that, we would have told you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We didn't, we didn't know that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's no more room to move.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've moved higher than we can afford, is the truth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thanks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, everybody, for being here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Item number five.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Oh, I was gonna move on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for suspension of the rules by member Rousseau, seconded by?

[Lungo-Koehn]: By member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: 22-43?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: offered by member McLaughlin, member Stone, member Rousseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One of the Medford public school district's highest priorities is school safety.

[Lungo-Koehn]: While we focus on all areas of safety, this particular resolution has a focus on gun violence prevention through the leadership of the district and forming, sharing empowerment and education of our school community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the safety and wellbeing of our students, teachers, and staff is a top priority of Medford public schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas in the United States, gun violence is the leading cause of death in children and teens.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas evidence strongly suggests that secure firearm storage is an essential component to any effective strategy to keep schools and students safe.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas an estimated 4.6 million American children live in households with at least one loaded, unlocked firearm.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas every year, roughly 350 children under the age of 18 unintentionally shoot themselves or someone else.

[Lungo-Koehn]: about one unintentional shooting per day, and 70% of those incidences take place inside a home, whereas 1,200 children and teens die by gun suicide each year, and over 80% of children under age 18 who died by firearm suicide used a gun belonging to a family member.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is hard to even read.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No, no, it's just, whereas research shows that secure firearm storage practices are associated with up to

[Lungo-Koehn]: up to a 78% reduction in risk of self-inflicted firearm injuries and up to an 85% reduction in the risk of unintentional firearm injuries among children and teens, whereas the incidence of gun violence on school grounds, up to 80% of shooters under the age of 18 obtain their guns from their own home or that of relatives or friends, whereas the U.S.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Secret Service National Threat Assessment Center recommends the importance of appropriate storage of weapons because many school attackers

[Lungo-Koehn]: used firearms acquired from their homes, whereas keeping students, teachers, and staff safe from the threat of gun violence should be the responsibility of all adult stakeholders at each of our school sites, whereas across the country, lawmakers, community members, and local leaders are working together to implement public awareness campaigns, such as the Be Smart program, which is endorsed by the National PTA and encourages secure gun storage practices and highlights the public safety risks

[Lungo-Koehn]: of unsecured guns, where secure storage of firearms is a legal requirement in Massachusetts pursuant to general law chapter 140, section 133L and 131C.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Failure to comply with the secure storage laws can lead to criminal prosecution, jail time, fines, or revocation of FID card or license, depending on the offense.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends storing firearms unloaded, locked, and separate from ammunition,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas, in order to continue with preventative measures to increase student and school safety, we must act now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Therefore, be it resolved that the Medford School Committee directs the superintendent and staff to update the student handbook to include information about parents' legal obligations regarding the secure storage of firearms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Resolved that the school committee directs the superintendent and staff to create an appropriate direct communication in the form of a letter or email to parents and guardians that explains the importance of secure firearm storage to protect minors from

[Lungo-Koehn]: accessing unsecured firearms and their legal obligation consistent with the Massachusetts Safe Storage Law.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Notification will be done as soon as possible and included on the district website and in annual registration materials at each school site.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We resolve that the Medford School Committee and superintendent will continue to work with local law enforcement agencies, health agencies, and nonprofit organizations to collaborate and increase efforts to inform district parents, guardians, and caregivers

[Lungo-Koehn]: their obligations regarding secure storage of firearms in their homes and vehicles.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Absolutely.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I don't know if any other committee member wants to speak, but I too met with Moms Demand Action.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Great cause, I believe in it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know the chief of police does.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know our board of health director then emailed the chief of police and myself and said, do you know about this group?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then we said, we're on board.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, we want safe gun storage.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It just is a no brainer.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So thank you for being here and all that you do for our community and it will save lives.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'll let you name and address.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, motion for approval by Member McLaughlin, seconded by Member Hays and all of us, Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We support the resolution.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, member Rousseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Resolution one regarding sanctuary laws for transgender students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Resolution two, to increase the maximum balance allowed by the special education reserve fund.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Resolution three, membership of the board of elementary and secondary education.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Resolution four, preserving local governance of Massachusetts schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Resolution five, personal financial literacy education.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Resolution six, establishment of a regional school assessment reserve fund.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The votes of the Medford School Committee are considered binding on the delegate unless the language as presented at the September 12th, 2022 meeting is different from the language up for final adoption at the delegate assembly on November 4th, 2022.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The reason votes are otherwise considered guidance is that the exact language voted on during the assembly can be modified by amendments during the assembly and returning to the school committee for a vote on the final language is not possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the Medford Public Schools is committed to supporting the academic, social, emotional, and physical needs of our students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the Medford Public Schools is committed to ensuring a safe and secure teaching and learning environment for all students and staff.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas women, girls, and LGBTQI plus students and adults across the United States continue to face discrimination, harassment, and barriers to equal educational opportunities.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now therefore be it resolved that the Medford School Committee calls on the Massachusetts Congressional Delegation to offer their support to the U.S.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Department of Education's 2022 proposed amendments to its Title IX

[Lungo-Koehn]: regulations that will, as described in the government's fact sheet, restore vital protections for students in our nation's schools, providing clear rules to help meet their Title IX obligation and strengthen protections for LGBTQI plus students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number two, directs the superintendent to transmit official copies of this resolution to the following Senator Elizabeth Warren, Senator Edward Markey, and Congresswoman Catherine Clark.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number two, we have it be resolved, the initial meeting to discuss the superintendent's goals be moved to the fall of 2022, offered by myself.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just ask for a motion for approval on that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: By member Kreatz, seconded by member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Would anybody like to speak?

[Lungo-Koehn]: If I may, from the chair, I just also think it's time to show a little respect to our superintendent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And she did ask that she take the summer to review data and to really be able to help us outline those goals.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I want to give her that opportunity.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I put this motion forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think we can do it in the early fall, but I think she deserves that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think what we're doing tonight today is pushing that timeline.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I can amend my resolution to read, be it resolved the initial meeting to discuss the superintendent's goals, be moved to the fall of 2022 with the finalization early winter.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm pushing the timeline.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So if it was broken up in two parts in the last resolution, I thought that's what you had asked.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You wanted to outline of how we should, because the first resolution says initial meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think we should outline when the final, you know, we can outline when the final meeting will be, or I just don't want it to be, we need to make sure it's changed from that September 30 date, because that doesn't meet,

[Lungo-Koehn]: the nature of the resolution number two, which we're gonna be voting on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it can be late fall or it can be early winter.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think we just need to change that September 30th date, because based on how the committee votes, I don't think we're gonna meet that September 30th date.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I second the motion.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion on the floor as amended, seconded by Member McLaughlin, seconded by Member Kreatz.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Second.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.
