[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number six, presentations of the public.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Regular meetings of the school committee include this presentations of the public agenda item to give any resident the opportunity to place a presentation before the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A resident may only present once at any meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These presentations are an opportunity for the public to make a presentation to the committee, but are not opportunities for dialogue with the committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If one or more members of the committee wishes to have a conversation about the topic presented, a member may request that the item be added to the subsequent regular meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The details for submitting a presentation to be found within the policy be DH public comment and presentation of the public.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Tonight we do not have any public participation, public comment, pursuant to policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: public comment and presentations, the public, any resident in the audience may be given permission to speak once on any item of the agenda up to three minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The speaker is expected to keep their comments to the item on the agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The speaker must begin their comments by providing a full name and full Medford street address where they reside.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Residents may also submit their comments by writing to the superintendent of schools prior to the meeting or by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: prior to or during the item on the agenda written comments must be kept to a length that allows for them to be read into the record in less than three minutes, or the comments will be summarized with the Secretary of the school committee, a welcoming inclusive community is both a value of the school committee and an aspirational goal.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We ask for your help in achieving this goal and value your perspective.

[Lungo-Koehn]: When writing or emailing please provide this required information.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number one, the name and number of the item on the agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number two, your first and last name.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number three, your full Medford Street address, where you reside.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And number four, your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I believe we addressed the one email we had.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number seven is continued business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have two more items, nothing under continued business, two items under number eight, new business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First up, the Medford school committee may send one delegate and one alternate delegate to the MASC slash mass annual joint conference for the purpose of voting during the delegate assembly on the resolutions of the MASC.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number three, given that 10% of the human population is left-handed and in some classrooms, Medford Public Schools utilizes half desks, which are designed for the handedness of the individuals using the desk.

[Lungo-Koehn]: By January 1st, 2022, every classroom will have sufficient left-handed desks in place for the number of students that are left-handed in that space.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If information cannot be ascertained to the number of students that are left-handed, then 10% of the desk count in classrooms that have

[Lungo-Koehn]: These types of desk will be for the left handed students, offered by member so member Graham and member McLaughlin, who would like to speak first, as the South as a South by myself.

[Lungo-Koehn]: She works with the council, she works with the mayor's office, she works with the city and all department heads.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that being- Her opinion stands, so it could create a conflict, but if you needed money, just like you did for the zoning consultant, which we were happy to give you, and you've been working diligently on that, then we'll take it by case by case basis.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Kim's the city solicitor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And definitely, I think Solicitor Scanlon would agree to work on that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's what happens now, out of respect for Solicitor Scanlon, a department head will say, I need somebody for protection of wetlands.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Attorney Scanlon will talk to somebody at KP Law and get the proper referral for whatever department head needs that attorney.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we can try to work out sort of the same scenario with the council.

[Lungo-Koehn]: out of respect for solicitor Scanlon, she'll know everything that comes into the office and she's managing everything that's going on city council wise mayor's office and every other department within the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I'll throw up both ideas and we'll see what we can come up with.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So the way the process goes now is the city clerk sends it up to my office.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I sign off and it referred to attorney Scanlon and then attorney Scanlon.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I mean, I refer anything legal to the solicitors offers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't think there's anything.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You just contact Attorney Scanlon and say we have a resolution on the agenda for such and such an issue.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, I will try to get it direct, but if it's a resolution, it comes to my office for sign off.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If it's a resolution.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But if you want to contact Attorney Scanlon like you would call her anyway,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Special school committee meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please be advised that on Thursday, June 24th, 2021 at 6 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: there will be a special school committee meeting held through remote participation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, chapter 30A, section 18, and the Governor's March 15th, 2020 order imposing strict

[Lungo-Koehn]: limitations and the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public in our parties with a right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford and Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording, transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast channel 15 and Verizon channel 45 at 6 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since the meeting will be held remotely, participants can log or call in by using the following link or call-in number.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One of the numbers, 1-929-205-6099.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please enter meeting ID 917-8155-7347 when prompted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name, your Medford Street address with your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The agenda will be as follows.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the superintendent's recommendations posted publicly on June 18th, 2021 for a fiscal year 22 operating budget for the Medford Public Schools of $67,461,003 contingent upon the eventual appropriation by the Medford City Council.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The district administration will ask the Medford School Committee to endorse a series of strategic investments made possible through the use of ESSER II and ESSER III funding aimed at mitigating the impacts of school year 2021-2022 of the instructional disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic during school year 2019-2020 and school year 2020-2021.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We will go into executive session and not reconvene after.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Good evening, everybody.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford School Committee, June 14th, 2021, Howard Alden Memorial Chambers, Medford City Hall.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Regular meeting, 6.30 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We will post in the City of Medford or Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name, your Medford Street address, your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You can call in by using number 1929-205-6099.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please enter meeting ID when prompted 939-6008

[Lungo-Koehn]: 9, 8, 3, 7.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm to be resolved that the regular school committee meetings be posted for its start time at 6.30 PM with the understanding that the actual meeting may begin any time thereafter if an executive session or committee of the whole meeting held prior to the meeting is elongated.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Subcommittee meetings will be scheduled by the chairperson of the school committee at a time which is convenient for the subcommittee members and the administrative team.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All meetings will be recorded and made accessible to the public.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Offered by member Kreatz and member van de Kloot.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is there a motion on the floor to approve?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seconded by Member Van der Kloot.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, four in the affirmative, three in the negative, motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number three, on February 3rd, 2020, this body unanimously voted to make Medford a hunger-free community, and in light of the pending federal legislation, the Universal Schools Meal Program Act of 2021, it is requested the administration plan for all school meals to be provided at no charge to students at the commencement of the fiscal, of the 2021 school year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Achieving our unanimously approved goal to make Medford

[Lungo-Koehn]: hunger free requires action, regardless of whether the above pending legislation fails to become law.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The request is that the administration offers all school meals at no cost to students and that all funding sources be considered, including ESSER grants.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If ESSER grant funding cannot be utilized and there are no other sources of revenue, the administration will provide an update to the Medford School Committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: at our first meeting in September on the projected financial impact to our budget, but the policy of free meals will be implemented nonetheless.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Offered by Member Ruseau, Member Mustone, Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: $2 a day, 4,000 kids a day, $1.5 million?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Russell?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't think that's a fair question to Member Van der Kloot.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if I may, from the chair, I think that's the point that maybe this needs to be amended with,

[Lungo-Koehn]: We make sure we have a broad communication plan so we capture anybody that may need free and reduced lunch.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But for me, I have three children.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If they ate school lunch every day, it'd be over $1,500.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And those that can afford it, we should be paying it, because $1.5 million or whatever it might be to provide free lunch to those that can't afford it as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have to think about that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The city has been, if I may, the city has been dedicating resources through a number, especially CDBG monies to partner organizations like the Greater Boston Food Bank that does the Mystic Market.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we are taking steps that are realistic and we're able to afford and maintain for years to come.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is there an amendment to just get the funding to find out how much this would cost first?

[Lungo-Koehn]: We would need to put it in our budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It needs to be somewhere in our budget to pay for everything.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need to know how much it will cost and how we're going to pay for it, correct?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mister Mister Gordon, please the microphone.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval was seconded.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Coach Kelly truly exemplified Mustang pride.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Community participation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Any citizen in the audience may be given permission to speak once at a school committee meeting regarding any item on the agenda for up to three minutes on any one item.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A community participation portion of the agenda will be established, which will give any citizen the privilege of placing any item before the school committee to be heard on any item.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Any item to be presented must be submitted in writing to the superintendent of schools by the Wednesday noon prior to the scheduled meeting with a maximum of five minutes allowed for any one presentation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Public participation emails, questions, or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name, your Medford Street address, your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 30A, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: specific information in the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with a right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post in the City of Medford and Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording, transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast channel 22 or Verizon 43 at 7 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You can call in by using phone number 1-929-205-6099.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please enter meeting ID 968-8468-0306 when prompted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Your Medford Street address, your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Executive session 545 regular meeting 6 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 30A, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 orders, imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So specific information, the general guidelines for remote participation, members of the public and our parties with a right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford and Medford community media websites and audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name, your Medford street address, your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You can call in by using number 1-929-205-6099

[Lungo-Koehn]: please enter meeting ID 950-4590-1152 when prompted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin, if you could call the roll, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Present.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Six present, one absent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we could just rise and salute the flag, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford School Committee will reconvene in public session following the executive session.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number two, beginning in the fall of 2021, an extract of the email addresses on file and school brains or whatever system is used for tracking parent caregiver emails will be created twice each school year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This extract will be used to create a white list within our email provider to allow emails in and out of

[Lungo-Koehn]: for any email on that white list for grades K through eight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Presently K through eight emails are blocked from any incoming or outgoing email now within the Medford public schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And this creates a problem for parents, caregivers, and students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Work arounds are challenging, expensive, and disruptive.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And students and families should not have to purposefully circumvent our systems to perform perfectly valid activities such as communication with our students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please be advised that on Wednesday, May 19th, 2021 at 7 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: there will be a committee of the whole meeting held through remote participation pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order suspended certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 30A, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15th, 2020 order imposing strict limitations of the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted through remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and our parties with a right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford and Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast Channel 22 and Verizon Channel 43 at 7 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You can call in by using 1-929-205-6099.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please enter meeting ID 913-5189-6187 when prompted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name, your Medford Street address, your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The agenda will be as follows.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Discussion of the development of the operating budget and budgetary priorities of the Medford Public Schools for fiscal year 2022.

[Lungo-Koehn]: as it pertains specifically to Central Office of the Medford Public Schools, including a variety of departments under the auspices of the Office of Superintendent and the Office of Finance and Operations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Summary of the Medford Public School budget presentations made throughout the course of all five Committee of the Whole budget meetings on May 3rd, May 6th, May 13th, May 18th, and May 19th.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Signed, Dr. Marice Edouard-Vincent, Superintendent of Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I will turn it over to Dr. Edouard-Vincent and Mr. Murphy to get us started.

[Lungo-Koehn]: After we call the roll.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sorry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please be advised that on Tuesday, May 18th, 2021 at 7pm, there will be a Committee of the Whole meeting held through remote participation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 30A, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15th, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting in the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: specific information, the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public in parties with a right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford and Medford Community Media websites and audio or video recording, transcript, other comprehensive record and proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast Channel 22 and Verizon Channel 43 at 7 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You can call in by using phone number 1-929-205-6099.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please enter meeting ID 9267229

[Lungo-Koehn]: 6484 when prompted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name, your Medford street address, your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: people from different cities and towns, and almost half, at least half of the questions we ask, they still cannot answer.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So right now, water, sewer, broadband infrastructure, we can use our money for plugging revenue gaps, but it's just seeming extremely restrictive.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we are waiting for more guidance on what we can even try to propose

[Lungo-Koehn]: to pay for so that we can free up some general fund money to supplement on the school side.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As of right now, it's just, it's so restrictive, it's kind of crazy the amount we'd be able to spend based on the guidance we have.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we know there's ways we're hiring a consultant that's hopefully starting signing a contract on Monday that's gonna help guide us through this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it's really late in the process, but guidance, the 152 page guidance wasn't released until

[Lungo-Koehn]: last Wednesday or Thursday, so we're still navigating.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I am trying to get more money for the schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number seven, community participation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Any citizen in the audience may be given permission to speak once at school committee meetings regarding any item on the agenda for up to three minutes on any one item.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Community participation portion of the agenda will be established, which will give any citizen the privilege of placing any item before the school committee or be heard on any item.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Any item to be presented must be submitted in writing to the superintendent of schools by Wednesday at noon prior to the scheduled meeting, with a maximum of five minutes allowed for any one presentation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Public participation emails, questions, or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Your first and last name, your Medford Street address, your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number 11, new business, ad hoc report request.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Fossil fuel utilization at the new school's target date, June 7th, 2021.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The report is attempting, yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three paragraphs, so might as well read it so everybody can understand it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The report is attempting to answer what, number one, what fossil fuel consumption at each of the new schools is in a typical year to the age of all systems that rely on fossil fuels.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three, what is the fuel used?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Four, if a ballpark estimate can be provided to replace the fossil fuel systems with a pure electric option, what would the cost of replacement be?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And similarly, if possible, what would the impact be on the energy cost compared?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Current cost, new cost, a ballpark is all that is requested.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if that cannot be determined,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Without an RFP or significant research, then this is not a required element of this report.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Background as the federal and state governments have moved on fossil fuel reduction in Medford has landed on the top 10 communities in Massachusetts on our energy reduction.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is both reasonable and appropriate for us to consider the fossil fuel consumptions in our schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Exclusive of the high school is on purpose here due to the extent of the work that would be required to include in this report.

[Lungo-Koehn]: data elements expected.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number one, building name.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Two, building system.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three, age of each system.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Four, average annual cost.

[Lungo-Koehn]: By building, if possible, for all new schools, if per building is not possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Five, amount of fuel used by each building and system for each building or for all schools, whichever level of detail is available.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Six, ballpark costs to replace each system with an electric version.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This should not include

[Lungo-Koehn]: any MSBA or other grants, just a pure cost, including the system installation, again, if possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Was there more?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Oh my goodness, I thought it was, that's all I thought it was.

[Lungo-Koehn]: in each of the previous four years, including 2020, 2021, through the date when the data is pulled to the report.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We anticipate as a result of the difference in students being identified during the pandemic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: background, early detection of student needs is financially reasonable and what is best for students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Understanding the size of this problem and strategizing about how to compensate for differences resulting from the pandemic to ensure students with special and educational needs are identified as quickly as possible and whatever additional supporting resources are made available and prioritized.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford school committee meeting date may 6 2021 committee the whole meeting, please be advised that on Thursday may 6 2021 at 7pm, there'll be a committee the whole meeting held for remote participation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Soon to Governor Baker's March 12 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law chapter 30 a section 18 and the governor's March 15 2020 order imposing strict limitations and number of people that may gather in one place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties of the right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post in the City of Medford or Medford Community Media websites and audio or video recording transcript to other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: all the needs of the city, including our children, which I care about very much.

[Lungo-Koehn]: is not gonna be beneficial for the city next year or the year after.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have a question about the, not necessarily budget related, but in a way, you mentioned the district and DESE's recommended fully back to school for all students, unless a medical exemption, but that wouldn't be, how would we, do we know how many we're expecting to potentially have a medical exemption?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And what does that look like per grade level and the cost too?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Or how will we manage that?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Will that be streaming from home while the teachers are in school?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, so are we ready to make that decision with regards to no remote, put the definition out and then kind of take a survey of our families for next year so that we can kind of get an idea before June 30th when we have to make the budget official?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Edouard-Vincent, did you want to say something?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No other questions from the committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: April 26, 2021, Committee of the Whole meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please be advised that on Monday, April 26, 2021 at 5 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: there will be a Committee of the Whole meeting held through remote participation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Purpose of the meeting is to identify the members of an advisory committee to rename the Columbus Elementary School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 30A, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order, imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Methodist School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting

[Lungo-Koehn]: can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording

[Lungo-Koehn]: transcript to other comprehensive record proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed through Method Community Media on Comcast channel 22 and Verizon channel 43 at 5 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You can call in by using 1-929-205-6099.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please enter meeting ID 98188625305 when prompted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name, your Medford Street address, your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The agenda will be as follows, creation of an advisory committee to rename the Columbus Elementary School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Do you all want me to read the policy as outlined on page two, three and four?

[Lungo-Koehn]: All right.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Edwin-Vincent, should I read the, I can read, it will take me a few minutes, but advisory committee selection on April 26, 2021, a committee of the whole be held to select and confirm the 23 voting members advisory committee and one ex-officio members follows.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Up to three selected from the Columbus School staff, Principal Kathy Kaye, and the one MHS student will be announced.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Each school committee member will select two members for the advisory committee from the valid applications received and will state the names publicly.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that an applicant is selected by more than one school committee member, the members will continue to name applicants until a total of 14 advisory committee members have been named by the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three additional names will be selected by lottery from the remaining applicants.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One of the mayor's appointments will serve as chair of the advisory committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The chair will be responsible for scheduling meetings, posting meetings, chairing meetings, and organizing a presentation

[Lungo-Koehn]: the school committee once the final names are determined.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The chair will be a voting member of the advisory committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The mayor will announce the chair of the committee prior to the selection of other members.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Current school committee members will not be considered for this position.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event the committee membership reaches an even number, the mayor will make an additional selection from the pool of applicants.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The mayor will reach out to the historical society, historical commission,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and our district commission to enlist the help of a member who will serve as a resource to the advisory committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The historian will be an ex officio non-voting member.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Participation by the Columbus school staff and students in recognition that the staff and students in the Columbus school are dedicated to their school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee requests the principal to create a representative group of staff and solicit input from their colleagues.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, student input is highly desirable and if it is feasible, student participation will be encouraged

[Lungo-Koehn]: in any way the principal deems to be workable in this very short period of time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: By April 16th, 2021, the principal of the Columbus School or Desnee as well as up to three staff members selected by peers will be appointed as voting members to the advisory committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Families of Columbus Elementary School community are urged to apply for membership on the advisory committee through the public application process or to submit their suggestions via the suggestion form.

[Lungo-Koehn]: By April 16th, 2021, a Medford High School student who attended the Columbus School

[Lungo-Koehn]: is a member of the CCSR and who is able to make the time commitment will be selected by his or her peers to be a member of the advisory committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event there is no applicant interested in the role, the principal of Medford High School may select another member of the high school community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Work of the advisory committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: At the April 26th Committee of the Whole meeting, a list of the names submitted for consideration will be made public and forwarded to the advisory committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: File containing the emails from community members on the topic of the renaming will be made available to the advisory committee members so that all advisory committee members are aware of the opinions and concerns expressed by our community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The advisory committee will develop criteria for evaluating the names.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The advisory committee will determine the process for vetting the names, narrowing the field and submitting

[Lungo-Koehn]: no more than three finalists to the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Press relations will be directed through the advisory committee chair and members of the advisory committee are urged to send press contacts to the chair.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Advisory committee meetings are public meetings and must follow all requirements of the open meeting law.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Superintendent will provide a note taker and create minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is expected that the advisory committee will need to meet three to five times and a majority of voting members will be required to reach a quorum for the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The advisory committee will hold at least one public hearing or issue one public input survey to solicit feedback on the opinions they are considering per the charge of this resolution at at least one of their meetings.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Advisory committee members may withdraw from participation by notifying the chair and will not be counted in subsequent quorum and voting requirements.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Removal of a member is permitted by a majority vote of the advisory committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The chair will notify the remaining members of the advisory committee of the reduction in membership.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No new members will be added to the advisory committee due to vacancies.

[Lungo-Koehn]: While consensus is always preferred, a simple majority of the total number of advisory committee members will be required to select up to three names that will be forwarded to the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A majority vote of the total number of committee members and not a vote of the quorum present is required for this vote.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The advisory committee will present the recommendations for the new names of the Columbus Elementary School no later than May 24th, 2021.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A presentation will be given explaining the way that the recommendation was arrived at and why the selected names were chosen.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If a majority of the advisory committee votes to recommend a timeline change to the school committee, they may do so.

[Lungo-Koehn]: At that time, the school committee will vote to approve or decline this recommendation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Timeline changes shall not exceed a date of July 31st, 2021.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Final selection of the new name.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Once the Methodist School Committee has received the names and presentation, the committee will vote either that evening or at a subsequent meeting

[Lungo-Koehn]: not later than June 7th, 2021 to approve the recommendation, given the authority for naming of public school buildings, the school committee's authority alone, per mass general law.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Signed very truly yours, Dr. Maurice Edwin-Vinson, superintendent of schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin, if you could take the roll, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: She's, okay, let me, there you go.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There we go, here, sorry, I was muted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: present seven, present zero, absent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have number one, resolutions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, member.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Best news I've heard all night.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Skipping page three then, we're on to number two, whereas the current school committee policy, GCA professional staff position states, all professional staff positions in the school system will be created initially by the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is this committee's intent to activate a sufficient number of positions to accomplish the school system's goals and objectives?

[Lungo-Koehn]: to provide for the equitable staffing of each school building.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Although such positions may remain temporarily unfilled, only the school committee may abolish a position it has created.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Each time a new position is established by the committee, the superintendent will present for the committee's approval a job description for the position, which specifies the job holder's qualifications and the job's performance responsibilities.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The superintendent will maintain a comprehensive set of job descriptions for all positions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Note job descriptions for professional staff positions that are available for review in the office of the superintendent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it resolved that the school committee amends policy GCA, professional staff positions, to ensure transparency, relevancy, and accountability across all professional staff functions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All professional staff positions in the school system will be created initially by the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is the committee's intent to activate a sufficient

[Lungo-Koehn]: number of positions to accomplish the school system's goals and objectives, and to provide for the equitable staffing of each school building.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Professional staff is defined as the department head, central office staff, nursing, or nursing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Superintendent will maintain a comprehensive list of positions and a set of job descriptions for all positions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All job descriptions will be reviewed every three years and presented to the school committee for approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Job descriptions will contain a last review date.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Superintendent will establish a review cycle for all positions descriptions within 60 days of the adoption of this policy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The initial review cycle will last for no longer than three years and conclude by September 1st, 2024.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Effective September 1st, 2021, the comprehensive list and current job descriptions for professional staff positions are available for review by the public on the Metro Public Schools website.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Each time a new position is established by the committee, the superintendent will present for the committee's approval a job description for the position, which specifies the job holder's qualifications and the job's performance responsibilities.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Although such positions may remain temporarily unfilled, only the committee may abolish the position it has created.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All positions unfilled for the entire school year will be reported to the committee annually no later than June 1st with an explanation for the vacancy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All positions that remain unfilled for more than two consecutive years will be presented to the committee to be abolished no later than June 1st.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event the superintendent wishes to maintain any positions that have been unfilled for more than two consecutive school years, the superintendent must explain the rationale and plan to fill the position and get approval from the committee to continue the unfilled position for an additional year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: offered by member Graham and member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I will turn it over to you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Anything to add member Rousseau?

[Lungo-Koehn]: and then move it to approve?

[Lungo-Koehn]: If I may, from the chair, I don't disagree with you about it being a bit confusing, although I agree with the premise of making sure.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, I agree with the premise of that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They're updated.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I also agree that we should probably ask the administration a reasonable timeframe, because we're doing this on the city side, trying to update all job descriptions, and it does take some time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham, then Mr. Murphy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member van de Kloot.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau, then Member Vandekloot, did you?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And to that point, I mean, I don't, I don't know if I'm missing a part on my sheet, but it just says defined as department head, central staff, nursing, and the sentence is incomplete.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I wouldn't even know what the rest entails.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That should just probably be a period.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Oh, with an and.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, so motion for approval by Member Ruseau as amended to October 1st, 2021 for a comprehensive list and a list of the current job descriptions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 30A, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order, posing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted

[Lungo-Koehn]: via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with a right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public could

[Lungo-Koehn]: can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post in the City of Medford or Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceeding as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is the Medford School Committee meeting, April 12th, 2021.

[Lungo-Koehn]: remote meeting by Zoom.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name, your Medford Street address, your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Medford Public Schools is inviting you to a scheduled Zoom meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One of the phone numbers to call in is 1-929-205-6099.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We hear you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We hear you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I thank the administration for doing this work and continuing the work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Next up, we have old business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Go to the order offered by member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to table by Member McLaughlin, seconded by Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to table has been approved.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number 11, communications.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't believe we have any.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've handled five and a half hours of communication.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number 12, new business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Do you wanna do this tonight or you wanna move it to the next agenda?

[Lungo-Koehn]: for the first one tonight, okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Resolution in support of expedited COVID-19 vaccinations for students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas of April 12th, 2021, the coronavirus pandemic has infected over 30.4 million individuals in the United States and resulted in more than 551,638 deaths across the country and 17,185 in Massachusetts.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas our strong public education system, which is essential to the individual and community well-being of our society, is facing unprecedented challenges due to the coronavirus pandemic and lack of clear national, state, and local directional resources.

[Lungo-Koehn]: These challenges include, but are not limited to, the academic and social emotional toll on students, as well as the need to rapidly pivot to distance learning, clean and equip

[Lungo-Koehn]: school facilities to adapt to new health protocols and social distancing, assess and address the risks to teachers, staff, and students, whereas vaccines have proven to be the most effective strategy to reduce and eliminate the spread of infectious disease and are an important and necessary tool for eradicating disease and vaccines are anticipated to be approved for use for some school-aged children in the coming weeks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the current Commonwealth vaccine distribution system created access issues for eligible residents that could create greater access disparities among school-aged children.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas the Medford Public Schools is committed to the health and safety of its students and staff, now therefore be it resolved that the Medford School Committee, number one, calls on the state legislature, the governor, the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, create a vaccine rollout plan for school-aged children that puts the distribution in the hands of local officials and eliminates

[Lungo-Koehn]: accessibility barriers to students and their families.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number two, calls on the Massachusetts Association of School Committees to publicly advocate for local control of vaccine distribution for school-age children.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And three, directs the district superintendent to transmit official copies of this resolution to the following, the commissioner of DESE, the governor of Massachusetts, Senator Warren, Senator Markey, Congresswoman Clark,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Senator Jalen, Representative Donato, Garbaly, and Barber, and the Massachusetts Association of School Committees.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Offered by Member Graham and Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is there a motion on the floor with a second?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seconded by Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The motion is approved.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to table number two.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to table number two, seconded by

[Lungo-Koehn]: member Van der Kloot.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Van der Kloot, roll call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number two is tabled.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, I'm missing number three.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have, I'm sorry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I have the condolences.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number four is my page five, for some reason.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, I think it was a misprint.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: School committee resolution condolences.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Mr. James F. Jim McKinnon, a former English teacher, head football coach, and submaster at Medford High School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, the Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Mr. Alan K.

[Lungo-Koehn]: McDougall, former Mustang football captain of 1985 Greater Boston League champions, and former freshman football coach at Medford High School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Mr. Leon Appiani, the son of the late Mr. Leo Appiani, former math teacher and varsity boys basketball coach at Medford High School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, the Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Mr. Alfonso J. Citrano, great uncle of Mrs. Gina Citrano of the Medford Public Schools Business Office.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Amitunisa Bagam, mother-in-law of Math Director, Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Faiza Khan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we may all take a moment of silence.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion adjourned by Member McLaughlin, seconded by Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: in the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance members of the public will be permitted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we aren't able to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media websites and audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceeding as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Session one strategic plan round table.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The school committee is hosting these sessions to collaborate and share ideas that will help inform potential revisions to be made to the Medford Public Schools strategic plan.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Discussions will include, does Medford Public Schools current mission statement adequately describe the long range goals you feel Medford Public Schools should aspire to?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Why or why not?

[Lungo-Koehn]: What changes or suggestions do you have?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Does MPS current vision statement adequately describe what you feel Medford Public Schools should achieve in the next X amount of years?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Why or why not?

[Lungo-Koehn]: What input changes or suggestions do you have?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, what key actions does Medford Public Schools need to take to demonstrate forward progress towards our vision in so many years and in what timeframe?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Signed Dr. Marice Edouard-Vincent, Superintendent of the Medford Public Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Welcome, everybody.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I believe we're going to have facilitators and note takers in each room.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: that it's up to the superintendent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, Heather, name and address the record.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You have three minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Heather.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have been talking about it for a while.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have some surprises that are coming.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So they're getting there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Cushing, anything you want to elaborate on as well?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Dr. Cushing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mayor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number six.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No, Mayor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: member van de Kloot.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll send it forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thanks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Great question.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number six, report on the solar panel project at the Andrews Middle School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Alicia Hunt, director of energy environment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I did tell Alicia that I could handle this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know we were all given the documentation from Dr. Cushing today.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the main gist of the request

[Lungo-Koehn]: is for us to approve that the city may lease rooftop space on Madeline Duggar Andrews Public School to a third party for the purpose of installing solar panels to generate electricity for use by the school building and to lease a portion of the parking area to install carport solar panels.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No parking spaces will be removed to accommodate the carport solar panels, which will be supported above the parking spaces.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This request is a step in the project

[Lungo-Koehn]: that was previously before this body to install solar and storage at the Andrew School.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The solar and storage is intended to offset the energy use at the building, reducing the cost of electricity with the school and allowing the building to operate off grid in the event of a major electricity outage.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The approval of the school committee will allow the city to enter into an agreement with a third party to allow it to install, operate and maintain the solar panels on the roof and in the parking lot and to sell the electricity generated

[Lungo-Koehn]: to the city at a price which would not exceed the price the city would presently pay to its existing energy providers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The panels will be financed and owned by the third party.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by Member Ruseau, seconded by Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In light of recent events in Boston regarding the participation of the student representative to the school committee, conversation with the current representatives, Colin Bailey and David Mai, will take place at 4 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: on March 24th, 2021 at the Rules, Policy and Equity Subcommittee meeting to understand how they are experiencing participation as our student representatives, as well as what changes may be necessary to better integrate their voices and respect their participation as critical members of the committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham, seconded by Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Zero the negative paper is approved.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Offered by member Rousseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As Medford public schools continue to work towards implementing our value of equity and taking action to root out systems that work against equity, the after school and before school application processes will require demographic data on the students and families that apply for our limited enrollment in these programs.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This deep data will not be used to select applicants

[Lungo-Koehn]: but will be used in the future to guide new policy decisions and in our efforts to create a more equitable system.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Data will be connected to applicants so that we can understand how changes in policy affects enrollment and wait lists.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Unless member Ruseau, do you want to say anything or motion for approval?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to approve.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by Member McLaughlin, seconded by Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, I'm in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It says that might've been offered by Member Ruseau and Member Graham on my next page, page four.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So thank you both.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Helen Alpers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: mother of former superintendent of schools, administrative assistant, Denise Chiesa Mahoney, aunt of administrative assistant for early childhood program, Cheryl Alpers, and grandmother-in-law of director of humanities, Dr. Nicole Chiesa.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, the Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Robert Olson, a former custodian for the Medford Public Schools, husband of Lee Olson.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Medford School Committee expresses its sincere condolences to the family of Susan Bratton, known to many as Sue, was a graduate of Summerville High School and proud of it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: She received her bachelor and master's degree from Boston College in the field of language, Latin, which was her love.

[Lungo-Koehn]: She began her career over 20 years in the Medford Public Schools as a paraprofessional.

[Lungo-Koehn]: She started her employee at the Franklin School as a one-to-one with a student who had mobility problems.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Later, she spent time at the McGlynn Complex doing what she loved to do, work with children who needed special care.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Susan touched the lives of many students, parents, and faculty alike in the Medford Public Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Oh, wait, no, maybe it should be up to four.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, and then each school committee member, right now it reads, each school committee member will select a member for the advisory committee from the valid applications received and will state the names publicly in the event that an applicant is selected by more than one school committee member, the members will continue to name applicants until a total of seven advisory committee members have been made by the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Three additional names will be selected by lottery from the remaining applicants.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, member- Sorry, I'm sorry.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Can everybody just state a number of how many committee members you're thinking, you're not held to it, just so we can kind of have an idea moving forward through this list.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You want one member?

[Lungo-Koehn]: 20 plus.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The chair will notify the remaining members of the advisory committee of the reduction in membership.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Cushing, you ready?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Kevin Carve yellow and thank you to the city councilors for allowing us to give an update and be here for the next item, hopefully, which will be the proclamation for our

[Lungo-Koehn]: Board of Health director, staff and volunteers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just wanted to chime in when Councilor Marks asked about the 4,500 seniors and just to give some reassurance that when we first had the doses and we were setting up the clinic and the governor announced that we would be able to vaccinate 75 and older, the next day we scrambled, we had emergency meetings, we grabbed the help of the Medford Housing Authority, the West Medford Community Center,

[Lungo-Koehn]: the senior center came together, and we were very concerned that we would sell out of our appointments in 30 minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I wanted to reassure you that it was open for over a week before the state took the rest of our doses.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And before they took our doses, we were able to call between my office, the Board of Health,

[Lungo-Koehn]: our three partners, we were able to call every 75 year or older that had reached out to us and left a voicemail over the last week and get them that appointment and able to get as many people as we can appointments at the state sites as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I didn't want to just point that out that we are doing everything we can to respond to calls

[Lungo-Koehn]: to get appointments for people.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we were able to have that clinic open for a full week and get everybody in that needed an appointment that was 75 plus, which went amazingly that day.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we look forward to giving them their second dose this weekend.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I appreciate the time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I want to point out that we have

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think all of our Board of Health staff on the call, Sophie, Rose, Brooke, Sarah, Melanie, Penny, Wendy, I see you all there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I also see a number of our volunteers.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Patty Costas is here, Pat Hanson's here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'm sure I'm missing some, but I just want to point out that not only are we here for all of you tonight,

[Lungo-Koehn]: You're all here also to support Marion O'Connor, our board of health director and all the work that she has done with obviously the help of you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So you've got us through the last year and this is for you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I appreciate the council signing onto this proclamation that we will hang proudly at Medford City Hall for all to see.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So if I may, this is a proclamation of gratitude to the staff and volunteers of the Medford Board of Health in response to the COVID-19 global pandemic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Whereas the city of Medford along with the nation and the entire world has faced the effects of the COVID-19 global pandemic since the beginning of 2020.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas the virus has affected the lives of every single person in the city of Medford and has claimed the lives of over 500,000 people in the United States.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas the Medford Board of Health in response to this unprecedented public health and humanitarian crisis

[Lungo-Koehn]: immediately and boldly took steps to protect public health, deliver aid, and mitigate the spread of COVID-19 in our community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas more than 120 residents in both medical and non-medical fields have consistently volunteered time and efforts to the city's model R U OK program to provide food, medication, supplies, phone calls, vaccinations, and comfort to Medford residents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas together with the R U OK

[Lungo-Koehn]: volunteers and Medical Reserve Corps volunteers, the Board of Health has been able to provide critical aid and support to the Medford community within the past year, including more than 10,000 initial calls made to seniors with 2,500 additional calls for follow-up, more than 2,500 deliveries of meals, medication and supplies, contact tracing for nearly 5,000 local cases of COVID-19,

[Lungo-Koehn]: including daily case counts as high as 105, created Medford's first multilingual language resource line to connect residents with resources and services related to food security, housing, mental and behavioral assistance, and other related needs, and nearly 2,000 calls received in just over two months.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas in collaboration with administrators, staff,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and health workers at Medford public schools, coordinated and provided support for over 20,000 individual and pooled COVID-19 tests in Medford schools, allowing children to return to in-person learning safely and securely.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas despite limitations and supply from the Commonwealth, coordinated the direct vaccination of nearly 2000 people thus far in the city of Medford, including residents 75 and older during clinics and directly in homes for those unable to travel,

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas working with the Medford Council on Aging, Medford Housing Authority, and West Medford Community Center directly assisted more than 500 Medford seniors with making vaccine appointments, registration, and transportation to state-sponsored vaccine sites.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And whereas the Medford Board of Health, through Director Mary Ann O'Connor, the dedicated staff, and countless volunteers, has, from the onset of the virus one year ago, performed above and beyond the call of duty

[Lungo-Koehn]: for the benefit of the public health of the residents of the city of Medford, regardless of language spoken, economic situation, race, gender, immigration status, ability, benefit eligibility or religious affiliation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now, therefore, I as mayor of the city of Medford do hereby proclaim with profound gratitude to those who have worked tirelessly to protect public health and in remembrance of those we have lost

[Lungo-Koehn]: that the city of Medford extends its deepest thanks and appreciation to the Medford Board of Health Director, Marianne O'Connor, the staff and volunteers of the Medford Board of Health for their work in the past year and on behalf of the people of Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if I just may, it's been a really tough year for the community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's been a tough year for our volunteers, our staff, and our director, but they have come together.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They are a family, we are all a family, and we have been able to conquer the challenges that have come before us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And thank you to the city council for your support, and the school committee, and the school administration.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Together we've been able to get through it, and we have hope now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are vaccinating people.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's a wonderful thing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we're gonna continue to do the work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know Mirian O'Connor's family's here too.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Everybody just so proud of the work that you all have done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And thank you from the bottom of my heart as mayor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'm sure the city council feels the same.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Madam Mayor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we aren't able to do so, despite best efforts, we will post in the City of Medford and Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast Channel 22 and Verizon Channel 43 at 6 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All right, we're recording, we're live.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please be advised that on Monday, March 1st, 2020 at 4.30 PM, there'll be a committee of the whole meeting held through remote participation pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, chapter 30A, section 18, and the governor's March 15th, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specific information, the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording, transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast channel 22 and Verizon channel 43 at 4.30 PM.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One of the phone numbers you can call is 301-715-8592.

[Lungo-Koehn]: please enter meeting ID 97190023060 when prompted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since the meeting will be held remotely, participants can log or call in by using the following link or call-in number.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Regular meeting, 6 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 30A, Section 18 in the Governor's March 15, 2020 order.

[Lungo-Koehn]: posing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specific information, the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so despite best efforts, we will post in the city of Medford or Medford community media websites and audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford community media on Comcast channel 22 and Verizon channel 43 at 6 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specifically, the Medford School Committee will discuss ongoing negotiations and hold a grievance hearing filed by the Teamsters of the 25 pursuant to the relevant collective bargaining agreement.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 53% of the city's budget, it does go to the schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And when Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Patterson decided to do a 5% increase without the city's knowledge, that led to the three and a half million over level funding.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So yeah, I argue that we did not cut the budget, but I can see what your point, Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: DeRusso, a level funded budget seems like a cut budget when you talk about fixed costs that are going up every year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it's a tough one to swallow.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's a tough situation we are once again facing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Mr. Murphy, Member Van der Kloot, Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Mr. Murphy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Van der Kloot, then Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Van der Kloot.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, city versus school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So $17,223,842 went to the school's health insurance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's 81% of health insurance, where the city side is 19%.

[Lungo-Koehn]: maintenance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we do city and school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I can't have Alicia breaking it down every single department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think that would take far too long.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the scenario and the five to eight million, some of the lower end of that is without increases.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we're looking more towards the eight plus budget gap.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So what Biden has proposed could cover that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm hearing it come as soon as the end of March.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I am hesitant to start either budget until we, at least until the end of March, because that is, I don't know where we will find $8 million to cut.

[Lungo-Koehn]: just we've already turned over all the rocks here so definitely not um okay that that's helpful just to know like are we talking about a week a month or whatever okay thank you the last i've heard is by the end of march they're expecting it and just my fingers across and as soon as we hear something we will let school committee and city council know great thank you may i remember graham is there a motion on the floor mayor no

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's just to get accounting for the 1 million, which I would expect within the next month, month and a half, Mr. Murphy, but there's no motion.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think we trust that we will get that in one of the next, one of the two or three upcoming school committee meetings.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Van der Kloot?
