[Lungo-Koehn]: Number nine, communications.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then number 10 is new business, and we have one resolution offered by myself.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it resolved that the administration provide to the Medford School Committee an update on progress toward renovation and upgrades to the two Medford High School student restrooms as contemplated

[Lungo-Koehn]: by previous allocations of funding and direction by the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had further resolved that the administration be prepared to provide an update related to these projects at the next regular scheduled meeting of the Medford School Committee on March 8th, 2021 to determine what if any portion of the September 2020 capital improvement appropriation should be directed toward the advancement of these projects as well as adding additional bathroom upgrades to the list to be complete on or before the start of the next school year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I put this on the agenda.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know we voted on this probably almost a year ago.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And since that time, we had a number of upgrades that we've done to all of our schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Four and a half million has been put in to get our kids and teachers safely back to school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and part of that was HVAC and fans and windows and HEPA filters.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I know that building and grounds have been very busy, but I wanted this to be put on because I think the restroom projects are extremely important and where we were able to use CARES funding for all the other work.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know there's the 816,000, which we need to do a few things with, but once we figure out cost estimates for the security upgrades and the boiler,

[Lungo-Koehn]: really hope that we could do more than two bathrooms at the high school, because I know they sorely are in need of renovation and upgrading.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've heard that for quite some time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I thank Mr. McLaughlin for being on tonight and kind of giving us an update.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know member Kreatz has the building and grounds subcommittee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So some of this work obviously will flow through that, but I just think it's important the committee talk about that 816,000 in depth so that we can

[Lungo-Koehn]: work on getting that spent on much needed improvements in our district.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm just, I'm really concerned to make sure we get them done this summer while our students are not in and before the start of the school year, but I can pass it off to Mr. McLaughlin if you have any updates on that and then member crops.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Kreatz.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My only question on the RFP is if we're able to do more than two and put it up out to bid for two bathrooms and with the 816,000, we're able to do more than that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I want to make sure we can capitalize on how many we can do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham?

[Lungo-Koehn]: We could call one next week.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know Mr. Murphy, you have like three projects plus the potential ADA accessibility improvements in the front entrance that I think are the four projects that we could use for this 816.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I don't know how you want to handle that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, I'm interested in moving the process forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I didn't know it was at that stage when I inquired a couple of weeks ago.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just thought it kind of fell to the wayside because of all the HVAC improvements that were getting done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's 5.05, Medford School Committee, February 8th, 2020, remote meeting by Zoom, pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, Chapter 30A, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15th, 2020 order, imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting in the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specific information in the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast Channel 22 and Verizon Channel 43 at 6 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting of the Medford School Committee, virtual information, 5 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since the meeting will be held remotely, participants can log in or call in by using the following link or call-in number.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One of the numbers is 1301-715-8592.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Enter meeting ID 940-7652-8040 when prompted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number six, we have the fiscal year 22 budget overview and anticipated timeline.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mr. David Murphy, assistant superintendent of finance and operations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mr. Murphy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Mr. Murphy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau, the member Kreatz.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thanks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If I may, as soon as we heard about Chapter 70 from the governor's budget a week or two ago,

[Lungo-Koehn]: And as soon as we heard about the cut of almost a million dollars in the charter school reimbursement.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I made sure it's when I talked to my finance our finance team that we let the city council on the school committee know right away so that's why you did get the email on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: the tough news and along the lines of the federal stimulus for the good news of the Medford public schools, thankfully getting a little bit over $2 million.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But with that, brings us down to about 1.2 in addition, when you subtract and add

[Lungo-Koehn]: it's Chapter 70, charter school tuition, and then federal stimulus four.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So what happened last year, usually in a normal budget cycle, we would know the number to give the school sometime in March, and then the budget would be created and budget hearings would start right away.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Last year, we were so up in the air on every state number, UGA, Chapter 70, charter school reimbursement, we were having

[Lungo-Koehn]: meetings with the lieutenant governor and the governor and the schools was having meetings with Desi and our finance team was having meetings with finance professionals.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And they were telling us the gloom potential 10, 20% cut and on a number of directions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it was really hard.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we knew right up until the end, we didn't know about chapter 70 being held harmless until I think one of the last weeks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: because it was the pandemic and because we're in a recession, we didn't have that number to really give the schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We knew we had to level fund, but that was after the prior finance director already had increased the budget without permission from the city side by almost 5%.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we level funded the school side and we cut almost a million dollars from the city budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thankfully, chapter 70 was held harmless and we were able to add to the school side.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This year I am trying to be as transparent as possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why you got the email from us last week.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And you'll get an update from the city's finance director who's going to come to hopefully our February 22.

[Lungo-Koehn]: school committee meeting to present on revenues and losses thereof in hopes that we can do the best to give the school side a number sometime after that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But everything is ever changing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're praying for Biden, President Biden's next stimulus package, which could help the city and of course the school side because we, city does not want to take from the schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's why we level funded the schools and cut the city side last year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: last year's budget was 52% of that budget plus went to the school side.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are doing everything we can in the toughest of times and we will continue to be transparent and we will continue to do whatever we can to get more money for our schools and that includes me advocating on the state and federal level and I will continue to do so as I know you all will.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I just wanted to make that clear because I appreciate the

[Lungo-Koehn]: City side budget and that most people thought that was great and I agree that school side.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have work we have some work to do, but we're going to get there and just want to clear up a few things.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Anybody else has any questions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, Mr. Murphy.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please be advised that on Wednesday, February 3rd, 2021 at 5 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: there will be a special school committee meeting held through remote participation pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, chapter 38, section 18, and the Governor's March 15th, 2020 order imposing strict limitations of the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specific information

[Lungo-Koehn]: The general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance member of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media websites, an audio or video recording, transcript or other comprehensive record proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since the meeting will be held remotely, participants can log or call in by using the following link or calling number.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 1-929-205-6099.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please enter meeting ID 91451.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 775527 when prompted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, comments or questions can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name, your Medford Street address, your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: While it is possible to submit questions via the Zoom software, we are strongly recommending that you use the email above while we gain familiarity with hosting our meetings online.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The agenda will be as follows, a negotiation in legal matters, executive session to discuss recommendation to approve the memorandum of agreement between the Medford Public Schools and the Medford Teachers Association governing working conditions for 2020-2021 school year, a tentative agreement of which was reached on January 23rd, 2021.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First, we have new business.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is offered by member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Given that attendance is a required first step in educating our students and given that excessive focus on attendance can lead to ill students and staff coming into school when they are contagious and with the potential to harm other students, staff and families, the attendance policy will be sent to the rules policy and equity subcommittee for review and update.

[Lungo-Koehn]: as needed to ensure that it prohibits awards or recognitions of any kind being conferred within Medford Public Schools for perfect attendance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: A motion for, oh, member Kreatz.

[Lungo-Koehn]: given that attendance is a required first step in educating our students and given that excessive focus on attendance can lead to ill students and staff coming to school when they are contagious with the potential to harm other students, staff, and families, the attendance policy will be sent to the rules, policy, and equity subcommittee for review and update as needed to ensure that it prohibits awards

[Lungo-Koehn]: or recognitions of any kind being conferred within the Medford Public School for perfect attendance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Can I just amend it to also, I mean, I think there's a middle ground here to maybe set a prohibit just to review the policy and see if we can come up with some middle ground here, I think.

[Lungo-Koehn]: prohibit doesn't send it to subcommittee to discuss it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But we're also voting with all due respect.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number two, the Rules Policy and Equity Subcommittee shall draft a new policy on field trips that includes the following.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The superintendent or designee will provide a report to this committee no later than 30 days after the completion of every field trip or at the next school committee meeting, whichever is later.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The report will include the number of students that participated, the number of students that were eligible to participate, and the breakdown of selected populations per DESE categories

[Lungo-Koehn]: for each of these groups, those that participated and those that did not, for any field trip that did not include eligible students.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Offered by member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin and Dr. Edouard-Vincent.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I remember asking her,

[Lungo-Koehn]: Did everybody go?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Could everybody afford the ticket?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And she said, yeah, I think almost everybody went.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There was some boys that didn't want to go.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And in my head thinking, I hope they really didn't want to go.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it wasn't just that they couldn't afford it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: some of the France and New York trips, you want that data too, but you also want the data on like the $35 ticket where, so if it's $2 to go to the zoo or $0 to go to the zoo, it's a lot different than a $35 ticket that some families might not be able to afford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 30A, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15th, 2020 order, posing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted

[Lungo-Koehn]: but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford and Medford community media websites and audio or video recording transcript to other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford community media on Comcast channel 22 and Verizon channel 43 at 5 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with a right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording, transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast Channel 22 and Verizon Channel 43 at 4.30 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since the meeting will be held remotely, participants can log or call in by using the following link or call-in number, 1-929-205-6099.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Please enter meeting ID 914-7691-9075 when prompted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then also, if the administration could just send us all the second slideshow so we can use that to help, that would be great.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And thank you for that, the administration.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, thank you for the two slide decks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That was helpful.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know we received the first one.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We'll get the second one, and we can maybe even put them on the website.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, and our next regular meeting

[Lungo-Koehn]: full of holiday chair will be Monday, the 21st.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So everyone's wearing their Christmas pajamas?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Come on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: OK.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Let's do it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have a Medford School Committee regular meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: April 6th, 2020, remote meeting by Zoom, 5.30 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are a little late.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We apologize.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Our budget committee meeting that started at four just went over a bit.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law,

[Lungo-Koehn]: 30A, section 18, and the governor's March 15th, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medford.edu.

[Lungo-Koehn]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via

[Lungo-Koehn]: technological means.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the event that we aren't able to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording, transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast channel 22 and Verizon channel 43 at 5.30 PM.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Since the meeting will be held remotely,

[Lungo-Koehn]: participants can log or call in by using the following link or call in number.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 1-929-205-6099.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Enter this meeting ID when prompted, 713-201-694.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Additionally, questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing medfordsc at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Those submitting must include the following information.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Your first and last name, your Medford Street address, your question or comment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do have questions may I ask I did email you this morning miss Perry We got two attachments from you back at the end of March or mid-march One was about six pages one was 13.

[Lungo-Koehn]: member van de Kloot.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There you go.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Then from what I was able to review, can you just tell me what page eight and nine of 13, which grade that relates to?

[Lungo-Koehn]: That has to do with the describing the signs and symptoms of a pregnancy, divine emergency contraception and its use.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Defining STDs, including HIV, and how they are and are not transmitted.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Analyzing the impact of drugs on safer sex.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Identifying medically accurate information about STDs.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So those two pages, do those relate to one specific grade?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And do you know if this is, if other districts are accepting this model and this curriculum in grade eight?

[Lungo-Koehn]: So what other surrounding cities or towns use page eight and nine in the eighth grade curriculum?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Are there any other questions?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'd just like to make an amendment, just amend the paper or do a side paper just to make sure that if you

[Lungo-Koehn]: If you add page eight or nine to any other grade other than eight through 12, that the school committee be, that it be discussed with the school committee first.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sure.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm not saying for or against it being discussed in sixth or seventh, but I just feel that I would like to have that discussion before anything like that is taught to a sixth or seventh grader.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, I agree.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That specific one, we can exclude from the amendment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's just the ones that I read out loud, I just feel like I think I would need more discussion or actually read the curriculum, the 600 page document before I want my sixth grader to learn about STDs and how to put a condom on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think that deserves much more discussion and a committee of the whole meeting

[Lungo-Koehn]: versus all the hard work that you did in your subcommittee meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, I'd like to, as part of the B paper, make sure that that information's in the handbook and that we do provide it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: different languages like we do for all other communications.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Number four, be it resolved that a playground advisory committee shall be created to oversee the completion of work associated with three CPC grants related to the Columbus and Brooks Playground Repair and Resurfacing and the McGlynn School Design Study.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The work will include collaboration and review of the RFP for the McGlynn Design Study and the execution of the study.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The advisory committee will also view all four school playgrounds and make recommendations regarding increased accessibility of playgrounds to all our students to be completed within the existing scope of funding or provided to the school committee as additional recommendations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The advisory committee shall provide a preliminary update to the school committee no later than June 1st and then quarterly thereafter for up to one year from the date of creation or sooner if work is completed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Cushing will issue a call for interested applicants and recommend members for the playground advisory committee to the school committee no later than, we can change these dates, April 6th, school committee meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The playground advisory committee will include school administrators, at least one parent from each elementary school and individuals with expertise in inclusive play and play spaces offered by member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It was till May 4th.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yep.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to table by member Graham seconded by member.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Would you like to speak member McLaughlin?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Oh, I was just amending it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Amending it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So motion as amended by member Graham, all those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Further recruitment of membership in the advisory committee begin anew at that time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Further that this vision committee shall follow the format of the advisory committee as laid out in the Medford School Committee policy

[Lungo-Koehn]: BDF advisory committees to the school committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think the fall is fine for the committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So just ask them to continue their work, and they have the spring and summer to do that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Mr. Osborne did write something up today letting us know.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He has reached out to the NAACP branch to explore finding a representative with the time, energy, and interest in joining the High School Vision Committee

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had planned a meeting with the leadership of the branch, but the current circumstances required rescheduling that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: As always, found the branch a supportive partner with the city to find local persons who want to serve on our boards, commissions, and committees.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm confident before the end of the summer, we can identify a branch member that we can add to the Medford High School Vision Committee.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So positive news, and I thank Mr. Osborne for helping out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Paper is tabled.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Offered by, okay, be resolved that a playground advisory committee shall be created to oversee the completion of work associated with three CPC grants related to the Columbus and Brooks Playground Repair and Resurfacing and the McGlynn School Design Study.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The work will include collaboration and review of the RFP for the McGlynn Design Study and the execution of the study.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The advisory committee will also view all four school playgrounds and make recommendations regarding increased accessibility of playgrounds to all students to be completed within the existing scope of funding or provided to the school committee as additional recommendations.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The advisory committee shall provide a preliminary update to the school committee no later than June 1st and then quarterly thereafter for up to one year from the date of creation or sooner if work is completed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Dr. Peter Cushing will issue a call for interested applicants and recommend members for the Playground Advisory Committee to the school committee no later than April 6, 2020 at the school committee meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Playground Advisory Committee will include school administrators, at least one parent from each elementary school, and individuals with expertise in inclusive play and play spaces offered by Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Graham, would you like to say anything else on that?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sure, an amendment by Member McLaughlin, and I can work with Dr. Cushing as well with a meeting with the NAACP next week, you can join me, and then I also have additional people on the Disability Commission that weren't put on because there's

[Lungo-Koehn]: many people that wanted to be on it, and there's some parents that I can refer, so we can work together on that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I can help however I can.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Minutes are approved.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Approval of bills, transfer of funds, and approval of payrolls.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion to approve by Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Seconded by Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call vote.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Hunger Free Pledge.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know we have Sarah McGiven and Carol present.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I will read the proclamation to make Medford hunger free, whereas hunger and poverty are issues of grave concern in the United States, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and the city of Medford, whereas Medford is committed to educating people about food insecurity,

[Lungo-Koehn]: and the importance of food banks in alleviating hunger in our communities, whereas food insecurity is a persistent and significant reality in Medford, where one in 10 people, one in eight children, and one in 14 seniors do not know where the next meal will come from, whereas the Greater Boston Food Bank and its member agencies provide vital hunger relief services to our most vulnerable neighbors, whereas Medford shall work with hunger relief organizations to make eastern Massachusetts hunger-free

[Lungo-Koehn]: by supporting access to three healthy meals a day for our residents in need.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Now, therefore, be it resolved that the Medford School Committee does hereby proclaim no later than January 1st, 2028, Medford will be hunger-free and urge all the residents of Medford to take note of this proclamation and participate fittingly in achieving this important goal.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And an advisory committee shall be created to provide specific recommendations for achieving this goal.

[Lungo-Koehn]: with appointments for one year to include at least a teacher, school administrator, nursing representative, adjustment Councilor, food services representative, and three school committee members.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The advisory committee shall provide at least an interim status report within six months of their first meeting and provide a final report to the school committee prior to the end of the one-year term of this advisory committee, given at the City Hall in Medford, Massachusetts this third day in February in the year 2020.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes, YMCA, it's great.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by Member Van der Kloot, seconded by Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call vote, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call vote has been requested.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 7 in the affirmative, 0 in the negative.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The paper passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This proclamation will now go to the City Council tomorrow night and hopefully as one unified

[Lungo-Koehn]: While we're under suspension, member Van der Kloot, resolution number five, as well as participation from our students that we have here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Is that correct?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it resolved that the Medford, this is offered by myself, with regards to the minimum wage question that a number of us have been asked.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it resolved that the school committee hold a committee of the whole meeting to discuss minimum wage for all employees.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Be it further resolved that the administration provide the school committee with a list of all

[Lungo-Koehn]: do not receive minimum wage and what the cost per year would be to make that change.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know there are a number of people that want to speak on that so we'll open up the floor to you and hopefully within the next 30 to 40 days we will hold a committee of the whole to get all the facts and figures before us as well as the law.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Committee of the whole meeting is a meeting that we have that isn't so formal.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sometimes we had one today at 5.30.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That one was televised.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This may be a little bit different.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We were talking about personnel, so we may have to go into executive session where we have to speak about personnel matters behind closed doors, but we can reconvene after we figure things out and make a full report, whether it's that night or after that night, letting the public know what facts and figures, anything that's public, we can release that afterwards.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Also, I know this may affect other positions in the budget, so we really need to give our finance department a little, even if it's a couple of weeks, just to get facts and figures before us so that we have the answers to the questions we're all going to have in committee of the whole meeting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think two weeks, maybe Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Patterson can enlighten us on how long that might take just

[Lungo-Koehn]: make sure we know every single position that will be affected, how many we have in that position, just like my motion reads.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I would hope within two weeks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Not necessarily, but if we're going to talk about different people in different positions, then yes, parts of it would have to go into executive session.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We can just, yep, whatever has to go into executive session, whether that's five, 10, 20 minutes to an hour, and then you can open it up to the general public.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I haven't weeded through them all, but I just kind of look to see how many.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But along those lines.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Given the creation of ad hoc reports at the behest of the School Committee can require substantial effort on the part of the Office of the Superintendent and her staff, and that the School Committee often depends on these ad hoc reports to assist in deliberations,

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Rules, Policy, and Equity Subcommittee shall generate a new rule for the School Committee to guide how ad hoc reports requests are generated.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by Member Van der Kloot, seconded by Member Kreatz.

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those in favor?

[Lungo-Koehn]: All those opposed?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member McLaughlin.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To this full committee where it can be changed or amended and then voted on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You're welcome.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay, motion for approval by Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Vanjie Clute, seconded by Ms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion passes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Offered by Vice Chair Rousseau, given that several periodic reports are required by law, regulation, past practice, and best practice,

[Lungo-Koehn]: The Rules, Policy, and Equity Subcommittee shall promulgate an annual schedule of such reports to provide the superintendent, the school committee, and the public a transparent and concise understanding of when to expect these reports.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Motion for approval by Member Van der Kloot, seconded by Member Graham.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If you could first just please read the resolve one more time.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, yes, I think that's the least that needs to be done at this point in the city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Move approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I believe we have the chief of police here tonight, and I just want to thank him for coming.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know that a number of things have transpired over the last several days and a couple months, and I know that it's under an active investigation, and what I want to say is, since the police department has found out about this, on Friday, there has been an active investigation, and I'm

[Lungo-Koehn]: really thankful for what the chief and the detectives have done so far.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't know what can be said tonight, but I think there's a lot of unanswered questions, and if the chief could tell us what he can, I think that would be important for the public and the parents and the staff of every school within this city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'll just stop there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just ask that, I know that's Mr. Edwards' story today.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just also ask that Mr. Edwards' other three stories be told as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But when you found out in January, what did you know?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Was that the same story?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm telling you what I know.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So you're going by the latest story, but what you were told in January, you're just going to go with the latest?

[Lungo-Koehn]: I've heard four stories so far.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: One question I have is with regards to, you said you authorized the sweep today and that was done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm thankful for that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm thankful that there's going to be sweeps within all of our schools in this city.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I guess my question goes to why didn't you think this was necessary when you found out in January?

[Lungo-Koehn]: A sweep of the school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That could have been there for weeks, and it was just found on the 28th.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And what's clear to me is that you mentioned there was a plausible

[Lungo-Koehn]: reason why it was there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I just want to point out there's hundreds of reasons how it could have got there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that makes the parents and the staff extremely uncomfortable with how this was handled.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I question many people's judgment on this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I guess a question now that a lot of people have, and there's a lot of questions that people have, is especially personnel that work there, because my

[Lungo-Koehn]: phone has gone off the hook since the staff has been notified as of like 2 p.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: today, they don't feel comfortable with the judgment that was made obviously by you, but by the principal of that school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I am under the impression he threw it away, and that's what I was told.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if you knew in January, I question what he told you then.

[Lungo-Koehn]: you know, why it wasn't reported to the police.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, I mean, I'm not gonna say too much.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I do know some of the results of the investigation that the police are working on, but what changes are gonna be made in staff before Monday?

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think by not doing anything with administration, by the school committee not doing anything with the administration is poor judgment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And by our superintendent of schools, who the people want to see do the right thing

[Lungo-Koehn]: and to wait till the spring where parents and personnel at that school are extremely uncomfortable.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it's sending the wrong message.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I hope the school committee does what they have to do on Thursday night, because this is something that cannot be repeated, and multiple things need to happen, including, I'm just beside myself,

[Lungo-Koehn]: We have not done lockdown drills in our schools this year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think we did them once, and they've only been done one time last year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: You also have the staff who is extremely concerned because they've never done evacuation drills from cafeterias or auditoriums.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There are personnel who are scared to take their children into the auditorium.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I was there with my family a couple weeks ago, and I mean, this affects

[Lungo-Koehn]: hundreds of people that are at that school.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And this affects our whole community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it's something that really, this cannot be tolerated.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I'm, again, thankful for the police and their investigation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I hope that all the questions that are being asked on social media, and I'm sure are going to be asked tonight, I hope they're answered.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I know that once the investigation is done, I know they will be answered.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm not going to answer them, although I know a lot of the answers, because the investigation is active.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But people, every single parent, and every single personnel at that school deserves every answer eventually.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And the sooner, the better.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I thank councilor Scarpelli for his comments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just have a point of information on that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't think that the school committee needs to move on this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I believe that somebody that knew about it in January has to be evaluated as well.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that's my comment on that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My other last two questions, to wrap it up, would be for the Chief of Police.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Having multiple, multiple people come to me with this information, very upset about it, obviously for the safety of themselves, their fellow staff members, and the children.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then days later, knowing that I had to handle it, and they obviously needed to be handled, they now fear retaliation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So as a chief of police that has done everything right since I came to you on Friday, I want you to know this is the fear of personnel in that building, that they fear retaliation from the principal and from the administration.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I want them to know, have your comment on that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Or if it was placed there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So there'll be no retaliation of personnel in the building is what you're telling me.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And because you're the one I trust that's here tonight, our children are safe to go to any of the Medford public schools on Monday morning.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And my reason for, you know, I really want to, I think I should mention my reason for asking about the retaliation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's because I've received a number of complaints over the last

[Lungo-Koehn]: a couple years, a number of complaints on a whole host of issues with regards to administration at McGlynn, that administrator, including retaliation, including a whole host of things that I did let the superintendent know at our committee of the whole meeting in June.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I just think it's extremely important because you do have a lot of scared personnel out there that fear retaliation from losing their job to a whole host of things.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I just,

[Lungo-Koehn]: really bothers me that they feel that way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And, and I understand where their concern is coming from.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So, um, I just think that's extremely important to bring up and make sure the chief is aware of.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I go to the people I trust.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I emailed the school committee, the mayor this morning at 6 a.m.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and they found out Friday.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm not sure about the mayor, but the school committee woman, one school committee woman said the school committee was notified Friday.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Just on that, I thank Councilor Falco for asking that it be here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It is a concerning spot.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think the council in the last year or so has learned a great deal about community aggregation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We've had a number of meetings relating to it, and we also have had a very informative meeting back, I believe, in September with the energy environment director in Melrose, which I think,

[Lungo-Koehn]: personally, for me, helped answer a lot of my questions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it was great to see another community and how the plan is succeeding.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think one concern I do have is just Medford's ability to notify people of their rights and the ability to opt out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And when I do get emails or phone calls or people stop me in the street to talk about community aggregation, 80% want to

[Lungo-Koehn]: move forward with it and implement it in the city of Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But there are some, a good 20% if I, just going off the people that contact me, there are people that don't want government telling them what to do, what plan to go into, and they too are concerned that this 30-day opt-out, when it does become available, if potentially the council is to vote for it, there's just many concerns.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They want to make sure that that opt-out plan is

[Lungo-Koehn]: well publicized, and people know how to do it, and where to go, and who to talk to, who to ask questions to.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And one resident brought this up to me, and we discussed it in depth.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What if an opt-out plan was implemented, just even a database, a list of people that would relieve some of the 20% that I'm calculating from the people that I talk to, relieve them of their fears, and let them know that, no, we're not going to hide the fact that you can opt out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If you want to, you can do it now, just in case something is implemented.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know it's a reach, but it's something that was requested by a resident, and I don't think it's a bad idea.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think the community aggregation is something that we're going to talk about within the next several months.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we just need to be ready on all accounts.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I move this forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it's definitely something worth exploring.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's simple.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's just a database.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It could be an Excel spreadsheet of people that want to be

[Lungo-Koehn]: listed as not being involved in this community aggregation from the get-go, and it would give a peace of mind to those who are not interested, and maybe it would help us get the votes, maybe unanimous, maybe not, but it would get votes to implement the plan, which I know a large percentage of Medford wants to work on and work towards.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I understand the sentiments of my colleagues.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just, I don't feel, I have to just speak again on it, I guess.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't feel that it would take a great amount of resources to start an Excel spreadsheet and people

[Lungo-Koehn]: call or write in, shoot a quick email to say they want to be on the opt-out list.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I actually think that it would ease a lot of people's fears, those that definitely do not want to be part of this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it's simple, take minutes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I agree with Councilor Dello Russo, there is an agenda for the Office of Environment and Energy, but I don't think that that's what the people are concerned about, that the agenda won't be notifying people accordingly on their

[Lungo-Koehn]: option to opt out, how many days they have to do it, and the fact that they can opt out whenever, they're going to be put in if they don't opt out within that first 30 days.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And that's what people are concerned about.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that's why you would implement something like this far beforehand, and you would be able to create that list, and people would be able to say, I want to opt out, and they would get what they want.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The people that don't want to be involved

[Lungo-Koehn]: would be able to do that sooner than later.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And when the council does meet in committee of the whole again, maybe there would be the definite votes for it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think we're definitely close to it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I know people have definitely changed their minds.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And they've learned a lot.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There are some people that maybe are still against it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But for me, this is something that would make me feel a whole lot better knowing that they have more than that 30 days.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Because that's the complaints I've been getting.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I thought this was just a way

[Lungo-Koehn]: sway another vote towards approving it and ease in people's fears.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll say it again.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I move approval.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'd like to see how it goes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And of course, we'll be meeting on it again in Committee of the Whole, probably after the holidays.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the Medford transcript, it's a rain garden coming to Wright's Pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The city of Medford is constructing a rain garden at the Middlesex Falls Pond that will help filter out pollutants, including phosphorus, nitrogen, suspended solids, and bacteria.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It will also be designed to conserve water.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it's a project they're gonna do in the near future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The rain garden project will cost the city a total of $50,000.

[Lungo-Koehn]: and is a match project for $125,000 grant that Medford received from the Massachusetts Office of Coastal Zone Management.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I can go into more detail, there's another few paragraphs, but it was on page A3 of the Medford transcript.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The rain gutter will contain plants that soak up phosphorus, nitrogen from rainwater before it flows into Wright's Pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it seems like a natural way to remove

[Lungo-Koehn]: Obviously chemicals from the pond, so anything we have with regards to a grant to be able to do this I think is extremely important, especially I have another resolution on where the article does mention some concerning things as well, but I think the rain garden is definitely a step in the right direction.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's only going to help better the pond, especially for the hundreds of kids that swim in that pond every summer.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 17711, but just to respond, I'm not really sure what the confusion is.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sometimes when you get a state or federal grant,

[Lungo-Koehn]: It changes the parameters of how we operate, so we are making sure that the hundreds of families that use it from Medford, it remains only Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This was a big issue back about a year ago when some of the law was looked into and they were potentially going to be opening it up to non-Medford residents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: the city will kind of... Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I wanted to bring this up.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I had a second resident email me with regards to the same article.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the second part of the article, it mentions how the city stores plowed snow on Rice Pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And residents have grown increasingly concerned about pollutants in the pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then our energy and environment director said because the city

[Lungo-Koehn]: City stores plowed piles of snow near the pond in the winter, which runs into the pond when it melts.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is a way for the runoff to get clean, treated, and filtered naturally.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Hopefully the rain guards will help that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But it says we've tested what is there, but there's a perception that there's bad stuff running off in there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So a resident who does frequent the pond called me, also asked me to reference the article, and it is concerning that we're putting plowed snow there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So my next, this resolution and the next has to do with figuring out if we can maybe do it another way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we have runoff, there's a number of different things that are coming off the snow within the snow that are being stored at Wright's Pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Maybe we should look into it more.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if this is a problem, then we can hopefully store the snow somewhere else because we want to make sure that we're keeping the pond as safe and clean as possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know that a resident was interested in the topic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm not sure if I can name him, but did reach out to the director of the Mystic River Watershed Association, who thought that piling up snow and allowing it to run into the pond is a poor choice.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think this is just something that definitely needs to be looked into.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we have piled snow that can be put somewhere else, I think we need to do that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So if we could have a response from our energy and environment office with regards to if there's been any testing, if so, what type of testing and when, that would be extremely helpful.

[Lungo-Koehn]: figure out what's going on here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilor Knight.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the Medford transcript, it's a rain garden coming to Wright's pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Um, the city of Medford is constructing a rain garden at the Middlesex fawn pond, fells pond that will help filter out pollutants, including phosphorus, nitrogen, suspended solids, and bacteria.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It will also,

[Lungo-Koehn]: be designed to conserve water.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it's a project they're going to do in the near future.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The rain garden project will cost the city a total of $50,000 and is a match project for a $125,000 grant that Medford received from the Massachusetts Office of Coastal Zone Management.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I can go into more detail, there's another few paragraphs, but it was on page A3 of the Medford transcript.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The rain garden will contain plants that soak up phosphorus, nitrogen,

[Lungo-Koehn]: from rainwater before it flows into Wright's Pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it seems like a natural way to remove obviously chemicals from the pond, so anything we have with regards to a grant to be able to do this I think is extremely important, especially I have another resolution on where the article does mention some concerning things as well, but I think the rain garden is definitely a step in the right direction.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Better the pond especially for the hundreds of kids that swim in that pond every every summer.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'll move approval of the question, Mr. President.

[Lungo-Koehn]: 17711, but just to respond, I'm not really sure what the confusion is.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sometimes when you get a state or federal grant,

[Lungo-Koehn]: It changes the parameters of how we operate.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we are making sure that the hundreds of families that use it from Medford, it remains only Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This was a big issue back about a year ago when some of the law was looked into and they were potentially going to be opening it up to non-Medford residents.

[Lungo-Koehn]: the city will kind of.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I wanted to bring this up.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I had a second resident email me with regards to the same article.

[Lungo-Koehn]: In the second part of the article, it mentions how the city stores plowed snow on Rice Pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And residents have grown increasingly concerned about pollutants in the pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then our energy and environment director said because the city

[Lungo-Koehn]: City stores plowed piles of snow near the pond in the winter, which runs into the pond when it melts.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is a way for the runoff to get clean, treated, and filtered naturally.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Hopefully the rain guards will help that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But it says we've tested what is there, but there's a perception that there's bad stuff running off in there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So a resident who does frequent the pond called me, also asked me to reference the article.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And it is concerning that we're putting plowed snow there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So this resolution and the next has to do with figuring out if we can maybe do it another way.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we have runoff, there's a number of different things that are coming off the snow within the snow that are being stored at Wright's Pond.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Maybe we should look into it more.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if this is a problem, then we can hopefully store the snow somewhere else because we want to make sure that we're keeping the pond as safe and clean as possible.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know that a resident was interested in the topic.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm not sure if I can name him, but did reach out to the director of the Mystic River Watershed Association, who thought that piling up snow and allowing it to run into the pond is a poor choice.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think this is just something that definitely needs to be looked into.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we have piled snow that can be put somewhere else, I think we need to do that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So if we could have a response from our Energy and Environment Office with regards to if there's been any testing, if so, what type of testing and when, that would be extremely helpful.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And if we haven't, then maybe we should see how the rain garden goes once it's implemented, then potentially do some testing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That's obviously not my forte, but if we could kind of

[Lungo-Koehn]: figure out what's going on here.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I will be much appreciated.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If we could just have the Department of Public Works and or the administration, let the city council know where snow is, is kept.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Um, when we take it off our streets, I think that just goes hand in hand with the prior resolution to try to make sure we're storing it in the right place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Aye.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I thought that was real call, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: section 37 M a notwithstanding the provisions of chapter 41 or chapter 71 or any other special general law to the contrary any city or town which accepts this provision of the section may consolidate administrative functions including but not limited to financial personnel and maintenance functions of the school committee with those of the city or town provided however that such consolidation may occur only upon a majority vote of both the school committee and

[Lungo-Koehn]: in the city, the city council with approval of the mayor required by law or in a town, the annual town meeting or in a town with no town meeting, the town council.

[Lungo-Koehn]: B, notwithstanding any general or special law to the contrary, decision to consolidate functions pursuant to paragraph A of this section may be revoked by a majority vote of either the school committee of the city or town or the city of town or both as such vote is described in said paragraph A. I put this before you,

[Lungo-Koehn]: is it was something that's been talked about from when I was a city councilor.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I believe the conversation started in the 2018 timeframe and it never fully moved forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So this is the way you have to accept it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Although, you know, I am happy to come before you with any, or I'm sure the school administration is as well with any specific requests.

[Lungo-Koehn]: First and foremost, I think this will help a great deal with facilities.

[Lungo-Koehn]: would go a very long way and make that happen.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So we have contracts set up and running to maintain our not-so-new schools anymore.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So just ask for your approval on this paper.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We will keep you up to date on anything moving forward and happy to request a vote if need be, but definitely we'll keep you updated.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Member Ruseau.

[Lungo-Koehn]: No, I understood it that once you accept this, it can be done, but it would have to come before the school committee for any type of budgetary vote.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So if this money is coming out of school monies, then yes, you'd have to vote for it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm not sure the city council would as well, unless it was coming out of city funding, then yes, it would have to be part of a budget or a supplemental budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I would expect tomorrow night that I would hope that they would approve this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I would expect to be paper that it would just be for facilities for now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then we'd have to go before and this body can do the same.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then if we wanna expand that, we can always take another vote.

[Lungo-Koehn]: That may be how some cities and towns handle it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So for example, if you were gonna put

[Lungo-Koehn]: IT under one director fully, and then if you're going to say, yeah, do it with IT, I could see that being the case.

[Lungo-Koehn]: train and get that job done, especially if we're going to have an influx of potential monies that we want to be spent towards maintaining our schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I do.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm gonna abstain and not take part in this discussion.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Okay.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Sorry, full disclosure, yeah, my sister's a teacher in the Metropolitan Schools.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is an issue that the city of Boston took up not too long ago.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think after reading about it, after discussing it with our environmental, somebody from our environmental committee, I think it's something that we definitely could benefit from having it in Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know we have

[Lungo-Koehn]: with the engineer's office, potentially getting a new traffic engineer that may help with our issue that we have with the utility companies ripping up our roads and replacing them the way they should.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is also maybe a third issue that potentially could be worked on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This ordinance, which I have the city of Boston's ordinance, which I've reviewed and read, it would entail

[Lungo-Koehn]: Any time the city of Medford opens up a street for any reason or any construction project, any time the street is opened, our utility companies, National Grid, Eversource, would be invited or asked to come and review that portion of the road.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And there would be a hope that they would survey and figure out where there are any potential leaks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Boston estimates they have thousands of gas leaks in their community, and this is a way to reduce that number.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We're a city that's obviously smaller than Boston, but we do have several, many, many gas leaks that I think need to be looked into, and we need to make that a priority.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's not good for the environment.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's not good for public health.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And obviously, so many more reasons why we should be getting on top of these gas leaks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If I could before the roll is called.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Councilor Longo-Kearns.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yeah, I just ask that we, I'm going to send around, I'll email all the councilors the city of Boston's ordinance so that we could maybe take the summer to review.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And then I would just ask that a committee of the whole meeting be set up in September.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And hopefully once we review it, we can implement this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: There's so many other facets to the ordinance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It's about nine pages long, but not only fixing the leaks, but within the ordinance, we can also mandate that anything National Grid or Eversource or any gas company provides to DPU, the Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities, that they provide to the city of Medford.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So our engineer's office, our environment office can use that and help, obviously, do what we need to do

[Lungo-Koehn]: alleviate the many, many leaks that we have in the community.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So it goes into depth and I won't go into it tonight, but I definitely would appreciate if my colleagues would read it so we can go through it and in the early fall and try to get this implemented as soon as we can.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, and I thank Councilor Marks for his comments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think we probably would see a level of times two or three of that 260 number, and that's very concerning, and I agree.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think this ordinance, if we implement it, it would give it some teeth, because if a gas company refuses to survey an open site,

[Lungo-Koehn]: or doesn't repair a leak found at the site, the city will then have the right to deny permits for other street digging they apply for.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think it goes in conjunction with the committee of the whole meeting we had a week or two ago with the engineer's office, where how can we have oversight and how can we put more teeth into it when they're not doing the right thing?

[Lungo-Koehn]: And this would be another avenue to make sure not only are they repairing our street properly when they dig it up, but also come to every single

[Lungo-Koehn]: project that we're doing and make sure these level three leaks are fixed and fixed accordingly.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think it's a tool that the engineer's office would hopefully, especially getting a new position, maybe including this job title in that position, I think we can make a huge dent in these level three leaks that maybe they're not affecting life, but they're killing trees.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Gas leaks kill trees, it kills vegetation, and that's all

[Lungo-Koehn]: outlined in the Boston City of Boston's ordinance.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think it's something that we need to, we've got a lot done this council.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think this is one extra thing that we can include since we're on the utility companies.

[Lungo-Koehn]: This is one extra thing that we can use to not only for the council to have some teeth because we're allowing for certain permits, but the DPW and the engineer's office, it definitely will allow them to, you know, if they, if we can get on top of it, we can make a huge dent in a level three leaks as Boston's doing.

[Lungo-Koehn]: The issue with Boston and other cities and towns implementing this is that National Grid and Eversource are going to focus more on the communities that have these ordinances in place.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So come time when we're one of the only ones that don't have it, we'll be down on the totem pole of when they're going to fix the leaks we do have.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think that this is instrumental in staying on top of it and staying in the 2017 plus time frame of what needs to be done

[Lungo-Koehn]: to cure the problem, so hopefully we can get this done in the fall and move forward.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Roll call, please.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If I could just

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm asking for 2016, 2017.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just want to see the difference in claims from our law department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know that we did meet with Solicitor Rumley yesterday, and he did give us some insight, numbers off the top of his head, with regards to how many claims have been put in.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I think that was great that he was on top of it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I believe it was about 30 claims from pothole and street defects and nine personal injury claims from potholes, two of which were

[Lungo-Koehn]: in addition to were personal injuries from people that were on bicycles that obviously went through a pothole and got injured.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I wanted to know that considering how hard our DPW is working with regards to how many potholes we do have out there.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't know if we had a bad winter, but they're everywhere.

[Lungo-Koehn]: They're getting filled, but there are a number more.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I know we discussed with the DPW contracting out.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I wanted to really see within this budget

[Lungo-Koehn]: how it evens out claims versus filling versus getting a contractor so that we can make an educated decision come next week or the week after when we have to make recommendations and approve or disprove the budget.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I move approval, ask for a roll call vote.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So if I could just read it, I was recently, this is,

[Lungo-Koehn]: From John Coddington, Medford Housing Authority to the Mayor's Office, who thankfully forwarded to us the email reads, I was recently approached by the firm hired by Verizon and charged with wiring the city for Fios.

[Lungo-Koehn]: He sent us some material and I had staff meet with him yesterday about the possibility of wiring our nine MHA public housing sites.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We, as in John Coddington, now plan to visit the Malden Housing Authority to see the quality of their installation work and to talk with them about their experience with the whole process.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If things look acceptable, the next step would be to have the engineers come up with a scope of work and a plan for wiring our 845 apartments.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'm thinking we'll know more within the next four to six weeks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I hope this information helps.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So the 845 units within the Medford Housing Authority, just wanna confirm that Verizon, hopefully Verizon will be installed in 2015 and Mr. Coddington is working on it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And I thank the mayor's office again for getting us a response on this.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just want to, my point of view is I think the city is doing a good thing with the push of this council and Council Marks putting in the thermoplastic sidewalks.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I know we're doing a pilot.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We are doing a pilot program for three crosswalks in the city that should be done within the next

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think it was four or five months.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I think we are moving in a step in the right direction.

[Lungo-Koehn]: If that works, I do agree that we should do many more throughout our community at a rate that we can afford, whether it's five or six per year, however much it costs, that we are able just to afford being able to do that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But I think it is a way to go.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I mean, the paint, I agree, lasts not even a full season.

[Lungo-Koehn]: And we makes it through to the beginning of fall and it's just not effective for the rest of the year.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So that is a way to go.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I just want to make sure that we see how the pilot program goes and do it in stages so that we can afford it.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Thank you, President Mayocko.

[Lungo-Koehn]: My issue comes just with financial.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Not only we have the budget coming up, but the number of bonds that are on the books.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Currently, I'd like to see a breakdown ofwe've got breakdowns before, but I'd like to see a breakdown of what is owed, what will be owed each year for each bond, a total of what is owed.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'd also like, for what we currently have, and then on a second spreadsheet, a breakdown of not only what is currently owed, but also an estimate on what the DPW department to rebuild is going to cost.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'd like that added to the bond worksheet.

[Lungo-Koehn]: as well as we need an update on what's going on with the police department.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We basically, you know, I believe it needs to be expanded on.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I don't think evidence being housed in a garage is sufficient, adequate, or reasonable.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I think we need to expand on the police department, but we need to know what the mayor and the city administration is gonna do, whether it's, I don't think it's gonna be rebuilt, but whether it be expand,

[Lungo-Koehn]: rework, refurbish what we need to do at the police station, I'd like that included.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'd also like, now we have a three point, I believe it's a $3.3 million bond that they want to put on the books for the pool at 3%, so that's gonna be a good amount, I'd say 80 to $100,000 a year that we're gonna have to pay back per year on the pool.

[Lungo-Koehn]: So I'd just like to see the figures.

[Lungo-Koehn]: What are we putting on the books?

[Lungo-Koehn]: What are we going to have to pay back from now until the next 15 years?

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need to be able to evaluate that along with the next budget before we can make the decisions.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I mean, everybody wants to see a brand new pool, brand new locker rooms.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I am one of them.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But at the same time, we have the rate payers who are basically screaming to us, what are you doing?

[Lungo-Koehn]: How much money can you spend over a three-year period?

[Lungo-Koehn]: and we have essentials that need to get done.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We do not have a DPW yard now.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It has to be rebuilt.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We had to do what we had to do with the police station, and we have to continue to figure out what the mayor wants to do with that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: We need to be able to evaluate it all before we can make a recommendation.

[Lungo-Koehn]: I'd like to ask for it by next Tuesday, because I know we're in line to get about $500,000 to go toward the $600,000 for the locker rooms of the pool, and time is of the essence for that.

[Lungo-Koehn]: But if so, if we could get this breakdown, hopefully within the next week, it would be appreciated.

[Lungo-Koehn]: It would help me make a determination, um, not only for the students and those who use the pool, but for the, the community as a whole to, to move forward most appropriately.

[Lungo-Koehn]: above ground spectator, um, room to, to investigate the cost of, uh, they said about 30,000 to put in a lift.

[Lungo-Koehn]: Yes.

[Lungo-Koehn]: To the chair.
